The newly elected councilmember shall have the right to appoint a new member to the board in the same manner as his predecessor. The mayor and council shall determine the amount of compensation, if any, to be paid to the members of the board of variance and zoning appeals. No person who holds elective public office shall be eligible to serve as a member during the term of such elective office, and the position of any member shall be deemed vacant upon such member qualifying as a candidate for elective public office, except that members may be also members of the planning and zoning commission. Any vacancy in the membership shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointment. 
(Code 1985, § 22-52)
 
Sec. 2-160. Officers; meetings; rules of procedure.
The board of variance and zoning appeals shall elect one of its members as chairperson, who shall serve for one year or until he is reelected or his successor is elected. The board of variance and zoning appeals shall adopt rules in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Meetings of the board of variance and zoning appeals shall be held at the call of the chairperson and at such other times as the board may determine. The chairperson, or in his absence the acting chairperson, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoena. The board of variance and zoning appeals shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be immediately filed in the office of community affairs and shall be a public record. 
(Code 1985, § 22-53)
 
Sec. 2-161. Powers.
(a)	The board of variance and zoning appeals shall have the power to: 
(1)	Hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative official in the enforcement of this chapter. 
(2)	Authorize upon appeal in specific cases such variance from the terms of this chapter as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this chapter will, in an individual case, result in unnecessary hardship, so that the spirit of this chapter shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured, and substantial justice done. The existence of nonconforming use of neighboring land, buildings, or structures in the same district or of permitted or nonconforming uses in other districts shall not constitute a reason for the requested variance. Such variance may be granted in such individual case of unnecessary hardship upon a finding by the board of variance and appeals that: 
a.	There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question because of its size, shape or topography that are not applicable to other lands or structures in the same district; 
b.	The application of this chapter to this particular piece of property would create an unnecessary hardship; 
c.	Such conditions are peculiar to the particular piece of property involved; and 
d.	Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purposes and intent of this chapter. 
No variance may be granted for a use of land or building or structure that is prohibited by this chapter. No variance may be granted that would conflict with or alter a stipulation or condition imposed by the mayor and council. 
(b)	In exercising the powers described in subsection (a) of this section, the board of variance and zoning appeals may, in conformity with the provisions of this chapter, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determination, and to that end shall have all the powers of the building official and may issue or direct the issuance of a permit. 
(Code 1985, § 22-54)
 
Sec. 2-162. Appeal procedure; effect of appeal.
(a)	Appeals to the board of variance and zoning appeals may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any officer, department, board or bureau of the city affected by any decision of the building official or other city official based on this article. Such appeal shall be taken within 30 days or as provided by the rules of the board of variance and zoning appeals, by filing with the building official and with the board of variance and zoning appeals a written notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. All papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken shall forthwith be transmitted to the board of variance and zoning appeals. 
(b)	An appeal stays all legal proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the officer from whom the appeal is taken certifies to the board of variance and zoning appeals, after the notice of appeal shall have been filed with him, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life and property. In such case, proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order, which may be granted by the board of variance and zoning appeals or by a court of record on application, on notice to the officer from whom the appeal is taken, and on due cause shown. 
(c)	The board of variance and zoning appeals shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal or other matter referred to it, and give public notice thereof, as well as due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the matter within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. 
(Code 1985, § 22-55)
 
Sec. 2-163. Appeals from decision of board.
Any person severally or jointly aggrieved by any decision of the board of variance and zoning appeals may take an appeal to the superior court. The appeal to the superior court shall be by writ of certiorari. Such appeal may be filed within 30 days from the date of the decision of the board of variance and zoning appeals, and upon failure to file the appeal within 30 days the decision of the board of variance and zoning appeals shall be final. 
(Code 1985, § 22-56)
 
Secs. 2-164—2-173. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 4. DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITIES
 
Sec. 2-174. Industrial development authority.
(a)	Established. The city council has established the public body corporate and politic known as the Development Authority of Austell. 
(b)	Appointment of board of directors; terms of members. The authority shall have a board of directors of the development authority appointed by the city council, each member of which shall be a taxpayer of the city and a resident of the city. The members shall serve staggered four-year terms. The terms of three of the first members shall expire in December 1994, and the terms of four of the first members expire in December 1996. Thereafter, each member shall be appointed to a four-year term. 
(c)	Organization of board; duties and responsibilities. The board of directors of the authority shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 36, ch. 62, development authorities. 
(d)	Scope, intent and applicability. The action taken by the mayor and council of the city, as herein specified, is not intended in any way to affect any public corporation, industrial development, downtown development, or payroll authority previously created by legislative act or constitutional amendment including, without limitation, its existence, purpose, organization, powers or function. 
(Code 1985, §§ 18-31—18-34; Res. of 4-1-1985; Ord. of 11-8-1993)
 
Sec. 2-175. Downtown development authority.
(a)	Established. The city council has established the public body the public body corporate and politic known as the Downtown Development Authority of Austell. 
(b)	Appointment of board of directors; terms of members. The city council has established a board of directors of the downtown development authority. Members of the board, appointed by the city council, shall be taxpayers of the city, residing in the city. Not less than four members shall either have or represent a party who has an economic interest in the redevelopment and revitalization of the downtown development area. The members shall be appointed for a four-year term. 
(c)	Organization of board; duties and responsibilities. The board of directors shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 36, ch. 62, development authorities. 
(d)	Area of jurisdiction. The downtown development area shall be that geographical area described in a metes and bounds description of the central business district of the city including the Clarkdale Mill Village area and such other areas as may be designated from time to time by the city council. The metes and bounds description, as amended from time to time, shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and with the board of directors of the authority. 
(e)	Scope, intent and applicability. The action taken by the mayor and council of the city, as herein specified, is not intended in any way to affect any public corporation, industrial development, downtown development, or payroll authority previously created by legislative act or constitutional amendment including, without limitation, its existence, purpose, organization, powers or function. 
(Code 1985, §§ 18-16—18-20; Res. of 11-22-1982; Mo. of 11-5-1984; Res. of 11-14-1994, § 1)
 
Secs. 2-176—2-183. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE VI. FINANCE
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 2-184. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accrual basis means the basis of accounting under which revenues are recorded when earned or when levies are made, and expenditures are recorded as soon as they result in liabilities, notwithstanding that the receipt of the revenue or payment of the expenditure may take place, in whole or in part, in another accounting period. 
Appropriation means an authorization granted by the city to make expenditures or to incur obligations for specific purposes. 
Assets means property of all kinds of a government, including both current assets and fixed assets. 
Audit means the examination of records, documents, reports, systems of internal control, accounting and financial procedures, and other evidence for one or more of the following purposes: 
(1)	To ascertain whether the statements prepared from the accounts present fairly the financial position and the results of financial operations of the constituent funds and balanced account groups of the governmental unit in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles applicable to governmental units and on a basis consistent with that of the preceding year; 
(2)	To determine the propriety, legality, and mathematical accuracy of a governmental unit's financial transactions; 
(3)	To ascertain whether all financial transactions have been properly recorded; and 
(4)	To ascertain the stewardship of public officials who handle and are responsible for the financial resources of a governmental unit. 
Balance sheet means a statement ordinarily prepared from books kept by double entry showing assets, liabilities, reserves and surplus of a fund of a governmental unit at a specified date properly classified to exhibit financial position of the fund or unit at the date. 
Bona fide competitive bidding means that a reasonable effort is made to make potential suppliers aware of the purchases to be made and that each potential supplier has a reasonable opportunity to bid on the item to be purchased. 
Budget means a plan of financial operation embodying an estimate of proposed expenditures for a given time and the proposed means of financing them. The annual budget refers to a period of one year. 
Cash basis means the system of accounting under which revenues are accounted for only when received in cash, and expenditures are accounted for only when paid. 
Debt service means the amount of money necessary annually to pay the interest on the outstanding debt and the principal of maturing bonded debt not payable from a sinking fund and to provide a fund for the redemption of bonds payable from a sinking fund. 
Delinquent taxes means taxes remaining unpaid on and after the date on which a penalty for nonpayment is attached. Even though the penalty may be subsequently waived and a portion of the taxes may be abated or canceled, the unpaid balances continue to be delinquent taxes until abated, canceled, or converted into tax liens. 
Fund means a sum of money or other resources (gross or net) set aside for the purpose of carrying on specific activities or to attain certain objectives in accordance with special regulations, restrictions, or limitations. A fund is a distinct financial and legal entity. 
Internal audit means an audit made by persons on the staff on the governmental unit whose accounts are being audited primarily for the purpose of internal control. The term "note" means an internal audit is usually a continuous audit. 
Liabilities means debts owed. 
Millage is a term used to express the property tax rate. The term "millage" is derived from the term "mil," which is one-tenth of a cent; thus, ten mils equal one cent or one percent. For tax purposes, millage is determined by dividing the total amount of money to be raised by the total assessed value of the city. 
Taxes receivable means the uncollected portion of taxes which a governmental unit has levied. 
(Code 1985, § 11-20; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 3)
 
Sec. 2-185. Objectives.
The objective of this article is to establish and promote minimum fiscal standards for this local government for the purpose of maintaining public confidence in this government by the demonstration and recognition of fiscal responsibility. 
(Code 1985, § 11-21; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 1)
 
Sec. 2-186. Administration.
The responsibility for the proper execution of the provisions of this article shall be with the finance director except where the responsibility is explicitly given to the city or others. 
(Code 1985, § 11-22; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 2; Ord. of 1-6-1997, § XV)
 
Sec. 2-187. Fiscal year.
The fiscal year of the city shall begin on July 1 of each year and end on June 30 next following. The fiscal year shall constitute the budget year and the year for the financial accounting and reporting of each office, department, or institution, agency and activity of the city government, unless otherwise provided by city ordinance or state or federal law. 
(Code 1976, § 3-1001; Code 1985, § 11-23; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 4)
 
Sec. 2-188. Modified accrual basis of accounting.
To the extent possible, the modified accrual basis of accounting shall be used so that expenditures, other than accrued interest on long term debt, are recorded at the time liabilities are incurred and revenues are recorded when cash is received, except for material or available revenues which shall be accrued to reflect properly the taxes levied and the revenues earned. All receipts and disbursements shall be posted promptly and at least on a monthly basis. To the extent possible all interfund transfers shall be cleared by the end of the fiscal year. 
(Code 1985, § 11-35; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 17)
 
Sec. 2-189. Financial statements and reports.
Financial statements and reports showing the current conditions of budgetary and proprietary accounts shall be prepared and presented to the city at least every six months. Not later than six months after the close of the fiscal year, a comprehensive annual financial report covering all funds and financial operations shall be prepared and published. A summary of this report, containing at least a statement of revenues and expenditures as of the close of the preceding fiscal year and the combined balance sheet for all funds and account groups, will be available online and in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1985, § 11-36; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 18)
 
Sec. 2-190. Audit.
All the funds, accounts and financial transactions of the city shall be subjected to an annual audit by an independent certified public accountant who is to be selected by the mayor and city council. The audit shall be conducted according to the standards set forth in the American Institute of Certified Public Accountant's publication, "Audits of State and Local Governmental Units." The accountant shall file a report with the city and shall prepare a summary of the report which shall be furnished and made available to the mayor and every councilmember. 
(Code 1976, § 3-1002; Code 1985, § 11-43; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 19)
 
Sec. 2-191. Revenue bonds and short-term notes.
The city shall have the power to issue bonds for the purpose of raising revenue to carry out any project, program or venture authorized under this Code or general state law. This bond authority shall be exercised in accordance with the state laws governing bond issuances by municipalities in effect at the time the issue is undertaken. Revenue bonds may be issued by the city as state law now or hereafter provides. Such bonds are to be paid out of any revenue produced by the project, program or venture for which they are issued. 
(Code 1976, §§ 3-3001—3-3003; Code 1985, §§ 11-40—11-42)
 
Sec. 2-192. Appropriation transfer or lapse.
No appropriation transfer shall be made from a sinking fund or debt retirement fund until all the legal obligations and requirements of such fund have been satisfied. All appropriations which are not obligated, encumbered or expended at the end of the fiscal year shall lapse and shall become a part of the unencumbered surplus which may be appropriated for the next fiscal year. 
(Code 1985, §§ 11-30—11-31; Ord. of 7-11-1983, §§ 11, 13)
 
Sec. 2-193. Community development block grants; procurement policy.
The city shall procure and manage the community development block grant projects according to procurement policy regulations outlined in 24 CFR 85.36 of the administrative requirements for all community development block grant funded along with all applicable regulations relative thereto. The policy shall be adopted by reference. 
(Code 1985, § 16-3; Ord. of 1-4-1999, § 16-2)
 
Secs. 2-194—2-224. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. BUDGET
 
Sec. 2-225. Statement of anticipated revenues.
The mayor shall present the statement of anticipated revenues on the basis of the ordinary and reasonable revenues which can be expected for the fiscal year. Property tax revenue estimates shall be based upon the anticipated tax digest, less a stated discount for delinquent taxes based on a consideration of the taxes which were delinquent at the close of the three prior fiscal years, plus a stated amount of delinquent taxes, including penalties and interest, to be collected in the fiscal year based on consideration of the actual experience in the collection of delinquent taxes in the three prior fiscal years. 
(Code 1985, § 11-24; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 12; Ord. of 1-6-1997, § XVI; Ord. of 4-7-1997, § 3)
 
Sec. 2-226. Time for adoption of budget; temporary expenditures.
(a)	An annual budget will be adopted by the city prior to the first day of the fiscal year. However, if for good and sufficient reasons the budget cannot be adopted by the first day of the fiscal year, the budget shall be adopted not later than 45 days subsequent to the beginning of the fiscal year. If the budget is not adopted prior to the beginning of the fiscal year, a resolution authorizing the continuation of necessary and essential expenditures to operate the city shall be adopted prior to the beginning of the fiscal year. 
(b)	The proposed budget shall be prepared by the finance department and made available for review a minimum of 45 days before the required date of adoption. The budget as adopted shall be a balanced budget with anticipated revenues (including appropriated unencumbered surplus) equal to appropriated expenditures. All funds within the budget shall also be balanced. 
(Code 1985, § 11-25; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 5; Ord. of 4-7-1997, § 3)
 
Sec. 2-227. Copy of budget filed for inspection.
At the time the proposed budget is submitted to the mayor and council, a copy will be be made available for public inspection in the office of the city clerk during regular office hours. 
(Code 1985, § 11-26; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 7; Ord. of 4-7-1997, § 3)
 
Sec. 2-228. Public hearing on budget.
No earlier than seven days after the proposed budget is transmitted to members of the city council and no later than the time that the budget is adopted by the city, a public hearing shall be held to give the public the opportunity to comment upon the proposed budget. Notice of the public hearing shall be given in a newspaper of general circulation in the city no more than 20 days and no less than five days in advance of the hearing. 
(Code 1985, § 11-27; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 8)
 
Sec. 2-229. Approval of adoption of budget.
The adoption of the budget shall be accomplished by the approval of a budget resolution which specifies the anticipated revenues by appropriate categories and the appropriated expenditures for each department and each non-departmental expense and for each fund covered by the budget. Amendments to the budget shall be approved by resolution. 
(Code 1985, § 11-28; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 9)
 
Sec. 2-230. Budget amendment; transfer of appropriations generally.
Any increase in appropriation in a departmental budget or in a non-departmental expense category, whether accomplished through a change in anticipated revenues or through a transfer of appropriations among departments and non-departmental expenses, shall require the approval of the city in the form of an amendment to the budget resolution. The transfer of appropriations among the various accounts within a departmental budget or within a non-departmental expense category shall not require the approval of the city; except that any transfer of appropriations within a departmental budget so as to increase the salary appropriation for the purpose of employing additional personnel shall require the approval of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 3-1006; Code 1985, § 11-29; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 10)
 
Secs. 2-231—2-253. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. FUNDS AND ACCOUNTS
 
Sec. 2-254. Fund establishment authorized.
The following funds may be established and shall be used as necessary to provide for the proper accounting of all financial activities of this city: 
(1)	The general fund to account for the general governmental operations and all financial transactions not properly accounted for in another fund. 
(2)	Special revenue funds to account for the proceeds of special revenue sources, other than special assessments, or to finance specified activities as required by law or administrative regulation. 
(3)	Debt service funds to account for the payment of interest and principal on long term debt other than special assessment and revenue bonds. 
(4)	Capital projects funds to account for the receipt and disbursement of monies, including bond funds used, for the acquisition of capital facilities other than those financed by special assessment and enterprise funds. 
(5)	Enterprise (utility) funds to account for the financing of services to the general public where all or most of the costs involved are paid in the form of charges by users of such services. 
(6)	Trust and agency funds to account for assets held by the city as trustee or agent for individuals, private organizations, and other governmental units. 
(7)	Intergovernmental service funds to account for the financing of special activities and services performed by a designated organization unit within the city for other organization units within the city. 
(8)	Special assessment funds to account for special assessments levied to finance public improvements or services deemed to benefit the properties against which the assessments are levied. 
(Code 1985, § 11-32; Ord. of 7-11-1983, § 14)
 
Sec. 2-255. Accounts established.
A complete self-balancing group of accounts shall be established and maintained for each fund used. This group of accounts shall include all general ledger accounts and subsidiary records necessary to reflect compliance with legal provisions and to set forth the financial position and the results of financial operations of the fund. Additional accounts shall be maintained as follows: 
(1)	A fixed asset account for the purpose of accounting for those assets which: 
a.	Are of a tangible nature; 
b.	Have a life longer than one fiscal year; and 
c.	Have a significant value (or have a value greater than $3,000.00). 
Fixed assets shall be recorded at original cost, shall not be depreciated and shall be removed from the account when disposed of. 
(2)	A general long-term debt account for the purpose of accounting for long term debt which is supported by general revenues and for recording and fairly representing the liability for long term debt at any time from date of issuance until the debt is retired. 
(Code 1985, §§ 11-33, 11-34; Ord. of 7-11-1983, §§ 15, 16)
 
Secs. 2-256—2-273. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 4. PROCUREMENT POLICY
 
Sec. 2-274. Non-budgeted purchases.
(a)	The city council acknowledges that every event cannot be foreseen, but also recognizes that the budget is the basis for the city's financial actions for each respective fiscal year. In keeping with its budget, non-budgeted purchases must be kept to a minimum and subjected to scrutiny, including determination of the degree of necessity for making the purchase. 
(b)	If a department head determines the purchase of a non-budgeted operating or capital item is necessary, he will submit a request for approval to the mayor, citing the reasons the purchase is necessary. If the purchase is approved by the mayor, the budget will be amended or adjusted as provided in this article to accommodate the non-budgeted purchase. 
(c)	The mayor shall notify the council of any non-budgeted capital purchases in excess of $3,000.00 that he has approved at the next regular meeting following the approval and shall obtain formal ratification of the purchase through a budget amendment in the manner provided in this article and by state law. 
 
Sec. 2-275. Budgeted purchases.
(a)	Each department shall be responsible for implementing and enforcing all purchasing rules and regulations and will maintain and distribute to all eligible vendors purchasing rules and regulations as may be written specifically for those vendors. All purchases require department head or designee approval. 
(b)	The finance department shall establish internal procedures for review of all proposed expenditures. The procedure shall have the effect of reserving city funds to cover authorized purchases made within approved appropriations levels based on a modified accrual basis of accounting. 
(c)	All purchasing is done in a competitive environment with qualified vendors being given a reasonable opportunity to do business with the city. 
(d)	To maintain an accurate incremental budget process, purchases should be made against the appropriate accounting code, thus accurately identifying where reductions and increases in specific line items are warranted for future budget years. In the event a particular budget line item, under a particular accounting code, has insufficient funds to allow a proposed purchase, the department head may either: 
(1)	Postpone the purchase until the next fiscal year; 
(2)	Identify a source from within the department budget to cover a shortfall; or 
(3)	Suggest an appropriate budget amendment. 
Resubmitting the documentation with a different accounting code is not permitted. 
 
Sec. 2-276. Criteria for purchases and bids.
(a)	Purchases over $1,000.00 and under $3,000.00. Purchases greater than $1,000.00 and less than $3,000.00 shall be authorized by the respective department heads who are required to document in writing their efforts to obtain at least three written quotes or bids for each purchase. Documentation and all associated paperwork will be maintained by the department. 
(b)	Purchases between $3,000.00 and $25,000.00. The department head, together with the mayor, shall authorize purchases between $3,000.00 and $25,000.00. All such purchases shall require informal (non-advertised, non-sealed) bids. Supporting bid documentation must be in written form. A minimum of three bids must be obtained from qualified vendors who regularly offer or carry the items or services to be purchased. 
(c)	Purchases over $25,000.00. Any purchase in excess of $25,000.00 shall be subject to the following: 
(1)	Must be approved and awarded by the mayor and city council in a regular or special meeting unless otherwise required or permitted pursuant to a county, state or federal negotiated contract purchasing system or law (including, without limitation, O.C.G.A. § 36-69A-4). 
(2)	Must be based on standard specifications that allow maximum competition among qualified vendors whose products or services meet established performance requirements. 
(3)	Such purchases shall require formal competitive sealed bids, which shall be advertised in the state procurement registry pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-80-26; provided, however, any public works construction contract governed by O.C.G.A. § 36-91-22 shall be advertised both in the state procurement registry and in the county newspaper of general circulation at least once no less than one week prior to the date at the time of public bid opening, in accordance with state law. In addition, the city shall make other reasonable efforts to make qualified vendors aware of the purchasing opportunity, including direct notification of potential vendors in the geographical area of the city. 
(4)	Following advertisement and time for bids, no item shall be determined a sole source purchase without the approval of the mayor. In such case, there must submitted to the mayor and city council full documentation of the lack of a competitive market as applicable. 
(5)	The purchasing limitations and authority provided in this section shall be followed in all circumstances. Purchases shall not be split or divided to avoid established bid limits. 
(d)	Alternative procedure when no sealed bids are received. Except as otherwise provided in this section, if no sealed bids are received following two lawfully advertised bids, and upon approval by the mayor and council, the department head shall be authorized without additional advertisement to seek and obtain sealed competitive bids from at least three vendors who commonly deal in such supplies, materials, equipment, or vehicles. This subsection shall not apply to purchases in excess of $25,000.00 or to public works projects as defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-91-1 et seq. 
(e)	Disqualified bidders. No contract shall be awarded to a bidder that is delinquent on any taxes, permit or license fees owed to the city. In addition, no contract shall be awarded to a bidder that is in arrears on an existing contract with the city or has failed to satisfy all liens against the bidder's property executed by the city. 
 
Sec. 2-277. Emergency purchases.
(a)	A bona fide emergency is a situation that seriously jeopardizes public safety, health or welfare or that otherwise adversely affects the ability of a city department to utilize normal purchasing channels. The department head and the mayor will determine the existence of an emergency situation or condition. Department heads will not use the emergency purchase procedure to abuse or otherwise purposely circumvent the established purchasing procedures. 
(b)	After determination that an emergency situation or condition exists, the department head shall make the purchase and obtain a receipt therefor. No later than the first working day after the purchase is consummated, the department head shall prepare and submit to the finance director a confirmation letter explaining the nature of the emergency. The letter shall be accompanied by the purchase receipt and any related documentation. The finance director shall report the emergency purchase to the mayor and city council no later than the next regularly scheduled council meeting following receipt of the confirmation letter and supporting documentation. 
 
Sec. 2-278. Local vendor preference.
(a)	Because bids awarded to local vendors contribute to the city tax base and promote the local economy, local vendors shall be given preference when bidding against non-local vendors, subject to the following: 
(1)	For purposes of this section, a local vendor is a vendor maintaining a physical presence within the city limits including at a minimum the maintenance of at least one office and continuous employment of at least two persons within the city limits for not less than six months prior to the submission of a bid. 
(2)	For purchases or contracts under $100,000.00, where a local vendor's bid meets all specifications and is within five percent of the lowest responsive and responsible non-local bidder, the city is authorized to negotiate with local vendors to match the lowest bid submitted by a non-local vendor. The lowest bidding local vendor shall be given one business day from the opening of bids to notify the department head or other designated city official that it will match the low bid submitted by the non-local vendor. 
(3)	If the local vendor refuses to match the low bid, then the next lowest local vendor within five percent, if any, shall be given one business day to agree to match the low bid submitted by the non-local vendor, and so on until all local vendors have had an opportunity to match the low bid. 
(b)	To be eligible for consideration under this section, bids submitted by local vendors must meet all other terms and conditions of the bid and must be otherwise qualified to be awarded city contracts. The exercise of local vendor preference shall not be at the sacrifice of the quality of the purchased product or service. 
(c)	Local vendor preference shall not apply to road construction or public works projects otherwise governed by state law or to the purchase of goods or services for which preference is prohibited by state law. 
(d)	The local vendor preference shall be stated in written solicitations for bids unless the preference is not applicable pursuant to this section. 
 
Secs. 2-279—2-304. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 5. AD VALOREM TAXES
 
Sec. 2-305. Tax rate as prescribed; levy.
The annual ad valorem tax rate upon all real and personal property within the city shall be set and levied annually by the city. Failure to set the rate in any year shall result in the imposition of the rate last set by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2011; Code 1985, § 11-50; Ord. of 10-6-1980)
 
Sec. 2-306. Assessment rate.
All property subject to the ad valorem tax shall be assessed at 40 percent of its full fair market value as established by the county for county ad valorem tax purposes. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2012; Code 1985, § 11-51)
 
Sec. 2-307. Tax appeals.
Any taxpayer may appeal from an ad valorem tax assessment as is provided in the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2014; Code 1985, § 11-52)
 
Sec. 2-308. Tax due and payable.
Ad valorem tax bills, as adjusted to conform to the tax digest of the county, shall be payable on or before December 31 or in the event of adjustment by the state revenue commissioner, within such reasonable time thereafter as may be determined by the city after receipt from the county of the adjustment information. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2015; Code 1985, § 11-53)
 
Sec. 2-309. Delinquent taxes.
All taxes due to the city when delinquent shall be collected by every means allowed by general state law. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2001; Code 1985, § 11-54)
 
Sec. 2-310. Interest on tax executions.
All tax executions shall earn the maximum rate of interest allowed by general state law. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2002; Code 1985, § 11-55)
 
Sec. 2-311. Issuance of executions and fi. fas.
The tax collector for the city shall issue all executions and fi. fas. for delinquent taxes as soon as the last day for the payment thereof has arrived over his signature alone. The executions shall be directed to all and singular sheriffs and constables of the state. The executions shall be signed by the tax collector under the seal of the city; such signatures may be manual or facsimile signatures. The signature of the mayor or any other person, other than the tax collector, shall not be required for the same to be validly issued. 
(Code 1985, § 11-56; Ord. of 8-3-1987)
 
Secs. 2-312—2-340. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE VII. ADMINISTRATIVE CODE ENFORCEMENT
 
Sec. 2-341. Code enforcement division authority.
The personnel of the code enforcement division of the community affairs department shall enforce the city's zoning, sign, and other regulations and standards as directed and approved by the city council, in the manner provided in this article. 
 
Sec. 2-342. Inspection authority, limitations and procedure.
Subject to constitutional limitations, code enforcement division personnel may enter or inspect any building, land, structure or premises in the city for the purpose of inspection of the building, structure, land, premises and all utility connections associated therewith for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the provisions of all state laws and city codes and ordinances; provided, however, that: 
(1)	Efforts shall be made to conduct inspections during normal business hours, if practicable, or unless, in the discretion of the code enforcement officer, an emergency is deemed to exist; 
(2)	All code enforcement division personnel shall present themselves, if necessary, to gain entrance or access to the property, at the front door or entrance in order to identify themselves prior to accessing the premises. The code enforcement division personnel shall present official identification upon reasonable request. If code enforcement division personnel are unable to identify themselves prior to accessing the premises, they shall leave notification to the property owner after completing the inspection. 
(Ord. No. 09-2017-01, § 2-31, 9-18-2017)
 
Sec. 2-343. Notice of violation.
Upon ascertaining, being advised by another individual, or believing that a violation of any code or ordinance exists, code enforcement division personnel shall cause a written notice to be directed to the owner of the property or such other appropriate representative unless, in the opinion of the code enforcement officer an emergency is deemed to exist. The notice shall, at a minimum, contain the following information: 
(1)	The owner or controller of the property; 
(2)	As best it can be ascertained or verified, the location of the property on which the violation exists, including the address, district, land lot and parcel identification; 
(3)	The nature of the violation and penalties, if applicable; 
(4)	A provision for rectifying the violation without further proceedings; 
(5)	A time frame for bringing the property into compliance and completion of the tasks required in order to rectify the violation without further proceedings; 
(6)	A date, or mechanism for determining a date, for a follow-up inspection in order to determine if the violation has been remedied and the property brought into compliance, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 09-2017-01, § 2-31, 9-18-2017)
 
Sec. 2-344. Follow up inspections.
(a)	Consistent with the provisions set forth in the notice regarding further inspection of the premises, the code enforcement division shall cause a follow-up inspection of the property to be performed. 
(b)	If the violation has been remedied, the property in question shall nonetheless be subject to additional follow-up inspections to ensure continued compliance. If, during any additional inspection, it is discovered that compliance has lapsed and substantially the same violations are once again in existence, the code enforcement division shall issue a citation to the owner of the property or the responsible party or refer the matter to the city attorney's office pursuant to section 2-345. 
(Ord. No. 09-2017-01, § 2-31, 9-18-2017)
 
Sec. 2-345. Failure to correct noncompliance upon notice; issuance of citations.
If, at the time of the follow-up inspection, the violation has not been remedied, the code enforcement division shall issue a citation to the owner of the property or the responsible party or refer the matter to the city attorney's office for handling in accordance with the provisions for enforcement under the applicable code section or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 09-2017-01, § 2-31, 9-18-2017)
 
Sec. 2-346. Emergency action when imminent harm or peril is likely.
(a)	If the code enforcement officer believes that an emergency is deemed to exist such that imminent harm or peril to life or property is likely to occur, or the code enforcement officer is otherwise authorized or directed by this Code to take immediate action to remedy, or attempt to remedy, a violation, the code enforcement officer shall be authorized to take all reasonable and necessary steps to remedy, or attempt to remedy, the violation in order to protect or avoid any imminent harm or peril to life or property without prior notice to the property owner or responsible party. 
(b)	The code enforcement officer shall thereafter make all reasonable efforts to contact the owner of the property or responsible person to inform them of the violations and action taken. Additionally, the code enforcement officer shall issue a citation to the owner of the property or the responsible party or refer the matter to the city attorney's office pursuant to section 2-345. 
(Ord. No. 09-2017-01, § 2-31, 9-18-2017)
 
Sec. 2-347. When notice is not required.
In any matter where a court order was previously rendered regarding a similar violation for the same property, the code enforcement officer shall immediately issue a citation without the necessity of following the notice provisions of this article. A prior notice for a similar violation on the same property shall be effective against the owner of the property or responsible person for substantially the same violation any time after the issuance of the notice. 
(Ord. No. 09-2017-01, § 2-31, 9-18-2017)
 
Chapter 4 ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 4-1. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, and in addition to the definitions provided in section 1-2, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administrator means the officer or employee designated to administer the provisions of this chapter. 
Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. 
Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage, wine or fortified wine. 
Business area means any street length between intersections where 50 percent or more is in use for business purposes and the area is properly zoned in accordance with the city zoning ordinances. 
Church means any permanent building, together with the tract of land upon which it is located, where persons regularly assemble for religious worship, but shall not include any other church-owned land or property not regularly used as an assembly area for religious worship services. 
College means only state, county, city, church or other college that teaches the subjects commonly taught in the common colleges of this state and shall not include a private college where only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects are taught. 
Distance means the measurement in horizontal lineal feet from the front door of the proposed licensee's premises in a straight line which describes the shortest distance to the nearest church, school ground or college campus. 
Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than 24 percent alcohol by volume, including, but not limited to, all fortified wines. 
Family means and includes any person related to the holder of such license within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity computed according to the civil law. 
Fortified wines means any alcoholic beverage containing more than 24 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term "fortified wines" includes, but is not limited to, brandy. 
Interest in license exists if the person involved is the outright owner of the license, a co-owner of the license, a partner in a partnership which owns all or any part of a license, a stockholder in any corporation organized for pecuniary gain which owns all or any part of a license, an owner, lessor, sublessor or stockholder in any corporation organized for pecuniary gain owning or leasing any real estate which is occupied by a liquor establishment or shares in any of the income or corpus of any trust fund or estate having any interest in a liquor establishment. Provided, however, that a stockholder shall not be deemed to have an interest in a liquor establishment where such stockholder owns any stock in a motel or hotel having 50 or more rooms with a liquor establishment located on the premises of such motel or hotel and owned by such motel or hotel. Notwithstanding any of the other provisions of this section, no one person shall have more than one interest in any one license in the city. 
License means the authorization by the governing authority of the city to engage in the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
Licensee means a person holding any class of license issued under the terms of this chapter. 
Lounge means a separate room connected with a part of and adjacent to a restaurant, as defined herein, with all booths, stools and tables being unobstructed and open to view. All lounges shall be air conditioned and have a seating capacity of at least 75 except as provided in section 4-125. 
Malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops, or any other similar product, or any combination of such products in water, containing nor more than 14 percent alcohol by volume and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer, and strong beer. The term "malt beverage" does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. 
Manufacturer means any maker, producer, or bottler of an alcoholic beverage. The term "manufacturer" also means: 
(1)	In the case of distilled spirits, any person engaged in distilling, rectifying, or blending any distilled spirits; provided, however, that a vintner that blends wine with distilled spirits to produce a fortified wine shall not be considered a manufacturer of distilled spirits. 
(2)	In the case of malt beverages, any brewer. 
(3)	In the case of wine, any vintner. 
Package means a bottle, can, keg, barrel, or other original consumer container. 
Premises means the definite closed or partitioned establishment, whether room, shop or building wherein alcoholic beverages are sold or consumed. 
Private club means a corporation organized and existing under the laws of the state, having at least 100 members regularly paying monthly, quarterly, semi-annual or annual dues, organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofit activities; except as otherwise defined in section 4-125. 
Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served and where meals are actually and regularly served, such place being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment, air conditioned, having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests; except as otherwise defined in section 4-125. At least one meal per day shall be served at least six days a week, with the exception of holidays, vacations and periods of redecorating. 
Retail means retail sales packaged to go and not for consumption on the premises. 
School means only those state, county, city, church or other schools that teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools of this state and shall include the adjacent open land used for school purposes but this shall not include any portion of a private school where only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects are taught. 
Stockholders means and includes the direct, indirect, beneficial and absolute owners of the stock in a corporation and the beneficiaries and trustees of any voting trust for stock. When any stockholder is required to meet any criteria, if the ownership or voting control is so divided, or by any other means avoids or circumvents any requirements of this chapter, the failure of any holder of any such interest or right to meet such criteria shall cause a failure of that entire stockholder share to meet such criteria. 
Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 24 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term "wine" includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, combinations of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines, and like products. The term "wine" does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-2001, 7-2006(e); Code 1985, § 3-1; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 7-13-1981; Ord. of 9-12-1994, § 1; Ord. of 3-4-1996, §§ I—III)
 
Secs. 4-2—4-20. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. LICENSES AND PERMITS
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 4-21. License required; scope of article.
(a)	No malt beverage, wine, distilled spirits or any other alcoholic beverage shall be stored, delivered, sold or manufactured in the city except under a license issued pursuant to this article and then only for the specific beverage and manner of sale provided in the license. 
(b)	The requirements of this article shall be in addition to any other requirements for business licenses under this Code, and, if other provisions of this Code conflict with this article, then this article shall control. 
(c)	Licenses which may be issued under this article include: 
(1)	Manufacturing: 
a.	Malt beverages; 
b.	Wine; 
c.	Distilled spirits; 
(2)	Wholesale: 
a.	Malt beverages; 
b.	Wine; 
c.	Distilled spirits; 
(3)	Packaged retail: 
a.	Malt beverages; 
b.	Wine; 
c.	Distilled spirits; 
(4)	Consumption on the premises: 
a.	Malt beverages; 
b.	Wine; 
c.	Distilled spirits; or 
(5)	Combinations: 
a.	Any combination of subsection (c)(3)a, b and c of this section; 
b.	Any combination of subsection (c)(4)a, b and c of this section; 
c.	The combinations of subsections (c)(4)a and (c)(3)a of this section; subsections (c)(4)b and (c)(3)b of this section; subsections (c)(4)a, and b and (c)(3)a, and b of this section; subsections (c)(4)a, b, and c and (c)(3)a, and b of this section; subsections (c)(4)a, and c and (c)(3)a of this section; and subsections (c)(4)b, and c and (c)(3)b of this section. 
(6)	Cabaret, in addition to subsection (c)(4) or (c)(5) of this section. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2002; Code 1985, § 3-20; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Sec. 4-22. Applications for new license.
(a)	All applications for new licenses under this article shall be accompanied by a payment in cash or by certified check for all the minimum fees and business taxes provided for in this Code for the classification into which the applicant falls. 
(b)	The city application shall be a photostatic or other copy of all the appropriate state applications and forms along with a city supplemental application form provided by the city along with the following: 
(1)	A legal description of the property upon which the premises are located; 
(2)	A current photograph of the applicant; 
(3)	Fingerprints of the applicant to be taken by the police department. 
(c)	The application shall also contain a form of oath providing that the information disclosed in the application is true and correct, and providing further that the applicant will abide by, observe and conduct such business according to the rules and regulations prescribed by the city, the acts of the general assembly and the rules and regulations of the state department of revenue in respect thereto. The oath shall be taken by the applicant and the agent in charge of the establishment if different from or additional to the applicant, and the oath shall be taken by the true owners. 
(d)	Any false statement or material misrepresentation or omission in any application hereunder shall be grounds for the revocation of any license granted hereunder. 
(e)	All applications for new licenses shall include a plat of survey from a registered surveyor showing a scale drawing of the location of the proposed premises and the distance to the property line of the nearest church or school ground or that the distance is more than the limits set forth in section 4-34(a). 
(Code 1976, § 7-2003(a)—(f); Code 1985, § 3-21; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 9-12-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 4-23. False statements in applications.
(a)	Any person who acquires a license or a renewal of the same in violation of this article by any misrepresentation or fraudulent statement shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(b)	Any untrue or misleading information contained in, or material omission left out of, an original, renewal, or transfer application for a license shall be cause for the denial thereof and, if any license has been granted under these circumstances, shall be cause for revocation. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-2003(g), (h), 7-2010; Code 1985, § 3-22; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-24. Preliminary approval required; payment of debts; notice of reasons for denial; data; processing time.
(a)	The community affairs department shall cause an inquiry to be made into the city tax records to determine if the applicant or other parties with interest in the application has any outstanding taxes or special assessments that are delinquent against such persons' property or any other monies owing to the city. No license shall be issued or renewed until such debts are paid in full. 
(b)	All applications shall be approved or disapproved by the city as a condition to action thereon and issuance of a license by the community affairs department. In the event that the police department determines that the application is not in order, in view of the requirements of federal or state law or this Code and any police department investigation, the community affairs department shall then notify the applicant of the reasons for not issuing the license to the applicant. 
(c)	All applicants shall furnish all reasonable data, information and records requested of them by the community affairs department or police department and failure to furnish such data, information, contracts, documents, financial statements and other records within 30 days of the request shall automatically serve to dismiss the application. 
(d)	The police department may require in addition to the licensee, fingerprinting and background investigation of any person interested in the application, including any person with a financial interest, such as stockholders, partners or employees, and any spouse, brother, sister, child or parent of any person with a financial interest. Should the applicant fail to produce such persons within 30 days of the request, the application may be denied by the police department. 
(e)	Applicants by filing an application agree to produce for oral interrogation any persons requested by the police department and considered as being important in the ascertainment of the facts relative to such license. The failure to produce those persons within 30 days after being requested to do so may result in a denial of the application by the police department. 
(f)	The city may require 45 days for processing any application for a license required under this article. For investigative purposes, the police chief may extend the 45 day processing period according to the licensee's compliance should the chief deem it necessary. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2004; Code 1985, § 3-23; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 1-6-1997, § XII)
 
Sec. 4-25. Issuance of license.
All licenses must be obtained and business taxes and fees paid not later than two weeks from the date of the approval of the application by the city and, if not so obtained, the license granted by the city shall be void. When a license has been approved and the applicant has deposited with the community affairs department the required taxes and fee, the license shall be issued. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2011; Code 1985, § 3-24; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-26. Managers; work permits for managers, employees, and license holders.
(a)	Every person licensed under this article for package sales of distilled spirits and for all consumption on the premises sales shall employ a person as manager, or a like position, for the licensed establishment and the manager shall obtain a manager's permit as provided in this section. This permit shall be valid for a period of 12 months from the date of issuance. 
(b)	Prior to employment as manager or employee, or prior to obtaining an interest in a license, each person becoming so employed or acquiring such interest shall obtain an employee's or manager's work permit, as the case may be, from the city police department by making application therefor on a form provided by the department. The city police department shall have a complete and exhaustive search made relative to any police record of the person fingerprinted. 
(c)	Licensees and managers under this section shall keep a copy of the permit on file at all times in the establishment and shall make these permits available for inspection during operating hours. 
(d)	No person shall be eligible to receive a permit if such person shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendere within ten years immediately prior to the filing of the application for any felony or misdemeanor of any state or of the United States or any municipal ordinance except traffic violations; the term "conviction" includes an adjudication of guilty of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime; where the violation is for a misdemeanor, or where there is a forfeiture of bond, or a violation of municipal ordinance, or where there is a plea of nolo contendere, the city may, after investigation, waive the same as a disqualification. 
(e)	The managers of the licensee shall post their work permit next to the license. The city police shall keep a list of all such managers and check such posted managers' work permits against such list at any time. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2034; Code 1985, § 3-25; Ord. of 1-11-1980; Ord. of 2-1-1982; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Sec. 4-27. Licensee and manager disqualification for prior convictions.
No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages, nor any manager's permit or work permit shall be issued to any person where any individual having an interest either as owner, partner, stockholder, directly or indirectly, beneficial or absolute, or such person's spouse, shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendere within ten years immediately prior to the filing of the application for any felony or misdemeanor of any state or of the United States or any local governmental ordinance except traffic violations; the term "conviction" includes an adjudication of guilty or a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime; where the violation is for a misdemeanor, or there is a forfeiture of bond, or violation of a municipal ordinance, or where there is a plea of nolo contendere, the city may, after investigation, waive the same as a disqualification. The term "traffic violation" herein shall not include driving under the influence. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2005; Code 1985, § 3-26; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-28. Prohibited interests.
(a)	No person who has any direct financial interest in a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at wholesale shall hold any other license or an interest in any other license under the terms of this article. 
(b)	No person, related within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity under the civil law to any wholesale licensee or employee thereof or any person with any interest therein, shall hold any other license or an interest in any other license issued under this article. 
(c)	No person or member of such person's family shall own, hold or control any interest whatsoever in more than one license to engage in the business of selling packaged distilled spirits at retail in the city. 
(d)	No more than one license to engage in the sale of packaged distilled spirits at retail in the city shall be issued to any person which shall include all members of such person's family. 
(e)	A licensee may take in partners or additional stockholders where it is determined that the additional capital furnished is to be used exclusively for additional inventory or expanding the facilities of the business or for building new facilities and where it appears that the licensee personally received directly none of the additional capital invested. Under this section an additional partner or stockholder must be approved by the city and, if approved, the business must obtain a new license. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2006; Code 1985, § 3-27; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Sec. 4-29. Residence requirements, agents.
(a)	All applicants must be owners of the business and shall have resided continuously within the state for 12 months prior to the date the application is made unless the applicant designates a local agent who meets such residency requirement. When the applicant is a corporation whose primary business is one licensed hereunder, the majority stockholders must meet the within requirements and the license shall be issued to the corporation and the majority stockholders. Where the applicant is a corporation whose primary business is other than the operation of an establishment requiring licensing hereunder, the license shall be issued to the corporation and an officer or agent of such corporation who meets the above requirements. If the applicant is a partnership, the same requirements pertaining to corporations shall apply to the partnership. 
(b)	All applications for licenses under this article by a corporation shall name in the application one or more residents in the state as the agent and representative of the corporation to receive all communications, notices, service of process or other papers or documents, on behalf of the corporation in connection with any matter arising out of or connected with the issuance, holding, suspension, revocation or other action with respect to any city license. The application shall give the mailing addresses of the persons, and the mailing to any person at that address of any notice required to be given under this article or any other law shall be sufficient notice to the corporation. If any person shall cease to be a resident of the state, another person shall immediately be appointed in writing in such person's place, and written notice shall be given to the administrator stating the name and address of the new agent. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2007; Code 1985, § 3-28; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 8-3-1987)
 
Sec. 4-30. Denial of license application; granting; appeal.
(a)	The community affairs department shall deny a city license under this article on any of the following grounds: 
(1)	Failure to meet state requirements for state license; 
(2)	Failure to pay required fees and taxes; 
(3)	Failure to provide valid information, documents and the like required by this article; 
(4)	False information in the application or attached documents; 
(5)	Improper residency of applicant, owner, or registered agents; 
(6)	Failure to meet distance or location requirements; 
(7)	Prior convictions as herein provided; or 
(8)	Failure to meet any other requirements in this article for a license of the class applied for. 
(b)	An application which has been denied shall not be resubmitted for 12 months after the denial unless there is a substantial change therein which would affect the reason for denial originally. 
(c)	An application for a location which has been cited for a violation of this Code or state law, with regard to alcohol sales in the previous 12 months, shall come before the city council for review. In such instance the council may, after conducting a hearing with notice to the application, continue the effect and duration of any suspension or probation. 
(d)	Otherwise, the community affairs department may issue any city license provided for in this article after approval of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2009; Code 1985, § 3-29; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 1-6-1997, § XII; Ord. of 7-10-2000, § 2)
 
Sec. 4-31. License constitutes grant of privilege.
(a)	All licenses herein shall be a mere grant of privilege to carry on such business during the term of the license subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this Code relating to such businesses. 
(b)	All licenses hereunder shall have printed on the front these words: "This license is a mere privilege subject to be revoked and annulled by the city council of the city and is subject to any future ordinances." 
(Code 1976, § 7-2012; Code 1985, § 3-30; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-32. Annual renewal.
All licensees hereunder shall be required to renew their licenses annually on forms prescribed by the community affairs department. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2013; Code 1985, § 3-31; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 1-6-1997, § XII)
 
Sec. 4-33. Duration and renewal of license.
Duration and renewal of licenses under this article shall be as for business licenses generally; and no licensee shall have any vested right to the renewal of any city license. No licenses under this article may be renewed if the licensee could be denied a new license under this article. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2014; Code 1985, § 3-32; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-34. Distance, area zoning and parking requirements.
(a)	No license shall be issued under this article where the place of business of the licensee is located a distance of less than 100 yards of any church, or 200 yards of any school building, educational building, school grounds or college campus; unless such place of business is a retail establishment for consumption on premises; in which case the distance requirement may be waived by the community affairs department if the establishment is located within the city's central business district. The mayor and council may waive at a public hearing the distance requirement for such businesses located in other commercially zoned areas at their discretion if the issuance of such license will not be deemed detrimental to property values or the general health and welfare of the general public. 
(b)	No license to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be issued within the lawful areas described in this article unless the location is zoned commercial or industrial under the zoning laws of the city. 
(c)	Where a retail liquor store exists in an area outside of the city limits, upon annexation of such area the same may be continued and shall be subject to all the provisions of this Code. 
(d)	Locations which will retail alcoholic beverages in package only shall provide one off-street parking space for each 200 square feet of floor space in the building used for that purpose. 
(Code 1976, §§ 2-2003(i), 7-2008; Code 1985, § 3-33; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 9-12-1994, § 1; Ord. No. 11-2010-01, 11-1-2010)
 
Sec. 4-35. Completion of premises proposed to be licensed.
Where a building in which any person intends to operate under the provisions of this article is, at the time of the application for the license, not in existence or not yet completed, a license may be issued for the location provided the plans for the proposed building show clearly a compliance with the other provisions of this article. No sales or consumption shall be allowed in the establishment until it has been completed in accordance with the plans and is in conformity with all of the other provisions of this article and the city codes. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2016; Code 1985, § 3-34; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-36. Alteration of premises.
Where a building in which any person is licensed or intends to operate under the provisions of this article is to be altered, modified, or renovated, any such interior or exterior work shall be subject to the prior approval of the city and shall meet all applicable codes. If approval is not obtained, the license application or the next subsequent renewal license may be denied. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2015; Code 1985, § 3-35; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-37. Time limits on opening and continuing business.
(a)	All licenses issued under this article must, within 90 days after the issuance of a city license, open for business. Failure to open for business shall constitute a forfeiture and cancellation of the issued licenses and no refund of license fees or business taxes shall be made. Any applicant unable to comply with the time limit of this section may make written request to the administrator for an extension of time not to exceed 90 days; and the city at its discretion may grant or deny the request. 
(b)	Any license issued under this article shall automatically be null and void where the licensed business has not operated or been open to the public for 30 days. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2017; Code 1985, § 3-36; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-38. Restrictions upon transfers.
(a)	Licenses hereunder shall not be transferable, except as otherwise provided herein. 
(b)	In the case of the death of any person holding such a license, or any interest therein, the same may, at the discretion of the city, be transferred to the administrator, executor or the lawful heirs of the deceased person. 
(c)	Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more of the partners in a partnership holding a license to withdraw from the partnership in favor of one or more of the partners, who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. Such a withdrawal shall not, however, serve to bring any new ownership into the partnership. 
(d)	Should a transfer of a location be approved, there shall be no pro rata return of any fee or business tax and the new location shall meet the requirements of a new license hereunder. 
(e)	However, a licensee may take in partners or additional stockholders where it is determined that the additional capital furnished is to be used exclusively for additional inventory or expanding the facilities of the business or for building new facilities and where it appears that the licensee personally received directly not any of the additional capital invested. Under this section, an additional partner or new principal stockholder must be approved by the city. 
(f)	All applications for transfer of locations shall comply with the provisions herein set forth governing new licenses. 
(g)	No transfer shall be permitted when the license is subject to revocation, suspension or the licensee is on probation for violation of this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2018; Code 1985, § 3-37; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 7-10-2000, § 1)
 
Sec. 4-39. Grounds for suspension or revocation; notice; hearing; refund.
(a)	No license which has been issued or which may hereafter be issued by the city to any licensee hereunder shall be suspended or revoked, except for due cause as hereinafter defined, and after a hearing and upon a prior five day written notice to the holder of such license of the time, place and purpose of such hearing and statement of the charge upon which such hearing shall be held. 
(b)	Due cause for the suspension or revocation of such license shall consist of the violation of any laws or ordinances regulating such businesses, or violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating such businesses, or for the violation of any state or federal law, or for the violation of this Code other than traffic ordinances. 
(c)	The mayor is delegated the authority to suspend any license hereunder for due cause in any emergency situation, and the suspension may be made effective immediately and remain in force until the next regular or called meeting of the city. 
(d)	When a license is so revoked, the city shall not be required to refund any portion of the business license fees. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2019; Code 1985, § 3-38; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-40. Acceptance and consideration of application after rejection or revocation.
When an application for a license to sell alcoholic beverages is denied or revoked for cause by the city, it is unlawful for the administrator to accept or consider an application from the same applicant for such license to operate the same type of business within 12 months from the time of the rejection by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2020; Code 1985, § 3-39; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-41. Removal of signs after revocation.
When any license for selling alcoholic beverages is revoked, all signs indicating that such beverages may be sold or purchased shall be removed from the place of business, both outside and inside. Upon receipt by the police department of notices of such revocation, the police department shall take the necessary steps to see that this section is enforced. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2021; Code 1985, § 3-40; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-42. Outstanding licenses, compliance.
(a)	So as to prevent an unconstitutional taking of property, all licensees for alcoholic beverages within the city in compliance with city ordinance requirements involving residency, distance, location, parking and type of building structure in effect at the time of first receiving the licenses and continuing to be in compliance therewith shall be exempt from the requirements of this article involving residency, distance, location, parking and type of building structure. 
(b)	Renewals and transfers of business ownership at the same location shall also be deemed in compliance hereunder to the extent provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)	Business transfers to new locations and new licenses must comply with all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2022; Code 1985, § 3-41; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-43. Licenses subject to state regulations.
All licenses issued under this article shall be subject to the rules and regulations authorized by state law and those prescribed by the state department of revenue and violation of these statutes and regulations shall be violations of this Code. In addition, all businesses, the applicant for the license, the agent in charge of the business and the owners thereof shall observe and obey the regulations provided in this article and any other applicable provisions of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2023; Code 1985, § 3-42; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-44. Open to inspection.
Any establishment holding a license issued under this article shall at all times, during the period allowable by law for operation of the business, be open to inspection by any officer of the police department or any license inspector of the city or to any person designated by the police chief. In addition, if the premises are being used after hours by employees or the owners or their agents, the premises may be inspected at this time by the designated persons in this section. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2032; Code 1985, § 3-14; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-45. Penalties; license revocation.
(a)	Upon conviction in the municipal court of any violation of any penal provision of this article, unless otherwise provided, the punishment shall be as follows: 
(1)	First offense: Minimum fine of $150.00; 
(2)	Second and subsequent offenses, if within 12 months of the first: Minimum fine of $200.00. 
(b)	Any license under this article may be revoked or suspended by the city for any conviction of the licensee or any agent, officer or employee thereof for violation of any portion of this article. 
(c)	Any license issued under this article may be suspended by the mayor until the next session of the city for reason of any disturbance, acts of disorderly conduct, violence, gambling or by reason of any conviction for violation in subsection (a)(2) of this section having occurred in the establishment or on the premises thereof. 
(d)	When the license of any establishment has been revoked, no further license shall be issued under this article to the same person at that location for a period of 12 months from the date of revocation. 
(e)	Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license to manufacture or sell at wholesale or retail any alcoholic beverages, the city license to manufacture or deal in those products shall thereupon be automatically revoked without any action by the city or any municipal officer. 
(f)	All owners or officers of establishments licensed under this article may be held responsible for any violation of this article by an employee thereof. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2033; Code 1985, § 3-15; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 7-10-2000, § 3)
 
Secs. 4-46—4-63. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. PACKAGED BEER AND WINE
 
Sec. 4-64. Scope of division.
In addition to the general business license requirements of this Code and the other articles of this chapter, the following sections shall apply to the licensing and operation of retail malt beverage or wine establishments in the city and should any section of this division conflict with other provisions in this chapter or the general business license requirement of this Code, then this division shall control. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2061; Code 1985, § 3-60; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-65. Retailers—Delivery.
Retail dealers in malt beverages licensed under the applicable licensing provisions of the city shall not buy or accept deliveries of malt beverages from wholesalers or other persons offering for sale except from wholesalers duly licensed under this Code. Retail dealers shall not accept deliveries except directly to the premises for which their license and permit were issued, and by no means other than a conveyance owned and operated by a wholesaler licensed as required under this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2063; Code 1985, § 3-62; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-66. Retailers—Storage.
All licensed retailers shall store all malt beverages in their possession on the premises for which the license was issued. All malt beverage stocks shall be available at all times for inspection by authorized city officials. Any brand or type of malt beverages found in any retailer's stock that is handled by a wholesaler who is not licensed to make sales and deliveries in the city shall be subject to immediate confiscation.
