(Code 1976, § 7-2064; Code 1985, § 3-63; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-67. Time of sale of wine only.
Wine in package or for consumption on premises may be sold at any time not prohibited by the state, except between 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. daily, and may be sold on any day. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2065; Code 1985, § 3-64; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Secs. 4-68—4-92. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. PACKAGED DISTILLED SPIRITS
 
Sec. 4-93. Scope of division.
In addition to the general business license requirements of this Code and other articles of this chapter, the following sections shall apply to the licensing and operation of retail distilled spirits establishments in the city and should any section of this division conflict with other provisions in this chapter or the general business license requirements of this Code, then this division shall control. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2041; Code 1985, § 3-50; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Sec. 4-94. Applications; contents.
(a)	All applications for license, both original and renewal, must be accompanied by a full and complete statement under oath of information relative to any and all interest in retail packaged distilled spirits stores. This shall include the names and addresses of all persons interested in the ownership of the business of selling at retail packaged distilled spirits, together with any interest each person or any member of his immediate family has in any other retail packaged distilled spirits store; the ownership of the land and building where such retail business is operated; the amount of rental paid for such land and building and the manner in which the same is determined and to whom and at what intervals it is paid; the names and addresses (by affidavit from the owner, lessor or sublessor of such land and building) of all persons having any whole, partial, beneficial or other interest in and to the land and building on and in which the retail packaged distilled spirits store is located; and any other information called for by the mayor and council. 
(b)	Any change in any relationship herein declared must be filed with the community affairs department when such change is made, and failure to so file within a period of 30 days after such change is made shall be grounds for revocation by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2042; Code 1985, § 3-51; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Sec. 4-95. Restrictions on other merchandise.
A licensee of a retail establishment under this division shall not operate the business in connection with any other mercantile establishment; provided, this shall not prohibit a licensee from operating in the same building complex with other businesses. No retailer hereunder shall sell, offer for sale, display or keep in stock at his place of business where packaged distilled spirits are offered for sale any other commodity except the following, all of which may be sold by the retailer at his option: 
(1)	Beverages containing no alcohol and commonly used to dilute distilled spirits; 
(2)	Wines and malt beverages, when property licensed; 
(3)	Glasses, stirring sticks and similar paraphernalia commonly used in the consumption of alcoholic beverages; 
(4)	Tobacco products; 
(5)	Packaged ice; and 
(6)	Snack food items. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2043; Code 1985, § 3-52; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Sec. 4-96. Front window display.
If a licensee so desires he may have his name displayed on the inside of the window in neon or other electric lights. Such sign shall be parallel with the window and so constructed as not to extend more than six inches from the window. A neon sign may also be constructed along the border line or edge of the front window inside the glass. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2044; Code 1985, § 3-53; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Sec. 4-97. Display of license.
No retail package distilled spirits license shall be allowed in, or in connection with, any restaurant, cafe or eating place, or in the same room where a bar or soda fountain is maintained for the dispensing and sale of soft drinks or other beverages. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2046; Code 1985, § 3-55; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Sec. 4-98. Price lists or tags.
Each retail licensee shall have conspicuously displayed within the interior of the licensed premises not less than two copies of a printed price list of the distilled spirits offered for sale and one printed copy of the penal sections of this chapter; provided, however, that a licensee, in lieu of having two copies of a printed price list, may have the price placed on the bottles or on the bottom of the shelf where liquors are exhibited for sale. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2047; Code 1985, § 3-56; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Secs. 4-99—4-124. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 4. CONSUMPTION ON THE PREMISES
 
Sec. 4-125. Definitions.
In addition to definitions provided in section 4-1 and other sections of this Code, the following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Lounge means a separate room connected with a part of, and adjacent to a restaurant as defined herein with all booths, stools and tables being unobstructed and open to view. All lounges shall be air conditioned and have a seating capacity of at least 40. 
Private club means a corporation organized and existing under the laws of the state, having at least 100 members regularly paying monthly, quarterly, semi-annual or annual dues, organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation and other nonprofitable purposes, no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of any shareholder or member, and owning, hiring, or leasing a building or space therein for the reasonable use of its members with suitable kitchen, dining room space, and equipment, and maintaining and using a sufficient number of servants and employees for cooking, preparing, and serving meals for its members and guests, provided that no member, officer, agent, or employee of the club is paid, or directly or indirectly receives, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages to the club or its members or guests beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed by its members at any annual meeting or by its governing board out of the general revenue of the club. 
Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served and where meals are actually and regularly served, such place being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment, air conditioned, having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare and serve suitable hot meals for its guests. At least one meal per day shall be served at least six days a week, with the exception of holidays, vacations and periods of redecorating. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2082; Code 1985, § 3-70; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-126. Scope of division.
In addition to the general business license requirements of this Code and the other articles of this chapter, the following sections shall apply to the licensing and operation of all establishments selling alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises and should any section of this division conflict with other provisions in this chapter or the general business license requirements of this Code, then this division shall control. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2081; Code 1985, § 3-71; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-127. Additional application and license requirements.
In addition to the application and license requirements of this chapter, the following shall be required for licenses under this division: 
(1)	No license to engage in the sale of distilled spirits by the drink at retail shall be granted except in the business areas zoned commercial or industrial under the zoning laws of the city. 
(2)	No license under this division shall be issued to any applicant who does not meet the requirements of a restaurant, lounge or private club as defined herein. 
(3)	The dining area or service area of any business licensed hereunder must be a minimum of 1,200 square feet. 
(4)	Licenses shall be granted only to private clubs or restaurants, as defined hereinbefore, or to lounges operated in conjunction with such restaurants with direct access between the lounge and restaurant. 
(5)	At least 50 percent of the business, by volume, shall be from the sale of prepared foods to be consumed on the premises except private clubs. Authorized officials of the city may examine the records of the businesses licensed hereunder at any reasonable time to ascertain that the requirements of this section are met. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2083; Code 1985, § 3-72; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Sec. 4-128. Additional regulations.
(a)	Drinks hereunder shall be served only by employees of the establishment. 
(b)	It is unlawful for any licensee under this article to permit professional belly dancers, strip dancing, exotic dancing, or any exhibitions of any like kind by whatever name called in connection with the operation of a restaurant, lounge or private club, as defined herein. 
(c)	Locations which will retail alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall provide one off-street parking space for each 100 square feet of floor space in the public assembly area in the building, or one off-street parking space for each four seats in the public assembly area in the building, whichever is greater. If the required off-street parking spaces cannot reasonably be provided on the same lot as the building it serves, the board of variance and zoning appeals may permit such space to be provided on other off-street property. Such property shall be within 400 feet of the premises to which it is appurtenant as measured along the nearest pedestrian walkway and will not require pedestrians to cross a state or national highway. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2084; Code 1985, § 3-73; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Secs. 4-129—4-154. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. BUSINESS OPERATION REQUIREMENTS
 
Sec. 4-155. Open containers and consumption restricted.
No bottle, can or other container of any alcoholic beverage shall be opened, consumed or possessed in an open condition by any person in any parking area, street or sidewalk within 300 feet of any place of business licensed under this chapter, whether the container or beverage was obtained at that place of business or elsewhere, nor within the premises of any business licensed for package only sales under this article. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2024; Code 1985, § 3-6; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-156. Hours and days for sale and purchase.
Except as otherwise herein expressly provided, it is unlawful for any licensee under this article or person employed by a licensee to sell, offer for sale, transfer or offer to transfer to others any alcoholic beverage on Christmas Day; or between the hours of 2:00 a.m. on Sunday and 7:00 a.m. on the following Monday and between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on the other days of the week; and it is unlawful for any person to purchase, receive or offer to receive from a licensee or person employed by a licensee any alcoholic beverage between the hours of 2:00 a.m. on Sunday and 7:00 a.m. on the following Monday and between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on the other days of the week. Provided, alcoholic beverages may be purchased and sold for consumption on premises on Sundays from 12:30 p.m. until 12:00 midnight in any licensed establishment which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross food and beverage sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is served, provided the licensee applies for and receives a permit for such sales from the city and pays the separate license fee therefor as established from time to time by the city. Such application for license shall have attached hereto an accounting by dollars and by percentage of total sales annually, revenues derived from the sale of food and alcoholic beverages. Provided further, the sale of alcoholic beverages in the city shall be permitted on any election day, as the same is authorized and defined in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2025; Code 1985, § 3-7; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-7-1983; Ord. of 4-17-1983; Ord. of 6-2-1986; Ord. of 8-11-1986; Mo. of 10-2-1989; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § IV)
State law reference(s)—Sale on Sundays and election days, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. 
 
Sec. 4-157. Prohibited practices; hours and places for drinking.
(a)	It is unlawful for any person owning or operating a place of business licensed under this chapter for consumption on the premises to permit any person to drink any whiskey, wine, beer or other alcoholic beverage upon the business premises between the hours of 2:00 a.m. on Sunday and 7:00 a.m. on the following Monday and between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on the other days of the week. 
(b)	It is unlawful for any person to drink any whiskey, wine, beer, or other alcoholic beverage while upon, or while upon or within any vehicle upon, the streets, sidewalks or parking areas in the city within 300 feet of a licensed premises; or upon, or while upon or within any vehicle upon, the public parks of the city without regard to their distance from a licensed premises. Provided, alcoholic beverages may be purchased and sold for consumption on premises on Sundays from 12:30 p.m. until 12:00 midnight in any licensed establishment which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross food and beverages sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is served, provided the licensee applies for and receives a permit for such sales from the city and pays the separate license fee therefor as established from time to time by the city. Such application for license shall have attached thereto an accounting by dollars and by percentage of total sales annually, revenues derived from the sale of food and alcoholic beverages. 
(c)	This section shall be construed to cover, include and apply to every type of alcoholic beverages licensed to be sold in the city, including beer, wine, malt beverages or distilled spirits. 
(d)	Each licensee shall maintain a daily schedule of the prices to be charged for all alcoholic beverages to be served and consumed on the licensed premises or in any room or part thereof. The licensee shall not vary the prices from hour to hour within a single day. The schedule of prices shall be maintained in a manner so as to be available to the paying public and law enforcement officers or agents of governmental authority. The schedule shall be effective for not less than a 24-hour period beginning at 2:01 a.m. and ending at 2:00 a.m. the following day and shall show thereon the date for which the schedule is effective. 
(e)	No licensee or holder of any license to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises or in any part thereof, or employee or agency of a licensee, shall: 
(1)	Offer or deliver any free alcoholic beverage to any individual or member of the general public, except as hereinafter provided; 
(2)	Deliver more than two alcoholic beverages to one person at one time, except as hereinafter provided; 
(3)	Sell, offer to sell, or deliver to any person or group of persons any alcoholic beverage at a price less than the price regularly charged for such alcoholic beverage during the same 24-hour period for which the price schedule herein required is in effect, except at private functions not open to the public; 
(4)	Sell, offer to sell, or deliver to any person or group of persons two or more or an unlimited number of alcoholic beverages during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at private functions not open to the public; 
(5)	Sell, offer to sell, or deliver alcoholic beverages to any person or group of persons on any one day at prices less than those charged the general public on that day, except at private functions not open to the public; 
(6)	Sell, offer to sell, or deliver alcoholic beverages, by the pitcher or carafe, except to two or more persons at any one time or as hereinafter provided; 
(7)	Increase the volume of alcohol contained in a drink without increasing proportionately the price regularly charged for such alcoholic beverage during the same 24-hour period for which the price schedule herein required is in effect; 
(8)	Encourage or permit on the licensed premises any game or contest which involves the drinking of any alcoholic beverages; or the awarding of alcoholic beverages as a prize, unless such prize be in unopened containers and the containers remain unopened on the premises and licensee assumes the responsibility to see that the containers remain unopened until they are removed from the premises. If the containers are opened on the premises, both the licensee and the customer shall be in violation of this section; 
(9)	Sell two or more alcoholic beverages for a price substantially the same as is charged one such alcoholic beverage; 
(10)	Require or encourage the purchase of a second or subsequent alcoholic beverage at the same time another alcoholic beverage is purchased; 
(11)	Knowingly allow an alcoholic beverage purchased on the premises to be removed from the premises without having been consumed. The term "premises," for the purpose of this subsection, shall be construed to mean the entire area under the supervision, management or control of the licensee, excluding areas for parking of motor vehicles, and, in the case of licensees whose licensed location is located on a portion of the premises of a club, organization, establishment or entity offering outdoor recreation (for instance, golf or tennis) then the term "premises" shall extend to cover all areas operated as a part of the club or entity excluding areas for parking of motor vehicles. 
(f)	No licensee shall advertise or promote in any way, whether within or without the licensed premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsection (e) of this section. 
(g)	No provision of this section shall be construed to prohibit licensees from offering free food or entertainment at any time, or to prohibit licensees from including an alcoholic beverage as a part of a meal, package, or to prohibit the sale or delivery of wine by the bottle or carafe when sold with meals or to more than one person, or to prohibit any hotel or motel from offering room services to registered guests, or to prohibit the sale of more than two drinks at one time which are to be consumed by the purchaser out of doors on the premises of the licensee, as hereinabove described, in connection with the purchaser's participation as a player in the games of golf or tennis; otherwise no food and alcoholic beverage package may be offered by any licensee; provided, however, nothing contained herein shall be construed to allow a licensee to circumvent the intent of this section by offering meals which include an alcoholic beverage as a device or scheme to promote drink sales at a price per beverage less than the daily listed price. 
(h)	Violations of this section shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or imprisonment for 60 days, or both. Violations shall be considered due cause for suspension or revocation of any license. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2026; Code 1985, § 3-8; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 3-7-1983; Ord. of 10-17-1983; Ord. of 2-3-1986; Ord. of 6-2-1986; Ord. of 3-4-1996, § III)
 
Sec. 4-158. Drive-in and curb service.
(a)	Curb service by retail or consumption on the premises licensees under this chapter or delivery of any alcoholic beverages off the licensed premises, other than by wholesalers licensed hereunder or by the state is hereby prohibited. 
(b)	Drive-in service windows at premises licensed under this chapter are hereby prohibited, except as provided in this section. 
(c)	Any business authorized by the state to provide drive-in windows may do so only as follows: 
(1)	The window shall be clear and unobstructed for a minimum of 24 inches wide and 36 inches in height. 
(2)	The location of the window shall be lighted in a manner that will enable the attendant of the window to clearly view the entire interior of any vehicle being served at the window. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2027; Code 1985, § 3-9; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-159. Furnishing alcoholic beverages to minors; prohibited practices.
(a)	It is unlawful for any person, business or any person in charge of, or employed in, any place of business where alcoholic beverages are kept to furnish to a minor, to permit any minor to buy, or to allow to be bought for a minor any alcoholic beverages. A minor shall be defined as anyone under 21 years of age. 
(b)	When any person in charge of, or employed in, any place of business sells any alcoholic beverage to a minor or otherwise violates this division the business shall be subject to the following: 
(1)	On first offense, the alcoholic beverage license will be suspended for a period of 60 days. 
(2)	On second offense, the alcoholic beverage license will be suspended for a period of six months. 
(3)	On third offense, the alcoholic beverage license will be revoked. 
Any licensee who is found to be selling alcoholic beverages to anyone while their license is in suspension shall have their license revoked. Returns of alcoholic beverages to wholesalers shall not be deemed to be sales within the meaning of this section. 
(c)	Any attempt to commit any act made unlawful by this section shall be itself unlawful and subject to punishment in the municipal court. 
(d)	In addition to citations for alcoholic beverage license violations, any person may be issued citations for violation of state law regarding furnishing alcoholic beverages to minors or purchase or possession of alcoholic beverage by minors or any related state offenses. 
(e)	It is unlawful for any person to allow or require a person in such person's employment under 21 years of age to dispense, serve, sell or take orders for any alcoholic beverage; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not prohibit persons under 21 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores or drug stores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold for consumption off the premises. 
(f)	No business or person who holds a license to sell alcoholic beverages shall allow any minors to be in, frequent, or loiter about the premises of the licensee unless such minors are accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. 
(g)	Any action with regard to an alcoholic beverage license shall be heard before the city council. Any ordinance violation not involving alcoholic beverage licensing shall be punishable in the municipal court. 
(Code 1976, §§ 3-1008, 7-2028; Code 1985, § 3-10; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 6-2-1986; Ord. of 10-3-1988; Ord. of 12-2-1996, § 1)
State law reference(s)—Sale to persons noticeably intoxicated, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-22; sale, etc., to minors, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-3-23—3-3-24.2. 
 
Sec. 4-160. Sale or delivery to unlicensed premises.
It is unlawful for any licensee hereunder to make deliveries of any alcoholic beverage beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by the license. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2029; Code 1985, § 3-11; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-161. Misrepresentation of alcoholic beverages.
It is unlawful for licensees hereunder or their agents to add to the contents of a bottle or to refill empty bottles or in any other manner to misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any alcoholic beverage. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2030; Code 1985, § 3-12; Ord. of 4-16-1981)
 
Sec. 4-162. Slot machines and pool tables prohibited on licensed premises.
No licensee under this chapter shall operate as a game room on the licensed premises without a game room license issued pursuant to this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2031; Code 1985, § 3-13; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 4-5-1999, § 4)
 
Chapter 6 ANIMALS 
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 6-1. Bird sanctuary.
The city is hereby declared a bird sanctuary and no person shall intentionally injure or kill any wild bird within the city with the exception of starlings or other nuisance birds. 
(Code 1976, § 11-1009; Code 1985, § 4-1)
 
Sec. 6-2. Animal and fowl enclosures; size, fencing.
No person shall keep or maintain within the city, any poultry, fowl, rabbits, horses, mules, ponies, cows or cattle, unless the same are kept or maintained on property having a total area of not less than 2½ acres bordered on all sides by a fence not less than five feet in height and which fence at any point shall be at least 50 feet distant from any residence of any adjoining property owner. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3015; Code 1985, § 4-2; Ord. of 10-3-1977)
 
Sec. 6-3. Swine and goats; poultry kept for commercial purposes.
No person shall keep or maintain within the city any swine or goats. In addition, no person shall keep or maintain, within the city, any poultry of any kind for commercial purposes. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3014)
 
Secs. 6-4—6-24. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. DOGS
 
Sec. 6-25. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Dog means a canine animal of either sex. 
Dog under control means a dog controlled by a leash, at heel, or beside a competent person and obedient to that person's commands, or within a vehicle being driven or parked on the streets, or within the property limits of the owner of the dog. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3012; Code 1985, § 4-20)
 
Sec. 6-26. State law adopted; enforcement.
The Responsible Dog Ownership Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq., and Cobb County Code, Chapter 10, Animals, are adopted by reference as though fully set forth in this section, and the Cobb County animal control officer is as designated the city animal control officer, authorized to enforce this chapter and city animal regulations generally. 
(Code 1985, § 4-32; Res. of 8-21-1989)
 
Sec. 6-27. Kennel locations restricted.
No person shall keep or maintain, within the corporate limits of the city, any kennel for the boarding, confinement, breeding or keeping of any dogs, except in zones where breeding and boarding kennels are specifically permitted under city zoning regulations. This section shall not prevent a licensed veterinarian from establishing or maintaining a veterinary clinic within the city for the treatment of dogs and other animals if in compliance with city licensing and zoning regulations. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3017; Code 1985, § 4-22)
 
Sec. 6-28. Conditions for keeping dogs in the city.
(a)	No dogs may be kept or maintained within the city, except on terms and conditions and to the extent provided in this article. 
(b)	Each family unit within the city, the same being all the members of a family living in one residential unit, shall be permitted to maintain and keep permanently up to a limit of four dogs. The offspring of such dogs may be kept and maintained for a period of 90 days after their birth and not thereafter in excess of the limit herein provided. 
(c)	When any dogs are confined and kept in a pen or enclosure at any time, it shall be thoroughly cleaned at least once a week and kept free from filth and stench at all times. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3016; Code 1985, § 4-21)
 
Sec. 6-29. Dog control on city property.
(a)	The owners or persons in possession or control of guard dogs, sentry dogs or watch dogs in the city shall immediately clean up any waste, excrement or damage left by or caused by such dog on any city street, sidewalk, parking area, park or other city property. Any dog kept at a place of business is hereby declared to be a sentry dog. 
(b)	Any person violating this section shall be liable for a fine of $50.00 per occurrence. 
(Code 1985, § 15-13; Ord. of 6-15-1984)
 
Sec. 6-30. Tags and collar required; removal.
(a)	It shall be the duty of each dog owner to provide a collar, to which shall be attached an owner identification tag and the vaccination tag, which collar shall be worn by the dog as provided herein, except when such dog is under immediate control of the owner or other person having custody of the dog or when it is participating in a dog show or exhibition. 
(b)	It is unlawful for any person to remove the collar without the permission of the owner or lawful custodian. 
(Code 1976, §§ 9-3005, 9-3009; Code 1985, § 4-23)
State law reference(s)—Removal of collars or identifying items or marks, O.C.G.A. § 16-9-71. 
 
Sec. 6-31. Identification tag required.
Unless exempted herein, every person owning or having custody of a dog shall provide therefor an identification tag showing the name and address of the owner of the dog. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3002; Code 1985, § 4-24)
 
Sec. 6-32. Vaccination; tag.
It is unlawful for any owner or lawful custodian of a dog to fail to have a valid vaccination tag for such dog as required by the laws of the state. In addition, it is unlawful for any person to attach a vaccination tag to any dog for which it was not issued, or to remove a vaccination tag from any dog without the consent of its owner or lawful custodian. No person shall vaccinate a dog against rabies who is not licensed to practice veterinary medicine in the state. 
(Code 1976, §§ 9-3002, 9-3009, 9-3010; Code 1985, § 4-25)
State law reference(s)—Control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 6-33. Vicious dogs.
It is unlawful for any person to cause, permit or be responsible for the presence of any vicious dog on the streets of the city or in any other public place therein, at any time, unless, and in addition to the other requirements of this article, such dog shall be securely muzzled to effectively prevent it from biting any person or other animal. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3006; Code 1985, § 4-27)
 
Sec. 6-34. Dogs at large prohibited; impoundment.
(a)	It is unlawful for the owner or other custodian having a dog in possession and control, to permit such dog to be out of control and unattended off the premises of such owner or other custodian, or upon public property, or upon the property of another person without permission of the owner or person in possession thereof. 
(b)	All dogs found running at large in violation of this article shall be immediately impounded by the county or the city, or their duly authorized agents. In the event any authorized officer or employee or authorized agent sees a dog which is apparently out of control and unattended, such officer or employee or agent may go upon any property to determine if this article has been violated. 
(c)	In the event that the ownership or lawful custodian of a dog is not known, and such dog is upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks, school grounds, public places, or premises of another, any law enforcement officer or agent or employee duly authorized by the county or city shall be authorized to take possession of such dog and impound it in accordance with the rules and regulations provided or adopted in this chapter for the detention, control and disposition of dogs impounded under this article. 
(Code 1976, §§ 9-3001, 9-3003, 9-3004; Code 1985, §§ 4-26, 4-28, 4-30)
 
Sec. 6-35. Dog bite procedure.
(a)	It is unlawful for any person having knowledge that any person has been bitten by a dog to refuse to notify promptly one or more of the officers, employees or agents mentioned in this section. 
(b)	It is unlawful for the owner of the dog to refuse or fail to comply with the written recommendations made by the officer, employee or agent in any particular case involving a biting dog. 
(c)	Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, whenever any authorized public officer or employee or agent shall receive information that any person has been bitten by a dog, such officer, employee or agent shall be required to have the dog confined for a period of ten days or whatever period is required by the adopted county animal regulations. 
(d)	Any dog confined under this section shall be housed at the county dog pound or at a licensed veterinarian if, in the discretion of the pound master, the latter would be necessary to protect the pound staff and other dogs housed at the pound. Any expense incurred in the handling of any dog, under this section, shall be borne by the owner of the dog. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3013; Code 1985, § 4-29; Ord. of 6-1-1987)
 
Sec. 6-36. Disposition of impounded dogs; fees.
(a)	Any dog seized or impounded under any provision of this article shall be detained at the county dog pound. The officers, agents, and employees of the county shall notify the owner of such dog by mail, if known or can be reasonably ascertained, that the dog has been impounded. The owner of any dog impounded may, within ten days after the mailing of the notice, reclaim the dog upon the payment of the fees charged by the county for impounding, boarding, rabies inoculation or tagging, and any other expenses due to the county for the impoundment and boarding of the dog. 
(b)	In the event the dog is not claimed in the time provided herein, the county may offer for the adoption by any person, any dog unredeemed or unclaimed by the owner upon payment of all costs due to the county for impoundment, boarding and other services provided for the dog. 
(c)	If the dog is not claimed by the owner within the time prescribed herein, then the county shall be authorized to dispose of the dog in as humane and painless a manner as possible. 
(d)	All dogs, if not claimed or adopted as provided, may be donated to any public or private institution for disposition. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3007; Code 1985, § 4-31)
 
Chapter 8 BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION 
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 8-1. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Chief appointing authority means the City of Austell, Georgia. 
Board of adjustments and appeals means the city council. 
Building, heating, air conditioning, electrical, swimming pool, and plumbing official, and flood control administrator means those officials appointed by the city council to administer such codes. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1002; Code 1985, § 5-1; Ord. of 6-3-1991; Ord. of 12-18-1991; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 11)
 
Sec. 8-2. Condemnation board.
The city has created a condemnation board consisting of the fire chief or his designee, the building inspector, one councilmember and two citizens the electrical inspector, the plumbing inspector, the mayor and one citizen appointed by the city council for a two-year term beginning on January 1 of odd-numbered years. This board shall act as the building official for the purposes of enforcement of city unsafe building regulations the Unsafe Building Abatement Code. All decisions of the board shall be by majority vote of all its members and its recommendations shall be sent to the city for action. 
(Code 1985, § 5-2; Ord. of 6-5-1989; Ord. of 8-6-1990, § 1; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 12)
 
Sec. 8-3. Construction and maintenance codes adopted.
(a)	The following codes, as set forth in O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-20 and 8-2-21, are adopted by the city as though fully set forth herein, as supplemented and amended by the state department of community affairs, and as may be amended by provisions of this chapter or of this Code, generally, to the extent permitted by state law: 
(1)	International Building Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014, 2015, 2017 and 2018 Georgia amendments. 
(2)	International Residential Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014, 2015 and 2018 Georgia amendments. 
(3)	International Fire Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 Georgia amendment. 
(4)	International Plumbing Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia amendments. 
(5)	International Mechanical Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia amendments. 
(6)	International Fuel Gas Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia amendments. 
(7)	National Electrical Code, 2017 Edition. 
(8)	International Energy Conservation Code, 2009 Edition, with 2011 and 2012 Georgia amendments. 
(9)	International Swimming Pool and Spa Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 Georgia amendment. 
(10)	International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 Edition, with 2015 Georgia amendment. 
(11)	International Existing Building Code, 2012 Edition, with 2015 Georgia amendment. 
(12)	International Wildland-Urban Interface Code, 2012 Edition, including Appendix chapters. 
(b)	Section 5601.1.3 (Fireworks) of the International Fire Code, adopted in subsection (a) of this section, is revised to state that the possession, manufacture, storage, sale, handling and use of fireworks are prohibited, except as follows: 
(1)	The storage and handling of fireworks as allowed in section 5604. 
(2)	The use of fireworks for fireworks displays as allowed in section 5608. 
(3)	The possession, storage, sale, handling and use of these specific types of fireworks: "Wire or wood sparklers of 100 grams or less of mixture per item; other sparkling items which are non-explosive and non aerial and contain 75 grams or less of chemical compound per tube or a total of 200 grams or less for multiple tubes; snake and glow worms; trick noise makers which include paper streamers, party poppers, string poppers, snappers, and drop pops each consisting of 0.25 grains or less of explosive mixture 
(c)	The International Wildland-Urban Interface Code, adopted in subsection (a) of this section, is subject to the following insertions: 
(1)	Section 101.1. Insert: City of Austell. 
(2)	Section 103.1. Insert: Fire department. 
(3)	Section 109.4.7. Insert: Misdemeanor, $1,000.00, 120 days. 
(4)	Section 114.4. Insert: $150.00 and $1,000.00. 
(d)	Subsequent editions or amendments to the adopted publications and state amendments and errata shall become effective 30 days after the city council receives notice that copies of such publications have been obtained, unless the council within such 30-day period disapproves the subsequent edition or amendment. 
(e)	A copy of each adopted code shall be authenticated and recorded by the clerk and kept on file in the community development department available for public inspection. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1001; Code 1985, § 5-3; Ord. of 5-4-1981; Ord. of 8-6-1990; Ord. of 9-7-1990; Ord. of 6-3-1991; Ord. of 12-18-1991; Ord. of 4-6-2015(4), § 1; Ord. of 4-6-2015(5), § 1)
State law reference(s)—Minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26. 
 
Sec. 8-4. Codes remedial in nature.
The construction codes adopted herein are remedial in nature, and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof, which are public safety, health, and general welfare through structural strength, stability, sanitation, adequate light and ventilation, and safety to life and property from fire and other hazards attributed to the built environment including alteration, repair, removal, demolition, use and occupancy of buildings, structures, or premises, and by regulating the installation and maintenance of all electrical, gas, mechanical and plumbing systems. 
 
Sec. 8-5. Requirements not covered by adopted codes.
Any requirements necessary for the strength, stability or proper operation of an existing or proposed building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system, or for the public safety, health and general welfare, not specifically covered by this chapter or the adopted construction codes, shall be determined by the building inspector. 
 
Sec. 8-6. Alternate materials and methods.
The provisions of the construction codes are not intended to prevent the use of any material or method of construction not specifically prescribed by them, provided any such alternate has been reviewed by the building inspector. The building inspector shall approve any such alternate, provided the building inspector finds that the alternate, for the purpose intended, is at least the equivalent of that prescribed in the construction codes, in quality, strength, effectiveness, fire resistance, durability and safety. The building inspector shall require that sufficient evidence or proof be submitted to substantiate any claim made regarding the alternate. 
 
Sec. 8-7. Liability of city.
The inspection or permitting of any building, system or plan, under the requirements of this chapter or the adopted construction codes shall not be construed in any court as a warranty of the physical condition of such building, system or plan or their adequacy. Neither the city nor any employee thereof shall be liable in tort for damages for any defect or hazardous or illegal condition or inadequacy in such building, system or plan, nor for any failure of any component of such, that may occur subsequent to such inspection or permitting. 
 
Sec. 8-8. Property fronting on a state highway; state highway department permit required.
No city building permit shall be issued for property fronting on a state highway unless a valid state highway department permit has been issued so that right-of-way control may be maintained. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1006; Code 1985, § 5-6)
 
Sec. 8-9. Structure moving.
(a)	Public service certificate and license. Only persons having a state public service commission certificate and public service license may move in the city houses or other buildings having a width greater than 12 feet and only in accordance with the restrictions provided in this section. 
(b)	Notice; permit. Any person desiring to move in the city a house or other building of a width greater than 12 feet shall first give 24 hours' notice to the police department and obtain a moving permit therefor from the police chief. 
(c)	Time limited. Houses or other buildings may be moved through the city only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. and only on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. 
(d)	Escort. Any person moving houses or other buildings through the city shall have at least two qualified escorts, one in front and one following the house or other building; city police will be available to act as escorts at such mover's expense, provided the duties of the police are not required elsewhere. The city police department may act as escorts for a fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. If the services of any other city department is required, the department shall be compensated in an amount determined the mayor. 
(e)	Warning lights and signs. The escort preceding the moving structure must have a flashing light and a wide load sign on the front of the vehicle. The escort following must have a flashing light and a wide load sign on the rear of the vehicle. 
(f)	Damages. Any damages caused by the moving of houses or other buildings, including damages to or the moving of traffic signals, wires, signs, and similar devices may be required to be paid by the mover prior to the time the house or other building leaves the city limits. 
(g)	Violations. Violations of this section are punishable as provided in section 1-9, and any house or other building moved in violation of this section shall be immediately moved off the public right-of-way to the nearest space available, at the violator's expense, and held until this section is fully complied with. 
(Code 1976, §§ 8-4001, 8-4007; Code 1985, § 5-8; Ord. of 3-6-1989)
 
Secs. 8-10—8-34. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. BUILDING PERMITS
 
Sec. 8-35. Building permit fees.
Building permit fees shall be as provided in the fee schedule of the issuing department. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1005; Code 1985, § 5-5; Ord. of 3-6-1989; Ord. of 6-5-2000, § 2, exh. A; 7-10-2000)
 
Sec. 8-36. Purpose and intent; building official to enforce; building permits required.
(a)	Purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of this chapter is to: 
(1)	Promote the general health, safety and welfare and to maintain required local uniformity with the administrative and technical requirements of the construction and maintenance codes adopted by the city; 
(2)	Acquire information on the type, size, and location of all buildings and structures constructed, deconstructed, remodeled, removed, or demolished; 
(3)	Exercise jurisdiction over the construction and inspection of new buildings, as well as additions that increase the physical dimensions of dwellings and commercial buildings, alterations to building structure or alterations to a building's heating, ventilating air conditioning, electrical or plumbing system; 
(4)	Provide plan review and on-site inspection performed by persons designated by the building official; and 
(5)	Establish and collect fees to defray the cost thereof. 
(b)	Building official. There is hereby created the position of building official, who shall administer and enforce this chapter. The building official also has the following duties: 
(1)	Issuing of building permits and certificates of occupancy in accordance with all provisions of this article. 
(2)	Making field inspections to determine that the building or structure being constructed, reconstructed or structurally altered or used is being pursued in accordance with the site plan for which a building permit has been issued. 
(3)	Making field inspections to ensure compliance of existing buildings, uses, and structures to provisions of this article. 
(4)	Ensuring that all construction has been completed in accordance with all applicable Code requirements prior to allowing occupancy. 
(5)	Enforcing provisions of this article through legal or other appropriate means to ensure compliance. 
(6)	Administering consent variances with minor setback changes. 
(7)	Issue temporary land use permits for construction or education mobile units. The temporary land use permit shall not exceed the time limits as set forth in this article. 
(c)	Building permits required. Prior to commencing any of the following work, unless exempted by the city's adopted building code, the owner or agent shall obtain a valid permit from the city for the following: 
(1)	Construction of new building, including one- and two-family dwellings, garages, and other structures. 
(2)	Additions that increase the physical dimensions of a building, including decks. 
(3)	Alterations to the building structure, or an alteration to the building's heating, electrical or plumbing systems, except where exempted below. Restoration or repair of an installation to its previous code-compliant condition as determined by the building official. 
(4)	Water heater replacements shall require a permit if the plumbing, venting, electrical or gas supply systems are altered. 
(5)	Electrical service modifications. 
(d)	Exemptions from permit requirements. The following buildings, structures and activities are exempt from the permit requirements of this section: 
(1)	Buildings or structures owned by the city; 
(2)	The restoration or repair of building equipment, such as furnaces, central air conditions, water heaters, and similar mechanical equipment (except electric service) without the alteration of, or addition to, the building or structure. 
(3)	Minor repairs performed for maintenance or replacement purposes in an existing building which does not involve the structural portions of the building or structure, or which does not affect room arrangement, light and ventilation, access to or efficiency of any exit stairways or exits, fire protections and which does not increase a given occupancy or use, for example window and door replacement if it does not affect structure. 
(4)	Re-siding, re-roofing and finishing interior surfaces, and installation of cabinetry. 
(5)	Fences not over seven feet (2,134 mm) high or other similar like enclosures. 
(6)	Portable buildings, or buildings less than 144 square feet, as long as they are not placed upon a permanent slab or foundation. 
(e)	Application for building permit. All applications for building permits shall be made to the building official. Any permit for new construction applied for shall be accompanied by five sets of complete plans, drawn to scale, which shall have been prepared by an architect or engineer whose state registration is current and valid, and whose seal shall be affixed to the plan submitted. Such plans shall include the following: 
(1)	The actual shape and dimensions of the lot to be built upon. 
(2)	The sizes and locations on the lot of any existing buildings. 
(3)	The shape, size, height, use and the location on the lot of the building or structure proposed to be built. 
(4)	Such other information as may be necessary to provide for the enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
(f)	Building permit fees. The building permit fee shall be determined from time to time pursuant to resolution adopted by the mayor and council. 
(g)	Duration of permit validity. A building permit for the purpose of remodeling or an addition to an existing structure shall be valid for a period of six months. A building permit for the purpose of new construction shall be valid for a period of one year. The building permits will expire at the end of the validity date whether work has been completed or not at which time the permit will be required to be renewed for work to continue. 
(h)	Certificate of occupancy required.
(1)	A certificate of occupancy issued by the building official is required in advance of the use or occupancy of the following: 
a.	Any lot or a change or extension in the use thereof. 
b.	A building hereafter erected or a change in the use of an existing building. 
c.	Any nonconforming use that is existing at the time of the enactment of this article or an amendment thereto or that is changed, extended, altered or rebuilt thereafter, the certificate of occupancy shall state specifically herein the nonconforming use fails to meet the provision of this article. 
d.	Nothing contained herein shall require a user to comply with minimum setback or side yard requirements for use of an existing building. 
(2)	A certificate of occupancy, either for the whole or a part of a building, shall be applied for coincident with the application for a building permit and shall be issued within ten days after the erection or structural alterations of such building or part thereof, and shall have been completed in conformity with the provisions of this article. 
(3)	A certificate of occupancy shall not be issued unless the lot, building, or structure, or use thereof complies with all the provisions of this article. If the certificate of occupancy is denied, the building official shall state in writing the reasons for refusal and the applicant shall be notified of the refusal. A record of all certificates shall be kept on file in the office of the building official and copies shall be furnished on request to any person upon request. . 
(i)	Penalties for violation. Any person found in violation of subsection (c) of this section shall be charged an increased permit fee of twice the original permit cost. Any person who is violation of any part of this section may also be subject to the penalties as set forth in section 1-9. 
(j)	Remedies. In any case in which any building or structure is or is proposed to be erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, maintained or used, or any land that is or is proposed to be used in violation of the provisions of this article or amendments thereto, the building official or other appropriate city authority or any adjacent or other property owner who would be damaged by such violation may, in addition to other remedies and after due notice to the owner of the violation, institute injunction, abatement, or any other appropriate action or actions, proceeding or proceedings to prevent, enjoin, abate, or remove such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, maintenance or use. 
(Code 1985, § 22-161)
 
Sec. 8-37. Daycare facility permit and certificate procedure.
(a)	Generally. For construction of daycare facilities, a commercial building permit form shall be completed and submitted to the city community affairs office for approval. In addition, when plans are required by this section, four sets of construction plans shall be submitted to the fire marshal's office for review and approval. 
(b)	Sprinkler systems and fire alarm systems required. All daycare facilities must have an approved fire alarm system. In addition, daycare facilities over one story and all commercial daycare facilities must have an approved sprinkler system. Fire alarm or sprinkler system work will require separate plans to be submitted by a licensed subcontractor after issuance of the building permit. 
(c)	Plans for facilities for fewer than seven occupants. Plans for facilities designed to have fewer than seven occupants may be rendered on eight-inch by 11-inch paper and shall include the following: 
(1)	Dimensions for the overall space. 
(2)	Dimensions for each room. 
(3)	All doors and windows including dimensions of each. 
(4)	Emergency lighting and exit sign locations. 
(5)	Fire extinguisher number and location. 
(6)	Fire alarm device number, type and location. 
(d)	Plans for facilities for seven or more occupants. Facilities designed to have seven or more occupants are subject to the following additional requirements: 
(1)	Plans must be stamped with the seal and state registration number of the drafting architect or engineer, per O.C.G.A. § 25-2-14(a). 
(2)	A site plan shall be submitted with the plans, showing locations of fire hydrants and the distance from the structure to the hydrant. 
(3)	A water flow test result of the closest hydrant showing a minimum flow 1,500 gallons per minute at 20 psi must also be submitted with the plans. 
(e)	Filing approved plans. Plans stamped as approved by the fire marshal's office shall be filed with the city community affairs office. 
(f)	Field inspection. The applicant must request appropriate field inspections by the city building inspector and the fire marshal's office. 
(g)	Certificate of occupancy. When the facility has been approved by and passed all inspections by the building inspector and fire marshal's office, a certificate of occupancy shall be issued. 
 
Secs. 8-38—8-60. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. EXCAVATING AND TRENCHING
 
Sec. 8-61. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Certificate means the certificate issued by Cobb County upon satisfactory completion of a mandatory training/educational program regarding excavation and trench safety practices, such program to be provided by the county. 
Certificate holder means the holder of the certificate identified in the definition of the term "certificate" in this section. 
Excavation means any manmade cavity of depression in the earth's surface, including its sides, walls, or faces, formed by earth removal and producing unsupported earth conditions by reasons of the excavation. If installed forms or similar structures reduce the depth-to-width relationship, an excavation may become a trench. 
OSHA means the Federal Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration, or successor agency. 
Supervisory personnel means any person who has the responsibility for layout, oversight, superintending, directing or controlling an excavation or trenching site. 
Trench is a narrow excavation made below the surface of the ground. In general, the depth is greater than the width, but the width of a trench is not greater than 15 feet. 
(Code 1985, § 5-61; Ord. of 11-7-1988, § 1)
 
Sec. 8-62. Compliance with regulations required.
No individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity of any kind whatsoever shall engage in any excavation or trenching except in compliance with the provisions of this article and in compliance with any applicable state and federal laws and rules. 
(Code 1985, § 5-62; Ord. of 11-7-1988, § 2)
 
Sec. 8-63. Adoption of OSHA safety and health regulations.
All safety and health regulations adopted by OSHA with regard to excavating and trenching operations, particularly 1926 CFR 1926.650—1926.653 (subpart P—excavations, trenching and shoring), as the same now exist or may be amended, are adopted as a part of this article the same as if quoted verbatim herein. 
(Code 1985, § 5-63; Ord. of 11-7-1988, § 3)
 
Sec. 8-64. County certificate required.
(a)	No equipment operator or supervisory personnel shall participate in any excavation or trenching or in any way work in an excavation or trench unless such person holds a valid certificate from the county evidencing satisfactory completion of a required educational program on safe trench/excavation practices provided by the county. No other person shall participate in or work in any excavation or trenching site unless a certificate holder is present at the excavation or trench site where work is being performed. 
(b)	In the event any person who holds a valid certificate is found to be in violation of the safety standards and requirements on any job site, the offense shall be promptly reported to the county. 
(Code 1985, § 5-64; Ord. of 11-7-1988, § 4)
 
Sec. 8-65. City permit required.
(a)	No excavating or trenching shall be performed until a permit or authorization for the same has been obtained from the city. Any applicant will be required to acknowledge receipt and understanding of safety requirements before any permit will be issued. All such permits shall be conspicuously posted upon the job site. No such permit shall be suspended or revoked except for due cause and after hearing before the mayor and council after notice to the permit holder of the date, time and place of hearing, along with notice of the charges, except a permit may be suspended prior to such hearing in the event of a cave-in of an excavation or trench resulting in human injury or death. Due cause shall consist of the violating of any laws or ordinances regulating excavating or trenching. Three days' notice shall be deemed reasonable, but shorter or longer periods of notice shall be authorized as the mayor and council may deem the circumstances to justify. At such hearing, the permit holder shall be entitled to be represented by an attorney, to cross examine any witnesses who may appear against him, and to present evidence in his own behalf. 
(b)	After July 1, 1988, no permit or authorization shall be issued unless an authorized agent of the applicant holds a certificate. 
(Code 1985, § 5-65; Ord. of 11-7-1988, § 5)
 
Sec. 8-66. Inspection by the city.
City personnel shall periodically inspect trench/excavation sites. Such inspectors shall, among other things, verify the presence of the required permit, verify existence of required certificates, and verify compliance to OSHA safety standards hereinabove adopted. 
(Code 1985, § 5-66; Ord. of 11-7-1988, § 6)
 
Sec. 8-67. Violations.
(a)	Violations of this chapter may result in revocation or suspension of any permit issued hereunder as hereinabove set out. 
(b)	A notice of violation shall be issued for any deficiency. Upon receipt of such notice, the deficiency shall be corrected immediately. 
(c)	All excavation and trenching work upon any job site shall cease immediately when there is trench activity by any person not a certificate holder or when the deficiencies cannot be corrected immediately or when there is a refusal or failure to correct immediately or when such work is being done without a permit. 
(d)	If deficiencies identified in a notice of violation are not corrected, the building permit, land disturbance permit or any other permit issued by the city may be suspended or revoked for due cause upon the conditions herein identified for revocation of permit. 
(e)	Flagrant or repeated violations shall be reported by the city to OSHA and Cobb County for action. 
(f)	Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or entity of any kind whatsoever, violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or six-month imprisonment or both for each violation. 
(g)	In addition, every violation of the terms of this chapter by any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or entity of any kind whatsoever, shall be deemed a nuisance and a continuing nuisance so long as such violation may be continued; and such violation is subject to abatement as a nuisance as provided by the laws of this state. 
(h)	Any violation of this article shall be subject to injunction. 
(i)	The above remedies are cumulative. Pursuance of any one remedy shall not be deemed an election of remedies and shall not prohibit pursuance of more than one remedy simultaneously. 
(Code 1985, § 5-67; Ord. of 11-7-1988, § 7)
 
Chapter 10 BUSINESSES 
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 10-1. Construction of terms; definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Business means any business, trade, occupation, profession, avocation, or calling of any kind for gain or profit, directly or indirectly, except those occupations licensed by the state or some agency thereof to the exclusion of the city. 
Dominant line means the type of business, within a multiple-line business, that the greatest amount of income is derived from. 
Engaged in business means when a person performs any act of selling any goods or service or solicits business or offers goods or service for sale for payment in an attempt to make a profit, including the sales or services of the character as made by a wholesaler or retailer or involved in any of the functions performed as a manufacturer, either as an owner, operator, or agent in any business, trade, profession, or occupation within this city; provided, however, the term "engaged in business" shall exclude activities of organizations and entities which are: 
(1)	Nonprofit, charitable organizations; and 
(2)	The activities of which are not in competition with businesses otherwise required to obtain business licenses. Furthermore, the term "engaged in business" shall not include the following activities: nonprofit organization suppers and bake sales, annual church bazaars, amateur youth athletic club sales, and amateur athletic booster club sales. 
Itinerant merchants, flea market vendors and other retailers without permanent places of business means:
(1)	All itinerant merchants, flea market vendors and other retailers without permanent places of business are exercising the same taxable privilege as other merchants when selling at retail in this city. For the exercise of this privilege, a tax is levied. 
(2)	For the purpose of this rule, the term "itinerant merchant" means any person who solicits, engages in, transacts or offers for sale any new or used merchandise either in one location or while traveling from place to place in the city. The term "itinerant merchant" is further defined as any person who does not intend to become or who does not become a permanent merchant at any one location and who for the purpose of transacting such business, rents, hires, leases, occupies or uses any building, structure, lot, tract, motor vehicle, sample case, or display case. 
License means a certificate issued by the city authorizing a person to engage in a business, and a certificate issued by the city evidencing payment of a professional occupation tax. 
Location of office shall not include a temporary work site which serves a single customer or project. 
Manufacturer means a person who, either directly or by contracting with others for the necessary labor or mechanical services, manufactures for sale or commercial use any articles, substances or commodities; including all the activities of a commercial nature wherein labor or skill is applied by hand or machinery, to materials so that as a result thereof a new, different, or useful article of tangible personal property or substance of trade or commerce is produced; and including the production or fabrication of specially or custom-made articles; and including the making, fabricating, processing, refining, mixing, slaughtering, packing, aging, curing, preserving, canning and preparing and freezing of fresh foods, fruits, vegetables, and meats. 
Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue-raising purposes. 
Person means and includes sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofits, or any other form of business organization. 
Practitioner of profession or occupation means one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. The term "practitioner of profession or occupation" shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. 
Professional occupation means an occupation licensed by the state or some agency thereof to the exclusion of the city. 
Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8) or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. 
Retailer means a person who sells to the consumer or any other person for any purpose other than for resale, any article or substance in the form of tangible personal property. 
Service means the accommodating or performing a duty or work by a person utilizing time or talents for direct or indirect remuneration. 
Wholesaler means a person who sells to jobbers or to another person other than the consumer anything in the form of tangible personal property. 
(Code 1976, §§ 3-2041, 7-1001; Code 1985, § 6-1; Ord. of 3-7-1988; Ord. of 9-11-1989; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-2. Occupation tax required; registration.
(a)	Each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city, whether with a location in the city or in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state exerting substantial efforts within the city pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for the business, trade, profession, or occupation. The record of such payment and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the city, such business tax registration shall be shown to the city finance director or the director's designee or to any police officer of the city, upon request. 
(b)	Each such registration shall be for the calendar year in which the registration was obtained unless otherwise specifically provided. The occupation tax, administrative or regulatory fee shall be paid within 90 days of January 1 or, with regard to a new business, the date upon which beginning to conduct business within the city. Each business which fails to timely pay the occupation tax or regulatory fees shall incur a penalty of $50.00. The penalties and interest shall be in addition to all other revocation or rights of the city to revoke business licenses or other licenses or permits granted by the city as well as other penalties, civil and criminal provided for in the Charter and this Code. The penalties and taxes may be collected by the remedies provided herein for collection of the occupation tax, and any penalties shall have the same lien and priority as the occupation tax to which the penalty is applied. 
(c)	Any business which commences following July 1 in any year shall pay a tax for that year of only 50 percent of the tax which would be payable for the full year. There shall be no such reduction in regularity or administrative fee. 
(d)	The registration herein provided for shall be issued by the community affairs department, and if any person whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after the occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the city, any of the kind of business, trade, profession, or occupation without having first obtained the registration, such offender shall be subject to the penalties provided thereof. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2044; Code 1985, § 6-2; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1; Ord. of 12-4-1995, § A; Ord. of 10-5-1998, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-3. License or certificate required.
(a)	Every business in the city required to register under section 10-2 is required to have a business license from the city for the privilege of engaging in a business within the corporate limits of the city if such license is not prohibited by the state. 
(b)	Every occupation licensed by the state to the exclusion of the city is required to have a certificate issued by the city evidencing payment of its occupation tax. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1002; Code 1985, § 6-3; Ord. of 10-6-1980)
 
Sec. 10-4. Occupation tax levied; restrictions.
(a)	An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the corporate limits of the city or upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, based upon the number of employees of the business or practitioner. The tax rate determined by number of employees for each business, trade, profession, or occupation is as follows and will be developed and updated from time to time by the finance department of the city: 
Employees	Tax Liability
1—9 	$125.00 
10—19 	$175.00 
20—49 	$200.00 
50 or more 	$350.00 

(b)	No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one occupation tax for each of its locations. 
(c)	No occupation tax shall be required for those real estate brokers, real estate agents, or real estate companies whose offices are located outside the jurisdiction and who sell property inside the jurisdiction. 
(d)	Notwithstanding the tax schedule set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the occupational tax payable by each insurance company or agency with a business location in the city shall be as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2043; Code 1985, § 6-5; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1; Ord. of 2-1-1999, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-5. License application.
(a)	Every person required to procure a license under the provisions of this Code shall submit an application for such license to the community affairs department, which application shall conform to the requirements of this section in addition to any other provisions of this Code. Unless otherwise provided in this Code, each application shall be a written statement upon forms provided by the community affairs department and submitted before March 1 of each year or ten days prior to opening a new business. Each application shall contain the following information: 
(1)	Name and home address of the applicant if an individual, or home office address if a corporation or partnership. 
(2)	Place where the proposed business is to be located and, if the property is leased, a copy of the lease contract or agreement and any related documents. 
(3)	Kinds of businesses to be carried on and the kinds of goods or services to be offered. 
(4)	Names and home addresses of the partners, if a partnership. 
(5)	Names and home addresses of the officers and directors, if a corporation. 
(6)	Complete record of all arrests and convictions against the applicant and every partner, officer or director of the applicant for violations of any laws and ordinances of the city, state or federal government other than minor traffic violations. 
(7)	A schedule listing the number of all employees who are or were employed during the preceding 12-month period, including the status of each as full- or part-time. (The term "employee" means any worker, full- or part-time, supervised by the employer and for whom the employer withholds FICA, federal income tax or state income tax or to whom an IRS form W-2 is issued by the employer. For each such employee the business must provide the employee's position, typical hours worked per week and dates of employment.) 
(8)	A statement, under oath, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 50-36-1 et seq., providing that the applicant is a United States citizen or legal permanent resident 18 years of age or older or that the applicant is a qualified alien or nonimmigrant under federal law and rules, 18 years of age or older, lawfully present in the United States and provide the applicant's alien number issued by the Department of Homeland Security or other federal immigration agency. 
(9)	Such additional information as the community affairs department or city may find reasonably necessary to the fair administration of this chapter. 
(b)	Each application shall be sworn to by the applicant if an individual, or by a partner if a partnership, or by an officer if a corporation. 
(c)	All information furnished or secured under the authority of this section, except as otherwise by state law provided, shall be kept in strict confidence by the community affairs department, shall not be subject to public inspection, and shall be utilized solely by the officers of the city responsible for administering the provisions of this chapter. 
(d)	False or incomplete statements on any application for a license shall be grounds for immediate revocation of such license and for the imposition of other penalties as herein provided. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1003; Code 1985, § 6-6; Ord. of 10-5-1981; Ord. of 9-4-1987; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1; Ord. of 12-4-1995, § E; Ord. of 2-1-2010)
 
Sec. 10-6. Procedure for issuance of license.
(a)	If any provision of this chapter provides for the review of an application for a license by a city officer designated therein, the community affairs department shall forward a copy of the application to such officer. The officer charged with the duty of reviewing the application shall make a recommendation thereon, favorable or otherwise, and shall return such recommendation to the community affairs department after receiving a copy of the application. 
(b)	Upon the receipt of the recommendation of the reviewing officer as hereinabove provided, or upon the receipt of the application if no reviewing officer is designated, the community affairs department shall forward such recommendation and application to the city for consideration and action at its next regular scheduled public meeting. 
(c)	No license shall be issued to any applicant whose place of business is not in full compliance with all minimum standard construction codes adopted by the city. 
(d)	Upon the express approval of the city, the community affairs department shall issue a business license to the applicant therefor, which license shall state the nature of the business authorized and bear the date of issuance and the signatures of the mayor and community affairs department. 
(e)	The granting of a business license under the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a privilege only, and nothing herein contained shall be construed as granting any person whose business is subject to municipal regulation any legal right to engage in such business. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1004; Code 1985, § 6-7)
 
Sec. 10-7. When tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent.
(a)	Each such occupation tax shall be for the calendar year 1995 and succeeding calendar years thereafter unless otherwise specifically provided. The registration and occupation tax shall be payable January 1 of each year and shall, if not paid by March 1 of each year, be subject to penalties for delinquency as prescribed in this chapter. On any new profession, trade, or calling begun in the city the registration and tax shall be delinquent if not obtained immediately upon beginning business and a penalty imposed. 
(b)	The tax registration herein provided for shall be issued by the community affairs department and if any person whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after the registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the city, any of the kind of profession, trade, or calling subject to this chapter without having first obtained the registration, such offender shall, upon conviction by the judge of the municipal court, be punished by a fine not to exceed one-half of the unpaid occupation tax for each year the tax is not paid. In addition, the marshal may proceed to collect in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2045; Code 1985, § 6-8; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-8. Prorating of tax.
When any person shall commence any business after the beginning of the business tax year, the tax levied by this chapter may be prorated such that the full scheduled rate of tax shall be due for businesses beginning operations before June 1 and one-half of the scheduled rate shall be due for businesses beginning operations on June 1 or later. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2050; Code 1985, § 6-9)
 
Sec. 10-9. Issuance of license or certificate.
Upon the payment of the taxes assessed in this chapter, it shall be the duty of the community affairs department to issue to each person a business license or occupational tax certificate. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2046; Code 1985, § 6-10)
 
Sec. 10-10. License or certificate to be displayed.
All persons shall exhibit and display the license or certificate in some conspicuous place in their business establishment. Any transient or nonresident person doing business within the city shall carry such receipt and certificate either upon the person or on any vehicle or other conveyance which is used in such business, and such person shall exhibit the same to any authorized enforcement officer of the city when requested to do so. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2047; Code 1985, § 6-11)
 
Sec. 10-11. Evidence of state registration required if applicable; state registration to be displayed.
(a)	Each person who is licensed by the secretary of state pursuant to O.C.G.A. title 43 shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city registration may be issued. 
(b)	Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1005; Code 1985, § 6-12; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-12. Transfer of license.
Unless otherwise provided in this Code, a license may not be transferred to another person, new owner, or location except as follows: 
(1)	If the ownership and business type remain the same and only the address or business name has changed then upon a ten day notice to the community affairs department and compliance with all building and zoning requirements, the change shall be allowed; 
(2)	Any other change may be allowed at the discretion of the city on a case by case basis. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1008; Code 1985, § 6-13)
 
Sec. 10-13. Change of address.
