Any person moving from one location to another shall notify the community affairs department of such move and of the new address in writing, no later than ten days after moving. The same tax receipt and certificate will be valid at the new location. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2048; Code 1985, § 6-14)
 
Sec. 10-14. Evidence of qualification required if applicable.
Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of an the city business registration, show evidence that such requirements have been met. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1010; Code 1985, § 6-15; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-15. Termination and renewal of licenses.
All annual licenses shall terminate on the last day of the year when no provision to the contrary is made. Unless otherwise provided, each licensee shall make a written application for renewal on forms supplied by the community affairs department no later than March 1 of each year, which application shall contain substantially the same information as the initial application. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1006; Code 1985, § 6-16)
 
Sec. 10-16. Delinquency penalties.
Any person failing to register on or before March 1 or, in the case of a new business, within ten days of commencing business, or failing to pay the tax due under the terms of this chapter by the due date, shall be subject to a penalty of $50.00. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2053; Code 1985, § 6-17)
 
Sec. 10-17. Revocation, suspension.
(a)	By the mayor. Whenever a person doing business under a city license shall violate any law or ordinance of the United States or of the state or of the city, in pursuance of that business, or when it shall be proven before the mayor that the health, morals, interest and convenience of the public demand the revocation of that license, the mayor shall suspend that license and report such to the next regular meeting of the city for its ratification or rejection. Should the action of the mayor be sustained by the city, the license shall be revoked, for at least one year, otherwise it shall be restored and remain in full force. 
(b)	By the city generally. The city, after affording the licensee notice of the charges and opportunity to be heard with respect to any revocation proceedings, may, if it finds this Code to have been violated by the licensee, licensee's agent, or employee, revoke such license in its entirety, suspend the same for a specified period of time, place the licensee on probation, or place other conditions thereon as the city may deem necessary. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-1007, 7-1011; Code 1985, §§ 6-18, 6-19)
 
Sec. 10-18. Issuance of executions.
The community affairs department shall issue executions for the collection of all outstanding and unpaid taxes imposed and assessed by this chapter. Such executions shall be collected in the manner provided by law for the collection of other taxes due to the city. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2052; Code 1985, § 6-20)
 
Sec. 10-19. Subpoena and arrest powers or city finance department.
(a)	The city finance department and its duly designated officer and inspectors or its successors shall be classified as business inspectors with full subpoena powers in conjunction with any violation pertaining to this chapter. 
(b)	In any case the finance department of the city, through its officers, agents, employees, or representatives, may inspect the books of the business for which the returns are made. The city representative shall have the right to inspect the books or records for the business of which the return was made in the city, and upon demand of the city representative such books or records shall be submitted for inspection by the city within 30 days. Failure of submission of such books or records within 30 days shall be grounds for revocation of the tax registration currently existing to do business in the city. Adequate records shall be kept in the city, for examination by the city representative at that officer's discretion. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of underreporting, a penalty will be assessed for the period delinquent. 
(c)	Upon the failure of any business to pay the occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of the returns within the time required herein, or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as above provided, any business tax registration granted by the city under this chapter permitting the owner of the business to do business for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business tax registration shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax herein provided for is at that time unpaid, or to an individual, firm, or corporation who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by the city representative in accordance with provisions found in subsection (b) of this section. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct business, the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the local government in the case of delinquent occupation tax. 
(Code 1976, §§ 3-2054, 7-1012; Code 1985, § 6-21; Ord. of 10-5-1981; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1; Ord. of 1-6-1997, § XIII)
 
Sec. 10-20. Financial institutions.
(a)	Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, the city has levied for each year, an annual business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations and state building and loan associations at the rate of 0.025 percent of the gross receipts of the institutions as defined in the O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, as now or hereafter amended. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to this section shall be $1,000.00 per year. 
(b)	Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city on March 1 each year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. The returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this chapter shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in the return. 
(c)	The due date of taxes levied by this section shall be April 1 of each year. 
(Code 1985, § 6-23; Ord. of 8-1-1983, §§ 1, 2)
 
Sec. 10-21. Paying occupation tax of business with no location in the state.
Registration and assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the business's largest dollar volume of business in the state is in the city and the business or practitioner: 
(1)	Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(2)	Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 6-24; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-22. Allocation of employees of business with multiple intrastate or interstate locations.
For those businesses that have multiple locations inside and outside of the city, only those employees working within the city shall be counted for the purpose of determining the occupation tax liability. 
(Code 1985, § 6-25; Ord. of 6-3-1991; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-23. Each line of business to be identified on business registration.
The business registration of each business operated in the city shall identify the dominant line of business that the business conducts. 
(Code 1985, § 6-26; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-24. More than one place or line of business.
Where a business is operated at more than one place or where the business includes more than one line, the business shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for each location and line and pay an occupation tax in accordance with the prevailing taxing method and tax rate for each location and line. 
(Code 1985, § 6-27; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-25. Practitioners of professions.
Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18) shall pay an occupation tax based on number of employees as set forth in section 10-4. 
(Code 1985, § 6-28; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-26. Practitioners exclusively practicing for a government.
Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, or a city or county of the state, or instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a city or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
(Code 1985, § 6-29; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-27. Purpose and scope of tax.
The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5 through 48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general or local law and ordinance. 
(Code 1985, § 6-29.1; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-28. Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose.
No business on which a business registration or occupation tax is levied by this chapter shall be exempt from the registration or tax on the grounds that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless 50 percent or more of the entire proceeds from the business are devoted to such purpose. 
(Code 1985, § 6-29.2; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-29. Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain.
All persons subject to the occupation tax levy pursuant to this chapter shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for the business as described in this article, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the registration herein provided for before commencing the same; and any person transacting or offering to transact in the city, any of the kinds of business, trade, profession, or occupation without first having so obtained the registration, shall be subject to penalties provided thereof. 
(Code 1985, § 6-29.3; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-30. Businesses not covered by this chapter.
The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this chapter but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other state law or by local law: 
(1)	Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission. 
(2)	Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. ch. 46-3. 
(3)	Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)	Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(5)	Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq. 
(6)	Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. 
(7)	Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (Businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls.) 
(8)	Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 
(9)	Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(10)	Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(Code 1985, § 6-29.4; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-31. Occupation tax prohibited by state or federal law.
An occupation tax shall not apply to the gross receipts of any part of a business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the laws of the state or of the United States. 
(Code 1985, § 6-29.5; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-32. Requirement of public hearing before tax increase.
(a)	After January 1, 1996, the city council shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this chapter. 
(b)	The city council may by subsequent ordinance or resolution provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioner of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reasons shall be set forth in the minutes of the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 6-29.6; Ord. of 12-5-1994, § 1)
 
Secs. 10-33—10-52. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. ADULT ENTERTAINMENT 
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 10-53. Purpose.
The purpose of this article is to regulate certain types of businesses, including, but not limited to, adult dancing establishments and adult entertainment establishments to the end that the many types of criminal activities frequently engendered by such businesses will be curtailed. However, it is recognized that such regulation cannot de facto approach prohibition. Otherwise a protected form of expression would vanish. As to adult dancing establishments and adult entertainment establishments, this article represents a balancing of competing interests: reduced criminal activity and protection of the neighborhoods through the regulation of adult dancing establishments versus the protected rights of these establishments and their patrons. 
(Code 1985, § 6-93; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-54. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Adult bookstore means an establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, books, magazines or other periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas or an establishment with a segment or section, comprising 20 percent or more of its net sales consisting of printed material which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult dancing establishment means a business that features live dancers for the entertainment of the establishment's patrons. 
Adult entertainment establishment means any business or establishment which offers its patrons services or entertainment characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, discussing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, including, but not limited to, adult motion picture theaters, adult mini motion picture theaters, adult hotels or motels, adult motion picture arcades, adult bookstores, adult video stores, encounter centers, rap establishments, escort bureaus and introduction services, as hereinafter defined. 
Adult hotel or motel means a hotel or motel wherein material is presented which is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult mini motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity for less than 50 persons used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
Adult motion picture arcade means any place to which the public is permitted or invited wherein coin- or slug-operated or electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines, projectors or other image-producing devices are maintained to show images to five or fewer persons per machine at any one time and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of 50 or more persons, used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
Adult video store means an establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, video tapes or movies or other reproductions, whether for sale or rent, which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas or an establishment with a segment or section, comprising five percent or more of its total floor space, devoted to the sale or display of such material or which derives more than five percent of its net sales from videos which are characterized or distinguished or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Appropriate attire means opaque clothing fully covering: 
(1)	The human male or female genitals, pubic area and buttocks; and 
(2)	The entire nipple of the female breasts. 
Crime involving moral character means any drug- or alcohol-related crime or any sex-related crime or any felony. 
Encounter center orrap establishment means any business, agency or person who, for any form of consideration or gratuity, provides a place where two or more persons may congregate, assemble or associate for the primary purpose of engaging in, describing or discussing specified sexual activities, or exposing specified anatomical areas. 
Escort bureau; introduction service means any business, agency or person who, for a fee, commission, hire, reward or profit furnishes or offers to furnish names or persons, or who introduces, furnishes or arranges for persons who may accompany other persons to or about social affairs, entertainments or places of amusement, or who may consort with others about any place of public resort or within any private quarters. 
Good moral character means a person is of good moral character, according to this article, if that person has not been convicted of a drug- or alcohol-related crime or sex-related crime or any felony in the past five years. 
Minor means any person who has not attained the age of 21 years. 
Specified anatomical areas means and includes any of the following: 
(1)	Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region, buttock, or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or 
(2)	Human male genitalia in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
Specified sexual activities means and includes any of the following: 
(1)	Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral or anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of unclothed genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship; 
(2)	Clearly depicting human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; 
(3)	Fondling or touching of nude human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breast; 
(4)	Masochism, erotic or sexually oriented torture, beating or the inflicting of pain; or 
(5)	Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexual contact with an animal by a human being. 
(Code 1985, § 6-94; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 2)
 
Sec. 10-55. Unlawful operation declared nuisance.
Any adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment operated, conducted or maintained contrary to the provisions of this article shall be and the same is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. The city may, in addition to, or in lieu of prosecuting a criminal action hereunder, commence an action, proceeding for abatement, removal or enjoinment thereof, in the manner provided by law. It shall take such other steps and shall apply to such court as may have jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate or remove such adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment and restrain and enjoin any person from operating, conducting or maintaining an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment contrary to the provisions of this article. In addition, violation of the provisions of this article shall be per se grounds for suspension or revocation of a license granted hereunder. 
(Code 1985, § 6-109.3; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 21)
 
Sec. 10-56. Violation penalty.
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00 per violation or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. In addition to such fine or imprisonment, violation of this article shall also be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of the license issued hereunder. 
(Code 1985, § 6-109.2; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 20)
 
Secs. 10-57—10-85. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. LICENSING
 
Sec. 10-86. License required.
It is unlawful for any person, association, partnership or corporation to engage in, conduct or carry on, in or upon any premises within the city of an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment defined in this article, without a license to do so. No license so issued shall condone or make legal any activity thereunder if the same is deemed illegal or unlawful under state or federal law. 
(Code 1985, § 6-97; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 5)
 
Sec. 10-87. Location restrictions.
No adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment shall be located: 
(1)	Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land which is zoned or used for multifamily or single-family uses or purposes. 
(2)	Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land upon which a church, school, governmental building, library, civic center, neighborhood public park or neighborhood playground is located. 
(3)	Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land upon which another establishment regulated or defined hereunder is located. 
(4)	Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land upon which any other establishment selling alcoholic beverages is located. 
For the purposes of this section, distance shall be by a direct line of measurement from property line to property line, using the closest property lines of the parcels of land involved. The term "parcel of land" means any quantity of land in any warranty deed, limited or general, or any quitclaim deed recorded in the deed records of Cobb County or Douglas County. 
(Code 1985, § 6-98; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 6)
 
Sec. 10-88. Application for license.
(a)	Any person, association, partnership or corporation desiring to obtain a license to operate, engage in, conduct or carry on any adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment shall make application to the community affairs department. Prior to submitting such application, a nonrefundable fee, as provided in the fee schedule of the issuing department, shall be paid to the city to defray, in part, the cost of investigation and report required by this division. The community affairs department shall issue a receipt showing that such application fee has been paid. The receipt, or a copy thereof, shall be supplied at the time such application is submitted. 
(b)	The application for license does not authorize the engaging in, operation of or carrying on of any adult entertainment establishment. 
(Code 1985, § 6-100; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 8)
 
Sec. 10-89. Application contents.
Each application for an adult dancing establishment license or adult entertainment establishment license shall contain the following information: 
(1)	The applicant's full true name and any other names used by applicant, including any trade names. 
(2)	The present address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(3)	Acceptable written proof that the applicant is at least 21 years of age. 
(4)	Business, occupation or employment history of the applicant for the five years immediately preceding the date of application, including the business or employment records of the applicant, partners in a partnership, directors and officers of a corporation. 
(5)	The business license history of the applicant and whether such applicant, in previous operations in this or any other city, state or territory under any governmental license, has had such license revoked or suspended, the reason therefor, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of suspension or revocation. 
(6)	If the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation or charter, together with the place and date of incorporation, and the names and addresses of each of its current officers and directors and stockholders. If the applicant is a partnership, the applicant shall set forth the name, residence address and dates of birth of the partners. If the applicant is a limited partnership, it shall furnish a copy of its certification of limited partnership filed with the county clerk or secretary of state. If one or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporations shall apply. The applicant corporation or partnership shall designate one of its officers or general partners to act as its responsible managing officer. Such designated person shall complete and sign all application forms required of an individual applicant under this division, but only one application fee shall be charged. 
(7)	If the applicant, or any of its partners, limited partners, officers, directors, or stockholders (if the applicant or any partner of the applicant is a corporation which has 20 or fewer stockholders), have been convicted of any crime involving moral character in the past five years and, if so, a complete description of any such crime including date of violation, date of conviction, jurisdiction and any disposition, including any fine or sentence imposed and whether the terms of disposition have been fully completed. 
(8)	If the applicant is a person doing business under a trade name, a copy of the trade name properly recorded. If the applicant is a corporation, a copy of authority to do business in the state, including articles of incorporation, trade name affidavit, if any, last annual report, if any. 
(9)	At least three character references from individuals who are in no way related to the applicant or individual shareholders, officers or directors of the applicant and who are not or will not benefit financially in any way from the application if the license is granted and who have not been convicted of any crime involving moral character. The licensing officer shall prepare forms consistent with the provisions of this subsection for the applicant who shall submit all character references on such forms. 
(10)	Address of the premises to be licensed. 
(11)	Whether the premises are owned or rented. 
(12)	A plat by a registered engineer, licensed by the state, showing the location of the proposed premises in relation to the neighborhood, the surrounding zoning, its proximity to any church, school, public park, governmental building or site, or other business hereunder regulated. 
(13)	Each applicant for an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment license shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct by: 
a.	If the applicant is an individual, the individual; 
b.	If by a partnership, by a general partner; 
c.	If a corporation, by the president of the corporation; 
d.	If any other organization or association, by the chief administrative official. 
(Code 1985, § 6-101; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 9)
 
Sec. 10-90. Applicant to appear.
The applicant, if an individual, or designated responsible managing officer, if a partnership or corporation, shall personally appear at a public hearing before the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 6-102; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 10)
 
Sec. 10-91. Application; investigation.
The city shall have 15 days to investigate the application and the background of the applicant. Upon completion of the investigation, the mayor and council may grant the license if it finds: 
(1)	The required fee has been paid; 
(2)	The application conforms in all respects to the provisions of this division; 
(3)	The applicant has not made a material misrepresentation in the application; 
(4)	The applicant has fully cooperated in the investigation of his application; 
(5)	The applicant, or any of its partners, limited partners, officers, directors or stockholders (if the applicant or any partner of the applicant is a corporation which has 20 or fewer stockholders), has not been convicted in a court of competent jurisdiction of an offense involving a sex-, drug- or alcohol-related crime or any felony or convicted of an attempt to commit any of the above-mentioned offenses, or convicted in any state of any offense which if committed or attempted in this state, would have been punishable as one or more of the above-mentioned offenses; 
(6)	Applicant has not had an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment license or other similar license or permit denied or revoked for cause in this city or any other city located in or out of this state prior to the date of application; 
(7)	The building, structure, equipment, or location of such business, as proposed by applicant, would comply with all applicable zoning and distance laws; 
(8)	The applicant is at least 21 years of age; 
(9)	That the applicant, his employees, agents, partners, directors, officers, or managers have not, within five years of the date of the application, knowingly allowed or permitted any of the specified sexual activities, as defined herein, to be committed or allowed in or upon the premises where such adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment is to be located, or to be used as a place in which solicitations for the specified sexual activities as defined herein have occurred; 
(10)	That on the date the business for which a license is required herein commences, and thereafter, there will be a responsible person on the premises to act as manager at all times during which the business is open; 
(11)	That the grant of such license will not cause a violation of this or any other ordinance or regulation of the city, state, or the United States. 
(Code 1985, § 6-103; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 11)
 
Sec. 10-92. Persons prohibited as licensees.
No license provided for by this division shall be issued to or held by: 
(1)	An applicant who has not paid all required fees and taxes to the city. 
(2)	Any person who is not of good moral character. 
(3)	Any corporation, any of whose directors, officers and stockholders (if such corporation has 20 or fewer stockholders) are not of good moral character. 
(4)	Any partnership or association, any of whose partners (general or limited) or members or stockholders (if any partner or member of such partnership or association is a corporation which has 20 or fewer stockholders) are not of good moral character. 
(5)	Any applicant who is not qualified to hold and conduct business according to the laws of the United States, state or city. 
(Code 1985, § 6-104; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 12)
 
Sec. 10-93. License refusal.
If the city, following investigation of the applicant, deems that the applicant does not fulfill the requirements as set forth in this division, it shall notify the community affairs department of such opinion and, within 15 days from the date of application, provide copies of the investigation report to the community affairs department. The community affairs department shall, within ten days, notify the applicant by certified mail of such denial. 
(Code 1985, § 6-105; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 13)
 
Sec. 10-94. Appeal to city council.
Denial of license issuance or renewal may be appealed to the city council. When an appeal hearing is placed on the council agenda, the council shall set a hearing date and instruct the community affairs department to give the appealing party at least ten days' written notice of such a hearing. At such hearing, the council shall receive all relevant testimony and evidence from the appealing party, from interested parties and from city staff. The council may sustain, overrule or modify the action complained of. The action of the council shall be final. 
(Code 1985, §§ 6-109, 6-109.1; Ord. of 2-6-1995, §§ 17, 19)
 
Sec. 10-95. License renewal.
Licenses for adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishments may be renewed on a year-to-year basis, provided that the licensees continue to meet the requirements set out in this division. The renewal fee for the adult entertainment establishment licenses and adult dancing establishment licenses shall be as provided in the fee schedule of the issuing department. 
(Code 1985, § 6-106; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 14)
 
Sec. 10-96. Licenses nontransferable.
No adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment license may be sold, transferred or assigned by a licensee, or by operation of law, to any other person. Any such sale, transfer or assignment, or attempted sale, transfer or assignment, shall be deemed to constitute a voluntary surrender of such license and such license shall thereafter be null and void; provided and excepting, however, that if the licensee is a partnership and one or more of the partners should die, one or more of the surviving partners may acquire, by purchase or otherwise, the interest of the deceased partner without effecting a surrender or termination of such license. An adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment license issued to a corporation shall be deemed terminated and void when either any outstanding stock of the corporation is sold, transferred or assigned after the issuance of a license, or any stock authorized but not issued at the time of the granting of license is thereafter issued and sold, transferred or assigned; provided and excepting, however, that if a stockholder dies, one or more of the remaining stockholders may acquire the interest of the deceased stockholder without effecting a surrender or termination of such license. 
(Code 1985, § 6-107; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 15)
 
Sec. 10-97. Change of location or name.
(a)	No adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment shall move from the location specified on its license until a change of location fee in the amount of $500.00 has been deposited with the city, and approval has been obtained from the community affairs director. Such approval shall not be given unless all requirements and regulations, as contained in this Code, have been met. 
(b)	No licensee shall operate, conduct, manage, engage in, or carry on an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment under any name other than his name and the name of the business as specified on his license. 
(c)	Any application for an extension or expansion of a building or other place of business where an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment is located shall require inspection and shall comply with the provisions and regulations of this division. 
(Code 1985, § 6-108; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 16)
 
Sec. 10-98. Grounds for revocation.
(a)	It shall be grounds for revocation of an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment license if the applicant is convicted of committing an offense that would have prevented an issuance of the original license under this division. 
(b)	It shall also be grounds for revocation if the applicant or applicant's agents or employees knowingly allow any criminal offense to occur on the licensed premises. Criminal offenses shall include any violation of the city ordinance or criminal laws of the state. 
(c)	It shall also be grounds for revocation if the person, corporation, partnership or association possessing an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment license fails to pay any fee or fines required by this division. 
(d)	It shall also be grounds for revocation if the licensee fails to pay when due all ad valorem taxes assessed against the licensee or if the ad valorem real property taxes assessed against the property upon which the licensee operates its business are not paid when due. 
(e)	It shall also be grounds for revocation if the licensee or any employee of a licensee violates any provision of this division. 
(Code 1985, § 6-109.4; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 22)
 
Sec. 10-99. Revocation hearing.
No license issued under this division may be revoked, except as provided herein and only after a hearing before the city council, for the city, upon a prior written notice to the licensee of the time, place and purpose of such hearing and a general statement of the reason the license would be revoked. Ten days' notice of the hearing shall be deemed reasonable. 
(Code 1985, § 6-109.5; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 23)
 
Sec. 10-100. Judicial appeal.
Any decision of the city council in the revocation of an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment license may be appealed to the Cobb County superior court for review. 
(Code 1985, § 6-109.6; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 24)
 
Secs. 10-101—10-128. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. BUSINESS OPERATION REQUIREMENTS
 
Sec. 10-129. Adult dancing establishment regulations.
(a)	No person shall advertise, or cause to be advertised, operate or cause to be operated an adult dancing establishment without a valid adult entertainment license issued pursuant to this article. 
(b)	No later than March l of each year an adult dancing establishment licensee shall file a verified report with the community affairs department or its designee showing the licensee's gross receipts and amounts paid to dancers for the preceding calendar year. 
(c)	An adult dancing establishment licensee shall maintain and retain for a period of two years the names, addresses, and ages of all persons employed as dancers. 
(d)	No adult dancing establishment licensee shall employ or contract with as a dancer or a person under the age of 21 years or a person not licensed pursuant to this article. 
(e)	No person under the age of 21 years shall be admitted to an adult dancing establishment. 
(f)	An adult dancing establishment shall not be open, except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m., Monday through Friday, or between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 11:55 p.m. on Saturday. 
(g)	No dancer shall fondle or caress any patron and no patron shall fondle or caress any dancer. No dancing shall occur closer than ten feet to any patron. 
(h)	No dancer shall solicit any pay or gratuity from any person. 
(i)	All dancers must wear appropriate attire when in view of or performing for the establishment's patrons. 
(j)	No adult dancing establishment shall allow any of its employees to engage in specified sexual activities on the premises of such establishments, and no employee of an adult dancing establishment shall engage in specified sexual activities on the premises of such establishments. 
(k)	No adult dancing establishment shall serve, sell, distribute or suffer the consumption or possession of any intoxicating liquor or controlled substance upon the premises of the licensee. 
(Code 1985, § 6-95; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 3)
 
Sec. 10-130. Adult entertainment establishment regulations.
(a)	No adult entertainment establishment licensee shall employ or contract with a person under the age of 21 years or a person not licensed pursuant to this article. 
(b)	No person under the age of 21 years shall be admitted to an adult entertainment establishment. 
(c)	An adult entertainment establishment shall not be opened, except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m., Monday through Friday, or between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 11:55 p.m. on Saturday. 
(d)	No adult entertainment establishment shall allow any of its employees to engage in specified sexual activities on the premises of such establishment, and no employee of an adult entertainment establishment shall engage in specified sexual activities on the premises of such establishment. 
(Code 1985, § 6-96; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 4)
 
Sec. 10-131. Employee restrictions.
(a)	Qualifications. Employees of an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment shall be not less than 21 years of age. Every employee must be of good moral character as defined in this article. Any employee who is convicted of a sex-related crime, or drug-related or alcohol-related felony while employed in any such establishment or under contract to any such establishment shall not thereafter work on any premises requiring licenses under this article for a period of five years from the date of such conviction, unless a longer time is ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. The term "convicted" includes an adjudication of guilt on a plea of guilty or nolo contendere. 
(b)	Approval for employment. Before any person may work on a licensed premises, he shall file a notice with the city police department of his intended employment on forms that require the information set forth in subsection (a) of this section. The city shall have 15 days to investigate the information required by the employee. If the employee is found to meet the qualifications of subsection (a) of this section, the city shall issue the applicant a license under this section. Upon issuance of the license, the employee may begin working on the licensed premises. If approval is denied, the prospective employee may, within ten days of the denial, apply to the city council for a hearing. The city council shall hold a hearing and shall issue such order as is required. An investigation fee as provided in the fee schedule of the issuing department shall accompany the notice of intended employment. 
(c)	Suspension, revocation of license. Conviction of violating the provisions of this Code shall subject an employee to suspension or revocation of a license. It shall be grounds for revocation of a license to operate an adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment if the applicant commits an offense which would have prevented an issuance of the original license or if the applicant or applicant's agents, employees or manager knowingly allow any criminal offense to occur on the licensed premises. 
(d)	Independent contractors. For the purpose of this article, independent contractors shall be considered as employees and shall be licensed as employees, regardless of the business relationship with the owner or licensee of any adult dancing establishment or adult entertainment establishment. 
(Code 1985, § 6-99; Ord. of 2-6-1995, § 7)
 
Secs. 10-132—10-160. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. AUCTIONEERS AND AUCTIONS 
 
Sec. 10-161. Applicability of article.
This article shall apply to all auctions, auctioneers, auction houses and any city licenses issued for such business activity. 
(Code 1976, § 7-3001; Code 1985, § 6-110)
 
Sec. 10-162. Auctioneer's license exemption.
Auctioneers required to obtain separate licenses under the existing license schedule are exempt from the requirement of obtaining such license provided they are employed by a licensed auction house in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 7-3002; Code 1985, § 6-111)
 
Sec. 10-163. Auction house parking; limit on number of days.
No auction house shall be licensed hereunder unless it shall have available no less than 25 parking places reserved for its customers and unless it limits its conduct of auctions to no more than two days per week. 
(Code 1976, § 7-3003; Code 1985, § 6-112)
 
Sec. 10-164. Auction license; days per week limited; false advertising.
(a)	Except for judicial auctions or auctions under a power contained in a will or trust, no auction shall be conducted in the city unless a license therefor is first obtained from the community affairs department. If the auctions are limited to no more than one day, an auctioneer's license as otherwise provided will be sufficient. In the event auctions are to be conducted on a regular basis or more than once a year, an auction house license must be obtained before any auction can be held. 
(b)	All auctions shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. ch. 43-6. In addition, no auction shall be conducted more than two days per week in the city and all such auctions must be conducted on the premises of the licensed auction house. 
(c)	No person shall make any statement or advertisement regarding an auction or the merchandise to be sold therein or the conditions or terms of sale, which advertisement or statement contains any assertion or representation which is untrue, misleading or deceptive. 
(Code 1976, § 7-3004; Code 1985, § 6-113)
 
Sec. 10-165. State sales tax return.
Each auction house upon applying for reissuance of its annual license shall attach thereto copies of its state sales tax return showing its gross sales for the year. The sales tax return shall be certified under oath by the applicant or applicant's accountant. 
(Code 1976, § 7-3005; Code 1985, § 6-114)
 
Secs. 10-166—10-183. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE IV. AUTO REPAIR ESTABLISHMENTS
 
Sec. 10-184. Scope.
This article shall apply to all businesses and locations within the city limits that meet the definition of an automotive paint and body repair shop, a light automotive repair establishment or a heavy automotive repair establishment (hereinafter "establishments") and all owners, operators and employees of said establishments. The general provisions of article I of this chapter shall apply herein except to the extent that they are inconsistent with the more specific provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 08-2017-01, § 6-220, 8-7-2017; Ord. No. 08-2017-03, § 1(6-220), 8-7-2017)
 
Sec. 10-185. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Automotive paint and body shop means an establishment for restoring auto bodies, painting or refinishing, with all activities carried on entirely within an enclosed building. 
Establishment employee means any individual employed, directly or indirectly, as a subcontractor or 1099 employee, of an establishment. 
Establishment owner means all persons, firms, corporations, partnerships or other forms of business entities operating, maintaining and/or managing an establishment and in whose name the business is licensed in the city. 
Heavy automotive repair establishment means an indoor repair establishment for performing automotive and truck repair, including engine and transmission overhauls. 
Light automotive repair establishment means an indoor repair establishment (no outside storage) for performing light auto and small truck repair (under one ton) such as brake repair, oil changes, lubrication, transmission repair, installation of belts and hoses, inspections and the like. 
(Ord. No. 08-2017-01, § 6-221, 8-7-2017; Ord. No. 08-2017-03, § 1(6-221), 8-7-2017)
 
Sec. 10-186. Business license requirements.
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to operate an establishment without a business license issued from the city. Business licenses issued for an establishment shall be valid only for the licensed location. 
(b)	All persons or entities desiring to obtain a business license as the operator of an establishment shall make written applications to the city on forms to be prepared and approved by the city. Applicants shall supply such reasonable and necessary information as may be required by the city. 
(c)	All applicants shall furnish all data, information and records reasonably related to the evaluation of an application, as may be required by the city or an interested city department. An applicant, by filing an application, agrees to produce for oral interrogatories any person under the applicant's supervision or control who might have information pertinent to the application, upon request of the city. Failure to furnish such information or produce persons within 30 days of the request shall automatically serve to dismiss the application. 
(d)	No application for any license hereunder shall be granted where the application or investigation shows any of the following to exist: 
(1)	The applicant has had any license issued under the police powers of any county or other governmental entity previously suspended or revoked. 
(2)	The location, if applicable, is not properly zoned. 
(3)	The applicant, as a previous holder of a license for this type of establishment, has violated any law, including this article, relating to such business, within a ten-year period immediately preceding the date of application. 
(4)	No similar business license is in effect for the location, if applicable. 
(5)	The applicant has supplied false information either on said application or in any communication with any official of the city relative to said application. 
(6)	The applicant has failed to pay any fee required under this article or has otherwise failed to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(7)	The applicant, during the 12-month period next preceding the filing this application has engaged in any deceptive business practice as defined by state and/or federal law. 
(8)	No original license hereunder shall be issued to an person, partnership, or corporation for pecuniary gain where any individual having an interest either as owner, partner, stockholder owning at least 25 percent of the stock of the corporation, such interest being direct or indirect, beneficial or absolute, or his spouse or the manager of the operation, shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendere within ten years immediately prior to the filing of said application for a felony or misdemeanor of any state or of the United States or any municipal or county ordinance except traffic violations. The term "conviction" includes an adjudication of guilt, a plea of guilty, or a plea of nolo contendere, or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime. Where the violation is for a misdemeanor, forfeiture of bond, violation of a municipal or county ordinance or where there is a plea of nolo contendere, the city council may, after investigation, if appealed by the applicant, waive the same as a disqualification. 
(9)	In addition to the above and in determining whether or not any license applied for shall be granted, the following shall be considered in the public interest and welfare: 
a.	If the applicant is a previous holder of a license, the manner in which he conducted his business thereunder, and particularly as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. 
b.	The location for which the license is sought, if applicable, as to traffic congestion, general character of the neighborhood and surrounding area, and the effect such an establishment would have on the adjacent and surrounding property values. 
c.	If it appears as though a third party is just using the applicant as a guise or "dummy" to obtain a license. 
(e)	Application fees and license fees for business licenses required hereunder shall be set from time to time by the city council. A schedule of said fees shall be maintained on file in the office of the clerk of the city. Licenses shall be issued for the time period selected as allowable upon the schedule of fees. 
(f)	Any license issued hereunder shall be posed conspicuously at the place of doing business of the licensee. 
(g)	No license hereunder shall be transferrable. 
(h)	Each license under this article shall be for one location only. Applicants with multiple locations shall obtain a separate license, paying a separate fee, for each place of business. 
(Ord. No. 08-2017-01, § 6-222, 8-7-2017; Ord. No. 08-2017-03, § 1(6-222), 8-7-2017)
 
Sec. 10-187. Zoning.
No license or permit shall be issued for an establishment under this article for a location, nor shall any business of such an establishment be conducted at any location or upon any property unless the property has been zoned PSC planned shopping center district, GC general commercial, LI light industrial or HI heavy industrial. 
(Ord. No. 08-2017-01, § 6-224, 8-7-2017; Ord. No. 08-2017-03, § 1(6-224), 8-7-2017)
 
Sec. 10-188. Requirements.
(a)	Establishments issued a license under this article cannot have bay doors facing a single- or two-family residential district. 
(b)	Establishments issued a license under this article cannot store vehicles that are being held for repair for more than 45 days from the date the vehicle is accepted for repair. However, the 45-day time limit may be extended to no more than 90 days from the date the vehicle is accepted for repair if the process to obtain a lien on the vehicle by the owner/operator of the establishment has been initiated. 
(c)	If an establishment cannot repair a vehicle that is accepted for repair on the same day on which it is accepted for repair, and the vehicle must be kept overnight by the establishment, the owner/operator of the establishment must: 
(1)	Catalogue and inventory each vehicle received including: date, make and model. 
(2)	Have no more than two vehicles stored per bay or work station after regular business hours. Any additional vehicles must be parked indoors or behind a solid screening fence at least six feet tall. 
(3)	If the establishment is within 200 feet of residentially zoned property, all vehicles being stored overnight must be hidden from view by either storing them indoors or behind a solid screening fence at least six feet tall. Said fencing must run along all property lines facing the residential property. 
(4)	For all establishments receiving a license under this article, all wrecked or dismantled vehicles must be stored indoors in an enclosed structure or completely hidden behind a solid screening fence at least six feet tall. 
(d)	Establishments issued a license under this article cannot store or display any merchandise in the open or on the outside of the building and/or structure located on the property. Merchandise shall include, but not be limited to, the following items: 
(1)	Automotive parts (transmissions, engines, mufflers, etc.). 
(2)	Automotive accessories (toolboxes, bed liners, bed covers, etc.). 
(3)	Related automotive accessories (jack stands, polishes, waxes, floor jacks, etc.). 
(4)	Exception. An establishment issued a license under this article may display racks of rims, wheels, mags, or tires (no more than three sets or a total of 12 tires) during hours of operation. All such displays and merchandise must be moved indoors during the time that the establishment is closed. 
(e)	Except for the replacement of a battery, an establishment issued a license under this article must perform all repair work indoors including replacement and removal activities such as changing/repairing tires, spark plugs, oil, filters, etc. 
(Ord. No. 08-2017-01, § 6-225, 8-7-2017; Ord. No. 08-2017-03, § 1(6-225), 8-7-2017)
 
Sec. 10-189. Revocation, suspension, probation of license.
(a)	Whenever a person doing business under a license pursuant to this article shall violate any law or ordinance of the United States, the state or the city, in pursuance of that business, or when it shall be proven before the mayor that the health, morals, interest and convenience of the public provide due cause for the revocation or suspension of that license, the mayor shall suspend that license and report such to the next regular meeting of the governing body for its ratification or rejection. Should the action of the mayor be sustained by the governing body, the license shall be revoked for one year, otherwise it shall be restored and remain in full force and effect. 
(b)	Due cause for the suspension or revocation of such license shall consist of any of the following: 
(1)	Violation of the provisions of this or any other city ordinance; 
(2)	Violation of any laws, ordinances or resolutions regulating such business, or violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating such business; 
(3)	A licensee or permittee has supplied false information to the city either during or following application for a permit or license, regardless of when the city shall have become aware of the same; 
(4)	A licensee or permittee makes a misrepresentation of fact, whether through advertisement or through any form of direct communication, oral or written, which is intended to mislead the public or to mislead a party with whom the licensee or permittee deals in pursuance of the licensed or permitted business. The term "misrepresentation of fact," as used herein, shall embrace not only express misrepresentations but also misrepresentations arising by virtue of the licensee's or permittee's conduct, including acts and omissions; 
(5)	If any reasons exist which would have been grounds for denial of the original application or renewal of the license or permit. 
(Ord. No. 08-2017-01, § 6-226, 8-7-2017; Ord. No. 08-2017-03, § 1(6-226), 8-7-2017)
 
Sec. 10-190. Violations; penalties.
Any person or entity violating any provision of this article shall be punished as follows: 
(1)	Upon first conviction, plea of guilty, or plea of nolo contendere, issued a fine of not more than $300.00, as well as potential suspension or revocation of the license pursuant to section 10-189; 
(2)	Upon second conviction, plea of guilty, or plea of nolo contendere, issued a fine of not more than $600.00, as well as potential suspension or revocation of the license pursuant to section 10-189; 
(3)	Upon third conviction, plea of guilty, or plea of nolo contendere, issued a fine of not more than $1,000.00 and up to one year in jail, as well as potential suspension or revocation of the license pursuant to section 10-189. 
In addition, every violation of the terms of this article by any person or entity shall be considered a nuisance and a continuing nuisance so long as such violation may be continued; and such violation is subject to abatement as a nuisance as provided by this Code for the city and laws of this state. The above remedies are cumulative. Pursuance of any one remedy shall not be deemed an election of remedies and shall not prohibit pursuance of more than one remedy at any time. 
(Ord. No. 08-2017-01, § 6-227, 8-7-2017; Ord. No. 08-2017-03, § 1(6-227), 8-7-2017)
 
Secs. 10-191—10-218. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE V. BAIL BONDING COMPANIES 
 
Sec. 10-219. Professional bonding companies, definition.
All persons who hold themselves out as signers or sureties of bail bonds for compensation, and who are licensed as provided herein, are declared to be professional bonding companies, whether operating as a corporation, partnership or sole proprietorship. 
(Code 1985, § 6-40; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 1)
 
Sec. 10-220. Applicability of article.
This article shall apply to any city business license issued to any professional bail bonding company as herein defined and to regulate the activities of others herein provided for in relation to this bonding business. 
(Code 1985, § 6-41; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 2)
 
Sec. 10-221. Qualification for license.
(a)	Application. To qualify for a license as a professional bonding company, the applicant shall submit the following applications to the community affairs department office: 
(1)	A completed application for bonding company. This application shall provide information in regard to the overall operation of a bonding business including the name of all partners, officers, stockholders and any other person or corporation having an interest in the bonding company. 
(2)	A completed application for bonding company employees. This application shall provide personal information in order that a background investigation on the bonding company employees can be conducted. Any individual who will have power of attorney extended for the purpose of writing bonds must submit the above described applications. 
(3)	The applicant furnished with the application, a complete set of the fingerprints and a recent credential-size full face photograph and a consent form permitting full background and criminal record examinations of each person who will act as an agent or employee of the bonding company. The fingerprints shall be processed by the police chief who shall certify the person to be free of any record of any crime of moral turpitude or any violation of law applicable to the bail bonding business. 
(4)	The applicant must set forth affirmatively that the applicant and its employees meet the qualifications set forth herein. 
(b)	Qualifications. No person including the applicant, its principals or employees, shall be permitted to sign professional bonds or act as an agent or representative of a bonding company if such person shall not meet the following qualifications: 
(1)	No such person shall have been convicted of a felony offense, convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude, failed to meet bonding obligations in the city, Cobb County or any other county in the state or elsewhere, or failed to qualify under applicable state statutes governing who may act in such a capacity. 
(2)	No persons employed by an agency having access to criminal history information, or persons related to those having such access, will be permitted to operate, own an interest in, or act in any capacity as an agent for a professional bonding company. For the purposes of this subsection, the term "persons related" includes spouses, children, stepchildren, parents, stepparents, grandparents, brothers, sisters, stepbrothers, stepsisters and first cousins. 
(3)	Such person shall have reached the age of 21 years, be a citizen of the United States and shall have been a bona fide resident of the state for the immediately preceding one-year period. 
(4)	The bail bonding company employing such person shall be located in the state and will be actively engaged in the bail bonding business and maintain a place of business accessible to the public. 
(5)	Such person shall be of good character and the applicant (or its officers, if a corporation) shall be vouched for by two other reputable citizens who are residents of the county. 
(Code 1985, § 6-42; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 3)
 
Sec. 10-222. Prohibited practices.
Professional bonding companies, their agents and employees shall be prohibited from taking the following actions: 
(1)	Suggesting employment of attorney. Professional bonding companies shall not suggest or advise the employment, or name for employment, any attorney to represent the defendant, during the negotiations for the bondsman to sign the bond or subsequent thereto. 
(2)	Soliciting business, etc., by bondmen. No professional bonding companies shall solicit business as a bondsman, nor shall such bondsman lounge about or around the county jail , for the purpose of engaging in or soliciting business as a bondsman; nor shall any officer or personnel of the county jail suggest to or advise in any manner whatever any prison of the city, the employment of the services of any particular professional bonding company to sign bonds for appearance in court at any time. 
(3)	Participation in defense. Professional bonding companies shall not advise defendants, principals in bonds signed by them, or give any directions in the defense or disposition of the cases in which bonds are signed. 
(4)	Payments to and by. No professional bonding companies, becoming surety on a bond and receiving the compensation in the case for signing a bond as surety, shall thereafter receive any other sum in the case to the final disposition of the case. 
(5)	Indirect bonds. No professional bonding company may sign a bond in which another bonding company or third party receives compensation to arrange the release of an inmate from the county jail or other detention facility. 
(6)	Persons prohibited from signing bonds. No attorney at law and no official authorized to admit to bail, nor any city or county official, shall become surety on any bond. 
(7)	Fees of sureties. Professional bonding companies shall not, when receiving compensation, charge or receive more than ten percent of the principal amount of the bond from the defendant or from anyone acting for the defendants. 
(8)	Prohibited payments and delegation of authority. No professional bonding company shall: 
a.	Pay a fee or rebate or give or promise anything of value to a jailer, police officer, peace officer, city recorder, or any other person who has power to arrest or to hold in custody; or to any city official or city employee in order to secure a settlement, compromise, remission or reduction of the amount of any bail bond thereof; 
b.	Pay a fee or rebate or give anything of value to an attorney in bail bond matters, except in defense of any action on a bond; 
c.	Pay a fee or rebate or give or promise anything of value to the principal or anyone in the principal's behalf; 
d.	Sign or countersign in blank any bond, or give a power of attorney to, or otherwise authorize, anyone to countersign such person's name to bonds unless the person so authorized is directly employed by the bondsman giving such power of attorney. 
(Code 1985, § 6-43; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 4)
State law reference(s)—Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-51 et seq. 
 
Sec. 10-223. Proof of financial responsibility.
It is unlawful for any professional bonding company to engage in the bonding business within the city without first offering proof of financial responsibility. Such proof shall be provided by the city by execution of an agreement with the city providing for an escrow account in any one or more financial institutions approved by the city. This escrow shall be ten percent of that company's bonding capacity and shall not be less than $10,000.00. If this escrow is encroached upon for any reason, or if the city council otherwise determines that additional escrow funds are required to insure the solvency or reliability of the professional bonding business, the city may require additional deposits to the escrow account. 
(Code 1985, § 6-44; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 5)
 
Sec. 10-224. Bonds in excess of financial capacity.
In the event a bonding company issues and has outstanding bonds of a face amount in excess of its proven financial responsibility or bonding capacity, it is unlawful for that company to issue further bonds without first offering proof of additional financial responsibility to the extent of such new bonds or cancelling sufficient outstanding bonds to reduce its bonding limits to a dollar amount within its proof of financial responsibility. 
(Code 1985, § 6-45; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 6)
 
Sec. 10-225. Monthly reports.
All bonding companies shall file with the police chief a monthly report. All reports shall be submitted on the form designed by the city council. These reports will include the following information and shall be filed in the form of an affidavit: 
(1)	List by name, in alphabetical order, amount and date of bonds signed during each month. 
(2)	List by name, in alphabetical order, case or indictment number and date of all bonds officially settled during each month. 
(3)	List by name, amount and date of bond all judgments rendered by the city court, the state or superior court of Cobb County or other jurisdictions subject to collection in the city. 
(4)	List by name, amount and date of bond all forfeitures pending in the city, Cobb County or other counties subject to collection in the city. 
(5)	List personnel in the employment of submitting bonding company. 
(6)	Report shall be filed with the city police chief on or before the tenth calendar day of each month. 
(Code 1985, § 6-46; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 7)
 
Sec. 10-226. Equal access to jail.
All professional bonding companies which hold a currently effective license, issued by the community affairs department, shall be entitled to equal access to the jail of this city for the purpose of making bond. 
(Code 1985, § 6-47; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 8)
 
Sec. 10-227. Termination of business.
Any professional bonding company which discontinues writing bail bonds during the period for which it is licensed shall notify the police chief and the community affairs department and immediately return such license. 
(Code 1985, § 6-48; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 9)
 
Sec. 10-228. Employee termination.
Any professional bonding company which terminates the appointment of any employee authorized to sign bonds shall immediately file written notice thereof with the police chief and the community affairs department, with a copy given or mailed to the terminated employee. Such notice filed shall state the reasons, if any, for such termination. Information so furnished shall be privileged and shall not be used as evidence in any action against the bonding company. 
(Code 1985, § 6-49; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 10)
 
Sec. 10-229. Denial, suspension, refusal to renew or revocation of license, penalties.
(a)	The city may deny, suspend, revoke or refuse to renew any license issued in accordance with these requirements for any of the following causes: 
(1)	Any cause for which issuance of the license could have been refused had it then existed and been known to the city. 
(2)	Material misstatement, misrepresentation or fraud in obtaining the license. 
(3)	Misappropriation, conversion or unlawful withholding of money belonging to others and received in the conduct of business under the license. 
(4)	Felony conviction of professional bonding company principal. 
(5)	Fraudulent or dishonest practices in the conduct of business under the license. 
(6)	Willful failure to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(7)	Willful failure to return collateral security to the principal when the principal is entitled thereto. 
(8)	When in the judgment of city, the licensee has, in the conduct of affairs under the license, demonstrated incompetency, or untrustworthiness, or conduct or practices rendering licensee unfit to carry on the bail bonding business, or making the licensee's continuance in such business detrimental to the public interest, or that the licensee is no longer in good faith carrying on the bail bond business, or that the licensee is guilty of rebating, or offering to rebate, or offering to divide the licensee's compensation, and for any of such reasons, is found by the city to be a source of detriment, injury or loss to the public. 
(b)	Any violation of this article shall subject the bonding company, and its principals, agents or employees in violation, to suspension of the license and punishment as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1985, § 6-50; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 11)
 
Sec. 10-230. Bonding procedures.
All bonding companies must comply with the bonding procedures as established for use in the city court. 
(Code 1985, § 6-51; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 12)
 
Sec. 10-231. Display of signs.
(a)	Each professional bonding company, duly licensed by the city, shall be allowed to display a sign, in a place designated by the police chief, at or near the book-in book-out section of the county jail. 
(b)	One sign per licensee shall be permitted and shall be limited to lettering and numbering of no more than three inches high and 1.5 inches in width for each letter or numeral. 
(c)	Signs shall be limited to two lines to allow name of business at top and phone number at bottom. 
(d)	Signs shall be restricted to black and white in coloring and shall be hung in place so designated on a first come first serve priority. 
(Code 1985, § 6-52; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 14)
 
Sec. 10-232. Prenumbered receipt as evidence of payment.
(a)	All professional bonding companies, which accept money or any other consideration for any bail bond which they execute, must for each payment received, give to the persons paying the money or giving the consideration, a prenumbered receipt as evidence of payment, which receipt shall state the date, name of the principal amount of money or consideration received and purpose of which received, number of the power of attorney form attached to the bond, penal sum of the bond, and name of person making payment or giving consideration. 
(b)	All professional bonding companies must retain a duplicate copy of each receipt issued as part of such person's records. 
(Code 1985, § 6-53; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 15)
 
Sec. 10-233. Power of attorney.
All professional bonding companies must attach to each bail bond a duly executed power of attorney in an amount of at least the penal sum of the bond. This section shall not apply to any card or certificate of membership of any automobile club. 
(Code 1985, § 6-54; Ord. of 7-1-1996, § 16)
 
Secs. 10-234—10-259. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE VI. CABARETS
 
Sec. 10-260. Scope of article; cabaret defined; license required.
(a)	In addition to all other license requirements of this Code, the following sections shall apply to the licensing and operation of a cabaret, which is defined as any establishment, indoor or outdoor, which provides entertainment (live or otherwise), or a place for entertainment, or a dance floor, or any facility for participatory entertainment, regardless of whether or not alcoholic beverages are served therein, provided this shall not apply to a motion picture or live theater unless alcoholic beverages are served therein. 
(b)	A separate business license shall be required for the operation of a cabaret according to the business license schedule adopted from time to time by the city, provided a separate business license is required for the operation of the business initially. Should any section of this article conflict with other provisions of this Code, then the most restrictive provisions shall control. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2091; Code 1985, § 6-150; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 9-8-1986)
 
Sec. 10-261. Entertainment; hours.
Entertainment at a cabaret shall be permitted only from 8:00 a.m. until the following 2:00 a.m. each day, Monday through Saturday. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2092; Code 1985, § 6-151; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 6-2-1986; Ord. of 9-8-1986)
 
Sec. 10-262. Private guards.
Private security must be provided by the holder of a cabaret license at the holder's own expense as follows: 
(1)	All establishments operating under a cabaret license shall have at least one private duty guard on the premises who shall be a person other than an owner, bartender, cook or cashier. 
(2)	Any person so employed as a guard shall first submit to a records and identification check by the police department in the discretion of the police chief based on the results of the records and identification examination. 
(3)	The cost of a records and identification examination and the issuance of a city identification card shall be $10.00 and shall be borne by the licensee. 
(4)	Any person so employed as a guard shall not be allowed to carry any firearm in the performance of such person's duties unless such guard is an employee of a licensed security agency and is individually licensed by the state as a security guard. 
(5)	All guards shall wear prominently displayed on their person an identification card or badge identifying them as guards and shall at all times carry on their persons the city identification card. 
(6)	No person shall be employed as a guard unless such person shall be age 21 years or older. 
(7)	Private security guards shall be on duty from 5:00 p.m. until the following 2:00 a.m. both Friday and Saturday nights. 
(8)	Private security guards shall be given a copy of the relevant portions of this Code. It shall be their duty to enforce such ordinances, provided they shall not have the power to arrest or detain any offender but shall call for police assistance to affect any arrest or citation for violation of this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2093; Code 1985, § 6-152; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 6-2-1986; Ord. of 9-8-1986; Ord. of 3-6-1989)
 
Sec. 10-263. Loitering.
(a)	For the purposes of a cabaret license, the term "loitering" means remaining outside the place of business of any cabaret license holder for a period of more than ten minutes; or, if a crowd of more than ten people has assembled, for any period of time longer than necessary to walk to one's automobile and drive directly from the premises. 
(b)	Loitering outside the place of business of any cabaret license holder is prohibited at any time. 
(c)	Violations of this section by customers of the cabaret license holder or members of the public not customers shall subject the customers or members of the public to punishment as for a misdemeanor. 
(d)	The cabaret license holder shall be in violation of this section by permitting loitering or upon being notified that loitering is taking place outside such holder's place of business failing to take all reasonable steps to cause the same to cease. 
(Code 1976, § 7-2094; Code 1985, § 6-153; Ord. of 4-16-1981; Ord. of 9-8-1986)
 
Secs. 10-264—10-289. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE VII. CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS 
 
Sec. 10-290. Permit required.
Any person desiring to solicit or canvass upon the public streets, areas or parks or call from house to house in the city for the purpose of raising funds or seeking donations for any religious, charitable or eleemosynary organization shall register with and obtain a written permit from the community affairs department. 
(Code 1976, § 7-3091; Code 1985, § 6-120; Ord. of 6-4-1979)
 
Sec. 10-291. Application for permit.
Any person desiring a permit to solicit or canvass upon the public streets, areas or parks or call from house to house under this article in the city shall file, on a form to be supplied by the city, an application stating the following: 
(1)	Name of applicant. 
(2)	Permanent home address. 
(3)	Social Security number. 
(4)	Name and address of employer or organization represented. 
(5)	Names and addresses of all persons assisting in the soliciting or canvassing or calling from house to house in the city. 
(6)	Nature of any merchandise, wares, goods or any similar items to be sold or offered for sale or given away in conjunction with the soliciting or canvassing or calling from house to house in the city. 
(7)	Proof of nonprofit and tax-exempt status shall be required when registering with the community affairs department. No organization shall be considered a nonprofit organization within the meaning of this subsection except a tax-exempt organization within the meaning of the Internal Revenue Code or the state income tax law as such code and such law are now or hereafter amended. 
(Code 1976, § 7-3092; Code 1985, § 6-121; Ord. of 6-4-1979)
