Unused facilities means facilities located in the rights-of-way which have remained unused for 12 months and for which the utility is unable to provide the city with a plan detailing the procedure by which the utility intends to begin actively using such facilities within the next 12 months, or that it has a potential purchaser or user of the facilities who will be actively using the facilities within the next 12 months, or, that the availability of such facilities is required by the utility to adequately and efficiently operate its facilities. 
Utility means all privately, publicly, or cooperatively owned systems for producing, transmitting, or distributing communication, data, information, telecommunication, cable television, video services, power, electricity, light, heat, gas, oil, crude products, water/sewer, steam, fire and police signals, traffic control devices, and street lighting systems, and housing or conduit for any of the foregoing, which directly or indirectly serve the public or any part thereof. The term "utility" may also be used to refer to the owner, operator, utility, service, contractor or subcontractor, or any agent thereof, of any above-described utility or utility facility. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 1.3, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-120. Penalties.
Every utility convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 per violation. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 8.1, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-121. Compliance.
No person shall be relieved of its obligation to comply with any of the provisions of this article by reason of any failure of the city to enforce compliance. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 10.3, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-122. Appeal of administrative decisions.
All appeals provided for by this chapter and any notification to the city required by this article shall be in writing and sent via certified mail to the director as specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 10.4, 9-9-2019)
 
Secs. 40-123—40-142. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. UTILITY REGISTRATION
 
Sec. 40-143. Required.
Each utility (other than the city gas system) who occupies, uses or has facilities in the rights-of-way at the time of passage of this division, including by lease, sublease or assignment, to operate facilities located in the rights-of-way, unless specifically exempted by state or federal law or this Code, shall file a registration statement with the city public works department. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 2.1, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-144. Procedure.
The registration information provided to the city shall be on a form approved by the city and include, but not be limited to: 
(1)	The name, legal status (i.e., partnership, corporation, etc.), street address, email address, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the utility filing the registration. If the registrant is not the owner of the facility in the right-of-way, the registration shall include the name, street address, email address if applicable, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the owner; 
(2)	The name, street address, email address if applicable and telephone and facsimile numbers of one or more facilities representatives. Current information regarding how to contact the facilities representatives in an emergency shall be provided at the time of filing a registration and shall be updated as necessary to ensure accurate contact information is available to the city at all times; 
(3)	A copy, if requested, of the utility's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the state public service commission or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements; 
(4)	A copy, if requested, of the service agreement, if applicable or other legal instrument that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the right-of-way for the purpose described in the registration. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 2.2, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-145. Incomplete registration.
If a registration is incomplete, the director shall notify the registrant and shall provide a reasonable period of time in which to complete the registration. If a registration is complete, the director shall so notify the utility in writing. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 2.3, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-146. Acceptance of the registration shall not convey title in the rights-of-way.
Acceptance of the registration is only the nonexclusive, limited right to occupy rights-of-way in the city for the limited purposes stated in the acceptance. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from obtaining permits required by city ordinances nor from obtaining appropriate access or pole attachment agreements before using the facilities of others, including the city. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from notifying the city of construction as required herein. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 2.4, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-147. Facilities in place without registration.
Beginning one year after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived, any facilities or part of a facility found in a right-of-way for which registration is required but has not been obtained unless specifically exempted by law, and for which no valid service agreement exists with the city, may be deemed to be a nuisance and an unauthorized use of the rights-of-way. The city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity, including, but not limited to, abating the nuisance; taking possession of the facilities, evicting the utility from the right-of-way; prosecuting the violator; or any other remedy provided by city ordinance or otherwise allowed in law or in equity. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 2.5, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-148. Reservation of regulatory and police powers.
The city by issuing a written approval of registration under this division, does not surrender or to any extent lose, waive, impair, or lessen the lawful powers and rights, which it has now or may be hereafter vested in the city under the constitution and laws of the United States, state and the city Charter, and under the provisions of the city's codified ordinances to regulate the use of the rights-of-way. The utility by applying for and being issued a written permit, is deemed to acknowledge that all lawful powers and rights, regulatory power, or police power, or otherwise as are or the same may be from time to time vested in or reserved to the city, shall be in full force and effect and subject to the exercise thereof by the city at any time. A utility is deemed to acknowledge that its interests are subject to the regulatory and police powers of the city to adopt and enforce general ordinances necessary to the safety and welfare of the public and is deemed to agree to comply with all applicable general laws enacted by the city pursuant to such powers. In particular, all utilities shall comply with city zoning and other land use requirements pertaining to the placement and specifications of facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 10.2, 9-9-2019)
 
Secs. 40-149—40-179. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. CONSTRUCTION PERMITS
 
Sec. 40-180. Required.
It shall be unlawful for any utility, other than the city gas system, to excavate or to construct, install, maintain, renew, remove or relocate facilities in, on, along, over or under the public roads of the city without a utility permit from the public works department in accordance with the terms of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 3.1, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-181. Application procedure.
Utility permits shall be obtained from the director (or such other person as the city manager may designate) upon application made on forms prescribed by the public works department. The written application shall include the following: 
(1)	The name and address of the utility; 
(2)	The nature, extent, and location of any work proposed to be done, along with satisfactory plans as attachments showing in detail the location of the proposed facility or operations as described in the permit application. The plans shall show the size or capacity of facilities to be installed; their relationship to street features such as right-of-way lines, pavement edge, structures, etc., horizontal and vertical clearance to critical elements of the roadway and any other information necessary to evaluate the impact on the street and its operation; 
(3)	The name and address of the person or firm who is to do such work; 
(4)	The name, street address, email address if applicable and telephone and facsimile numbers of one or more facilities representatives; 
(5)	The projected dates for the work to be started and finished; 
(6)	An indemnity bond or other acceptable security in an amount to be set by the city to pay any damages to any part of the city road system or other city property or to any city employee or member of the public caused by activity or work of the utility performed under authority of the permit issued; 
(7)	A copy, if requested, of the registrant's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the state public service commission or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements; and 
(8)	A copy, if requested, of the service agreement, if applicable or other legal instrument that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the right-of-way for the purpose described in the application. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 3.2, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-182. Permit fees.
Fees shall be determined by the director, subject to the approval by resolution of the city council. A fee schedule shall be available at the offices of the director and the city clerk and open for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 3.3, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-183. Issuance of permit.
If the director determines the applicant has satisfied the following requirements, the director may issue a permit whether: 
(1)	Issuing of the approval will be consistent with this division; 
(2)	The applicant has submitted a complete application and has secured all certificates and other authorizations required by law, if applicable, in order to construct facilities in the manner proposed by the applicant; and 
(3)	The impact on safety, visual quality of the streets, traffic flow, and other users of the right-of-way and the difficulty and length of time of the project, construction or maintenance is within acceptable parameters. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 3.4, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-184. Emergency situations.
(a)	Each utility shall, as soon as reasonably practicable, notify the director of any event regarding its facilities which it considers to be an emergency. The utility may proceed to take whatever actions are necessary in order to respond to the emergency. A utility who engages in an emergency excavation shall take all reasonable precautions to avoid or minimize damage to any existing facilities. 
(b)	In the event that the city becomes aware of an emergency regarding utility facilities, the city may attempt to contact the affected utility or facilities representative. The city may take whatever action it deems necessary in order to respond to the emergency, including cut or move any of the wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances, or other parts of the facilities. The city shall not incur any liability to the utility, for such emergency actions, and the cost of such shall be paid by each utility affected by the emergency. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 3.5, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-185. Effective period of permit.
(a)	Each permit shall have a set commencement and expiration date based on information provided in the applicant's permit application. 
(b)	The permit shall remain in place until construction is completed or until its expiration date unless the utility is in default. The director may give written notice of default to a utility if it is determined that a utility has: 
(1)	Violated any provision or requirement of the issuance or acceptance of a permit application or any law of the city, state, or federal government; 
(2)	Attempted to evade any provision or requirement of this division; 
(3)	Practiced any fraud or deceit upon the city; or 
(4)	Made a material misrepresentation or omission of fact in its permit application. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 3.6, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-186. Cancellation for cause.
If a utility fails to cure a default within 20 working days after such notice is provided to the utility by the city, then such default shall be a material breach and the city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity to terminate the permit. If the director decides there is cause or reason to terminate, the following procedure shall be followed: 
(1)	The city shall serve a utility with a written notice of the reason or cause for proposed termination and shall allow a utility a minimum of 15 calendar days to cure its breach. 
(2)	If the utility fails to cure within 15 calendar days, the city may declare the permit terminated. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 3.7, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-187. Expiration of permit.
If work is not begun within six months of the date of issuance, the permit will automatically expire. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 3.8, 9-9-2019)
 
Secs. 40-188—40-212. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 4. MINIMUM STANDARDS
 
Sec. 40-213. Manual adopted.
The Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards Manual, including all references contained therein to codes, rules, regulations, schedules, forms and appendix items, promulgated by the state department of transportation, as may be amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in the division as if fully set forth herein, subject to the amendments and modification contained in this division. A copy of the manual shall be maintained at the offices of the director or his designee and open for public inspection. Any conflicts between the provisions of this division and the manual shall be resolved in favor of the manual. References to state personnel, agencies, and fees shall be interpreted, where required, as meaning the city municipal equivalents. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 4.1, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-214. Protection of traffic and roadway.
Unless specifically in the permit, no utility may occupy the city rights-of-way unless sufficient space is available so that the free flow and safety of traffic and other capacity considerations are not unduly impaired and the installation does not prevent the department from reasonably maintaining the streets, structures, traffic control devices and other appurtenant facilities, and further provided that maintenance and operations of the facilities do not jeopardize the traffic, street structure, other users of the right-of-way or the right-of-way itself. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 4.2, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-215. Grading.
If the grades or lines of any street within the city right-of-way are changed at any time by the city during the term of the permit and this change involves an area in which the utility's facilities are located, then the utility shall, at its own cost and expense and upon the request of the city upon reasonable notice, protect or promptly alter or relocate the facilities, or any part thereof, so as to conform with such new grades or lines. In the event the utility refuses or neglects to so protect, alter, or relocate all or part of the facilities, the city shall have the right to break through, remove, alter, or relocate all or any part of the facilities without any liability to the utility and the utility shall pay to the city the costs incurred in connection with such breaking through, removal, alteration, or relocation. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 4.3, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-216. Installation of poles and other wireholding structures and relocation.
Unless otherwise provided in a valid service agreement, no placement of any pole or wireholding structure of the utility is to be considered a vested interest in the right-of-way, and such poles or structures are to be removed, relocated underground, or modified by the utility at its own expense whenever the city determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. The facilities shall be so located and installed as to cause minimum interference with the rights and convenience of property owners. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 4.4, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-217. Notice; locate request.
As provided in O.C.G.A § 25-9-6 and other applicable state law currently in place or as amended, no utility shall commence, perform, or engage in blasting or in excavating with mechanized excavating facilities unless and until the utility planning the blasting or excavating has given 48-hours' notice by submitting a locate request to the utility protection center, beginning the next working day after such notice is provided, excluding hours during days other than working days. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 4.5, 9-9-2019)
 
Secs. 40-218—40-242. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 5. RESTORATION OF PROPERTY
 
Sec. 40-243. Cost.
Each utility shall be responsible for the cost of repairing any facilities in the rights-of-way and adjoining property or other facilities which it or its facilities damage. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 5.1, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-244. Liability.
A utility shall be liable, at its own cost and expense, to replace, restore or repair, any street, facilities or property or structure thereon, thereunder, thereover or adjacent thereto that may become disturbed or damaged as a result of the construction or installation, operation, upgrade, repair or removal of facilities to a condition as good as or better than its condition before the work performed by the utility that caused such disturbance or damage. If the utility does not commence such replacement or repair after 20 working days following written notice from the city, the city or the owner of the affected structure or property may make such replacement or repair and the utility shall pay the reasonable and actual cost of the same. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 5.2, 9-9-2019)
 
Secs. 40-245—40-266. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 6. INSPECTION
 
Sec. 40-267. Availability.
The utility shall make the construction site available to the director and to all others as authorized by law for inspection at all reasonable times during the execution and upon completion of the construction. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 6.1, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-268. Cessation of work.
At any time, including the time of inspection, the director may order the immediate cessation of any work which poses a serious threat to the health, safety, or welfare of the public, violates any law, or which violates the terms and conditions of the permit or this division or issue an order to correct work which does not conform to the permit or applicable standards, conditions or codes. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 6.2, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-269. Notification.
When the construction under any permit is completed, the utility shall notify the department. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 6.3, 9-9-2019)
 
Secs. 40-270—40-286. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 7. OTHER APPROVALS, PERMITS AND AGREEMENTS
 
Sec. 40-287. Additional permits required.
The utility shall obtain all construction, building or other permits or approvals as according to city ordinance, state or federal law. In addition, a permittee shall comply with all requirements of laws, shall complete work in a way as to not cause any unnecessary or unauthorized obstructions of sidewalks, streets, waterways or railways, and is responsible for all work done in the rights-of-way regardless of who performs the work. No rights-of-way obstruction or excavation may be performed when seasonally prohibited or when conditions are unreasonable for such work, except in the case of an emergency as outlined in section 7 of the Design and Construction Standards for Public Works. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 7.1, 9-9-2019)
 
Secs. 40-288—40-307. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 8. AESTHETIC STANDARDS
 
Sec. 40-308. Authority and scope.
(a)	The provisions of O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92(a)(10) authorize the city to establish reasonable regulations for the installation, construction, maintenance, renewal, removal, and relocation of pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, poles, towers, traffic and other signals, and other equipment, facilities, or appliances in, on, along, over, or under the public roads of the city. Further, 47 USC 253(c) provides that the city has authority to manage its public rights-of-way. 
(b)	The city finds it is in the best interest of the city and its residents and businesses to establish aesthetic requirements and other specifications and reasonable conditions regarding placement of facilities in the public rights-of-way. These requirements, specifications and conditions are adopted in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the residents and businesses of the city and to reasonably manage and protect the public rights-of-way and its uses in the city. 
(c)	The objective of this division is to ensure use of the public rights-of-way: 
(1)	Is consistent with the design, appearance and other features of nearby land uses; 
(2)	Protects the integrity of historic, cultural and scenic resources; and 
(3)	Does not harm residents' quality of life. 
(d)	This division applies to all requests to locate facilities in the public rights-of-way and ongoing use of the public rights-of-way for such facilities. This division is established pursuant to the city Charter and applicable law. This division is administered by the city public works department. 
(e)	Placement or modification of facilities in the public right-of-way shall comply with this division at the time the permit for installation or modification is approved and as amended from time to time. Permittees are required to comply with this Code and applicable law and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.1, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-309. Definitions.
Unless otherwise defined in section 40-119, terms used in this division shall have the meanings given them in O.C.G.A. § 36-66C-2. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.2, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-310. Facilities standards.
(a)	Facilities must be compatible in size, mass, and color to similar facilities in the same zoning area, with a goal of minimizing the physical and visual impact on the area. 
(b)	Facilities in the residential R80, R40, R30, R20, R15, R10, RSL, RD, RA6, RM8, FST, RM12, historical and architecturally significant areas shall be visually and architecturally integrated with the residential R80, R40, R30, R20, R15, R10, RSL, RD, RA6, RM8, FST, RM12, historical/architecturally significant areas and shall not interfere with prominent vistas or significant public view corridors. 
(c)	Facilities must be located in alignment with existing trees or facilities. 
(d)	Facilities must maintain the integrity and character of the neighborhoods and corridors in which the facilities are located. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.4, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-311. Undergrounding.
Should such facilities be required to be installed underground by any current or future comprehensive zoning plan or ordinance, such facilities shall be installed underground in designated areas determined by the mayor and councilmembers so long as placement underground will not materially impact the provision of service, any individual requesting to locate facilities aboveground in designated areas determined by the mayor and councilmembers has the burden to demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that undergrounding will effectively prohibit the provision of the service in question. 
(1)	Light poles and small wireless facilities collocated thereon may be located aboveground in areas of the city where facilities are primarily located underground. 
(2)	The city may: 
a.	Allow collocated small wireless facilities placed aboveground prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived and subject to any applicable pole attachment agreement to remain aboveground; or 
b.	Allow the wireless provider to replace the pole associated with previously collocated small wireless facilities at the same location or propose an alternate location within 50 feet of the prior location, which the wireless provider shall use unless such alternate location imposes technical limits or significant additional costs. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.5, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-312. Historic district.
Facilities installed in the historic district of the city as currently defined or as may be defined in the future shall conform to the provisions of the comprehensive zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.6, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-313. Camouflaging.
Facilities must be designed using camouflaging techniques that make them as unobtrusive as possible if: 
(1)	It is not possible or desirable to match the design and color of facilities with the similar facilities in the same zoning area, as required under section 40-310; or 
(2)	Existing facilities in the area are out of character with a streetscape plan or other aesthetic plan that has been adopted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.7, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-314. Concealment.
Facilities shall incorporate specific concealment elements to minimize visual impacts. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.8, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-315. Preferred locations.
(a)	Unless otherwise provided by applicable law, facilities shall, to the extent that is it reasonable, be placed in the following areas of the city: 
(1)	On utility poles; 
(2)	On street lights; 
These areas are identified in terms of priority, meaning utility poles are the most preferred location, followed by streetlights, etc. 
(b)	Facilities may be located outside areas identified in subsection (a) of this section if: 
(1)	Facilities must be placed outside of the areas identified in subsection (a) of this section in order to maintain existing services, improve services, or new service can only be provided if facilities are placed in areas located outside of those identified in subsection (a) of this section; or 
(2)	The proposed facilities will meet all applicable requirements for the non-preferred location and will complement the character of the zoning area. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.9, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-316. Installation and modification standards.
Installation of new facilities in, on, along, over, or under the public rights-of-way or modification of existing facilities in, on, along, over, or under the public rights-of-way shall: 
(1)	Minimize risks to public safety; 
(2)	Ensure that placement of facilities on existing structures is within the tolerance of those structures; 
(3)	Ensure that installations and modifications are subject to periodic review to minimize the intrusion on the right-of-way; 
(4)	Ensure that the city bears no risk or liability as a result of the installations or modifications; and 
(5)	Ensure that use of the public rights-of-way does not inconvenience the public, interfere with the primary uses of the public rights-of-way, or hinder the ability of the city or other government entities to improve, modify, relocate, abandon, or vacate the right-of-way or any portion thereof, or to cause the improvement, modification, relocation, vacation, or abandonment of facilities in the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.10, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-317. Plans for use.
No facilities shall be placed in, on, along, over, or under the public rights-of-way unless: 
(1)	There are immediate plans to use the proposed facility; or 
(2)	There is a contract with another party that has immediate plans to use the proposed facility. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.11, 9-9-2019)
 
Sec. 40-318. Contact information.
Every facility placed in the public rights-of-way shall at all times display signage that accurately identifies the facility owner and provides the facility owner's unique site number, and also provides a local or toll-free telephone number to contact the facility owner's operations center. 
(Ord. No. 2019-09-01, § 9.12, 9-9-2019)
 
Chapter 42 SUBDIVISIONS
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 42-1. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alley or service drive means a public way which is used primarily for vehicular service access to the back or the side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
Block means a piece or parcel of land entirely surrounded by public streets, other than alleys. 
Building setback line means a line across a lot establishing the minimum open space to be provided between the buildings and the street or a distance from a side or rear property line. 
Corner lot means a lot abutting upon two or more streets at their intersection. 
Crosswalk means a specially paved or marked path for pedestrians crossing a street or road. 
Cul-de-sac means a street having one end open to traffic, the other end being permanently terminated by a vehicular turn-around. 
Double frontage lot means a lot other than a corner lot abutting upon two or more streets. 
Final plat means a drawing showing completely and accurately all legal and engineering information of the subdivision. 
Health department means the Cobb County or Douglas County health department. 
Interior lot means a lot other than a corner lot or double frontage lot. 
Lot means a portion of a subdivision, or any other parcel of land, intended as a unit for transfer of ownership or for development or both. In determining the area and dimensions of a lot, no part of the right-of-way of a street or crosswalk shall be included. 
Master zoning plan means a comprehensive plan, which may consist of several maps, data, and other descriptive matter, for the physical development of the city or any portion thereof, including any amendments, extensions, or additions thereto recommended by the planning and zoning commission, indicating the general location for major streets, parks or other public open spaces, public building sites, routes for public utilities, or other similar information. The master plan shall be based upon and include appropriate studies of the location and extent of present and anticipated population, social and economic resources and problems, and other appropriate information. 
Planning and zoning commission means the city planning and zoning commission. 
Preliminary plat means a drawing which shows the proposed layout of a subdivision with sufficient detail to indicate its workability. This drawing is not to be in final form for recording. 
Street means a dedicated and accepted right-of-way for vehicular traffic, whether designated as highway, thoroughfare, lane, road, boulevard, or otherwise. The following are definitions intended to distinguish between different categories of streets: 
(1)	Collector streets means those streets which are intended to carry traffic from minor streets to and from the major streets and expressways and include the principal entrance streets of a development and streets for circulation within a development. 
(2)	Expressways means high capacity streets from which access to abutting property is prohibited, and which are intersected at specific locations by major and collector streets. 
(3)	Major streets means those streets which are intended primarily for the use of fast or heavy traffic. 
(4)	Marginal access streets means minor streets parallel to and adjacent to major streets or expressways, providing access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
(5)	Minor streets means those streets which are used primarily for access to the abutting properties. 
Subdivider means any person creating a subdivision as defined herein, including any agent of the subdivider. 
Subdivision means any division or redivision of a lot, tract or parcel of land, regardless of how it is to be used, either by platting or by metes and bounds, into two or more lots, building sites, or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale, legacy, or building development, including all division of land involving the dedication, change, or abandonment of a street, site, easement, or other right-of-way for any public use or facility. When appropriate to the content, the term "subdivision" shall relate to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided. The division or sale of land by judicial decree is not defined as a subdivision for the purpose of these regulations. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2001; Code 1985, § 20-1)
 
Sec. 42-2. Scope and applicability of chapter.
(a)	Any person proposing to subdivide land within the city shall submit to the planning and zoning commission and the administrator plats of the proposed subdivision which shall conform to all requirements set forth in this chapter. 
(b)	No subdivider shall proceed with any construction work on a proposed subdivision before obtaining preliminary plat approval from the planning and zoning commission and administrator as certified thereon. 
(c)	No subdivider shall sell or negotiate to sell any lot in a proposed subdivision by reference to or exhibition of or by any other use of a plat of such subdivision, until the final plat has been given approval by the planning and zoning commission and administrator, as certified thereon, and recorded in the office of the city clerk. 
(d)	No land dedicated as a public street shall be accepted, opened, or improved, nor shall any utilities or other facilities be installed thereon, unless such street shall have been accepted or opened as, or otherwise shall have received the legal status of, a public street prior to the adoption of these regulations, or unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a plat approved by the planning and zoning commission or on a plat made and adopted by the planning and zoning commission; provided, however, that the city may locate and construct, or may accept, any other street, if the ordinance or other measure for such approval be first submitted to the planning and zoning commission and administrator for its review and comment. 
(e)	No building permit shall be issued for, and no building or other structure shall be erected on, any lot within the city, unless such lot has access to a street which shall have been accepted or opened as, or otherwise shall have received the legal status of, a public street, or which corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a plat approved by the planning and zoning commission and administrator or a plat made and adopted by same. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2002; Code 1985, § 20-2; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 20)
 
Sec. 42-3. Administration.
(a)	This chapter shall be administered by the zoning administrator. The mayor shall, however, be the designated official to provide final review, certification and signature for all plats which are to be received by the city. The administrator shall make a recommendation to the mayor as requested prior to any required signatures by the mayor. 
(b)	The planning and zoning commission may from time to time supplement this chapter with administrative procedures, to the end that the public may be better informed and that the approval of plats may be expedited with the prior approval of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2072; Code 1985, § 20-3; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 21; Ord. of 8-2-1993, § 4; Ord. of 4-4-1994, § 1)
 
Sec. 42-4. Schedule of fees.
Fees, as provided for by the issuing department, shall be paid to the city for the following: 
(1)	Preliminary plat. 
(2)	Application for final approval. 
(3)	Extension of preliminary plat. 
(4)	Final plat. 
(5)	Certified copy of final plat. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2071; Code 1985, § 20-4)
 
Sec. 42-5. Penalties.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof may be punished as provided in section 1-9. Each day's continuance of a violation shall be considered a separate offense. The owner of any lands or parts thereof, where anything in violation of this chapter shall be placed or shall exist, or any building contractor, or agent of the owner who may have assisted in the commission of any such violation, shall be guilty of a separate offense. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2073; Code 1985, § 20-5)
 
Secs. 42-6—42-28. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. PROCEDURE
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 42-29. Pre-application conference and review.
Prior to the preparation of the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall confer with the city manager, who shall review sketch plans and other information concerning the proposed subdivision to determine its workability, etc. The purpose of this review is to acquaint the subdivider with city plans and policies that might be significant to the proposed subdivision. No fee shall be charged for pre-application review. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2011; Code 1985, § 20-20)
 
Secs. 42-30—42-46. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. PRELIMINARY PLAT
 
Sec. 42-47. Application for approval.
After the procedure described in section 42-2, the subdivider shall submit to the administrator an application for preliminary plat approval, which shall be accompanied with three copies of the preliminary plat and other information as specified in section 42-95(c) and a filing fee, as specified in section 42-4. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2012; Code 1985, § 20-21)
 
Sec. 42-48. Review procedure.
(a)	An application for preliminary plat approval shall be studied by the administrator for compliance with these regulations and other relevant city and county ordinances and regulations. The administrator shall indicate in writing, on the preliminary plat, or by letter to the planning and zoning commission, any changes that are necessary to meet the intent of this division or otherwise to serve the best interests of the community. 
(b)	The planning and zoning commission shall not act on any preliminary plat without holding a hearing thereon. No less than five days before such hearing, the planning and zoning commission shall notify the subdivider of the time and place. 
(c)	Within 30 days after the submission of an application for preliminary plat approval, the planning and zoning commission shall: 
(1)	Issue a certificate of preliminary plat approval; 
(2)	Issue a certificate of preliminary plat approval, subject to any necessary modification, the nature of which shall be indicated on the plat or attached in writing thereto; or 
(3)	Disapprove the preliminary plat, in which case the planning and zoning commission shall so notify the subdivider in writing, stating the reasons therefor. 
(d)	The action of the planning and zoning commission shall be noted on three copies of the preliminary plat. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider and one copy each shall be for the planning and zoning commission's records and the administrator's records. 
(e)	Failure of the planning and zoning commission to act on a preliminary plat within 30 days shall be deemed approval, and thereafter a certificate of preliminary plat approval shall be issued to the subdivider at such subdivider's request. However, if the planning and zoning commission determines that additional time is required to study the preliminary plat, it may take an additional 30 days after the subdivider has been notified. 
(f)	All preliminary plat approvals shall be limited by the following qualifications: 
(1)	Preliminary plat approval is only tentative, pending submission of a final plat; 
(2)	Preliminary plat approval shall be effective and binding upon the planning and zoning commission for a period not to exceed two years, and shall thereafter expire and be null and void except to the extent that work on the subdivision has progressed. However, the subdivider may request in writing that the planning and zoning commission grant an extension of time, and the planning and zoning commission may grant such an extension, subject to payment of fees. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2013; Code 1985, § 20-22; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 17)
 
Sec. 42-49. Waiver for small subdivision.
(a)	The provisions of sections 42-47 and 42-48 may be waived in the case of a subdivision of five lots or less, and the subdivider may submit an application for final plat approval, without submitting a preliminary plat, provided: 
(1)	Each lot in the proposed subdivision abuts an existing public street; 
(2)	The proposed subdivision will not affect any major alterations of utility installations, or other existing or proposed public facilities; and 
(3)	The application for final plat approval meets all the applicable procedural, design, and other requirements of these regulations. 
(b)	A subdivider intending to proceed in accordance with subsection (a) of this section shall first consult with the administrator, supplying sufficient information to satisfy the administrator that the specific conditions will be met. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2014; Code 1985, § 20-23; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Sec. 42-50. Improvements authorized by approval.
(a)	Preliminary plat approval is authorization for the subdivider to undertake preliminary subdivision improvements in accordance with the procedures set forth below. These improvements may be undertaken for the entire subdivision as represented in the preliminary plat, or for a unit division thereof, and shall consist of the clearance and rough grading of streets, installation of monuments and pins as specified in section 42-178(a) and section 42-186, respectively. 
(b)	No building permits will be issued for buildings in the subdivision until it is evident to the administrator and planning and zoning commission that the improvements in the preliminary plat are being fulfilled and will be completed in their entirety. Furthermore, the issuance of building permits will be ceased at any time that the specified improvements do not conform with the standards set forth by the administrator. 
(c)	The subdivider shall enter into a contract with the city for the installation, by the city, of all improvements required by these regulations. 
(d)	On completing the preliminary subdivision improvements prescribed above, the subdivider may submit to the administrator an application for final improvement, which shall consist of: 
(1)	A plat and other information as specified in section 42-95(e), in three copies; and 
(2)	A filing fee as specified in section 42-4. 
(e)	Upon receiving an application for final improvements, the administrator shall inspect the work completed and review the information submitted by the subdivider and shall: 
(1)	Endorse a permit for final improvements on one copy and return same to the subdivision; or 
(2)	Require the subdivider to make such changes as may be necessary to satisfy the provisions of these regulations and other applicable city specifications. 
(f)	Upon receiving a permit for final improvement by the administrator, the subdivider is authorized to proceed with installation of remaining improvements, as specified in section 42-74. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2015; Code 1985, § 20-24; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Secs. 42-51—42-73. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. FINAL PLAT
 
Sec. 42-74. Application for approval.
While the certificate of preliminary plat approval is in effect, the subdivider may submit to the administrator an application for final plat approval, which shall consist of the final plat and other documents, as specified in section 42-96, and a filing fee, as specified in section 42-4. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2016; Code 1985, § 20-25; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Sec. 42-75. Review procedure.
(a)	No final plat shall be acted upon by the planning and zoning commission without holding a hearing thereon. Not less than five days before such hearing, the planning and zoning commission shall notify the subdivider of the time and place of the hearing. 
(b)	Within 30 days after the submission of an application for final plat approval, the planning and zoning commission shall: 
(1)	Approve the final plat; or 
(2)	Disapprove the final plat, in which case the planning and zoning commission shall so notify the subdivider in writing, stating the reasons therefor. 
(c)	The planning and zoning commission shall not approve a final plat until all the requirements of these regulations have been met, and the administrator has certified in writing to the planning and zoning commission that: 
(1)	All the improvements to the subdivision required under these regulations have been completed in accordance with city specifications; or 
(2)	An improvement contract with the city has been provided by the subdivider as prescribed in section 42-50(c). 
(d)	Upon approving a final plat, the planning and zoning commission shall endorse on three copies thereof a certificate of final plat approval. The secretary of the planning and zoning commission shall have one copy recorded in the office of the city clerk. This copy shall be retained in the files of the city clerk, one copy shall be filed in the administrator's files, and one copy shall be given to the subdivider. Additional certified copies of the final plat shall be given to the subdivider at such subdivider's request upon payment of a fee, as prescribed in section 42-4. 
(e)	Failure of the planning and zoning commission to act on a final plat within 30 days shall be deemed approval, and thereafter a certificate of final plat approval shall be issued to the subdivider at such subdivider's request. However, if the planning and zoning commission determines that additional time is required to study the final plat, it may take an additional 30 days after the subdivider has been notified. 
(f)	When all improvements required by these regulations have been completed, the subdivider shall provide the administrator with one complete set of as-built plans and drawings showing the subdivision and its improvements. This set of plans and drawings shall include: 
(1)	Plans of all streets and alleys, showing the planned and actual location of all utility lines; 
(2)	As-built, centerline profiles of all streets; 
(3)	Profiles and invert elevations of all storm and sanitary sewer lines as such improvements shall have actually been installed by the subdivider; and 
(4)	A letter submitted by a registered professional engineer certifying that all sewers, storm drains, curbing and paving have been placed according to grade stages set by such engineer, or such engineer's representatives, in accordance with plans submitted to and approved by the administrator. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2017; Code 1985, § 20-26; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Secs. 42-76—42-93. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. PRELIMINARY AND FINAL PLATS
 
Sec. 42-94. Pre-application plat.
The pre-application plat shall represent the entire area which the subdivider contemplates developing, including possible unit divisions not scheduled for immediate development. The form of the submittal and the extent of degree of precision of same, may be determined by the subdivider. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2021; Code 1985, § 20-30)
 
Sec. 42-95. Preliminary plat specifications.
(a)	The preliminary plat shall represent the entire area which the subdivider contemplates developing including possible unit divisions not scheduled for immediate development. 
(b)	The preliminary plat shall be submitted in five copies, and shall consist of black or blue line prints on white background and such other documents as are necessary to meet the requirements of this section. 
(c)	The preliminary plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn at a scale of not less than 100 feet to one inch. Sheet size shall not exceed 48 by 36 inches; however, a scale of 200 feet to one inch may be used to avoid sheets in excess of these dimensions. In no case shall the sheet size be less than 8.5 by 11 inches. 
(d)	The preliminary plat shall contain the following information: 
(1)	Proposed name of subdivision. 
(2)	Name and address of the owner of record. 
(3)	Name, address and telephone number of the subdivider. 
(4)	Date of survey, date of plat drawing, north arrow and graphic scale, data and space for revision dates. 
(5)	Location (land district, land lot, county and state). 
(6)	Number of lots and typical lot sizes. 
(7)	Location map showing streets, highways, land lot lines, railroads, and other significant features within one mile of the proposed subdivision, drawn at a scale sufficient to show the required information; U.S. Geological Survey maps or city maps may be used as references. 
(8)	Exact boundary lines of the tract indicated by a heavy line giving lengths and bearings; also, the interior angles and intersecting lines will be shown. 
(9)	Unit divisions or stage development in their numerical order, if any, proposed by the subdivider. 
(10)	Contour lines based on sea level data. These shall be drawn at intervals not greater than five feet. Contour lines will be obtained from field survey, photogrammetric methods from aerial photographs, of U.S. Geological Survey maps. (Contour lines from a field survey are strongly suggested for more accuracy in drainage, etc.) The basis for the topographic contour shall be specified, giving description, location and elevation of benchmark. 
(11)	Natural existing features within and about the proposed subdivision, including drainage channels, bodies of water, wooded areas, sudden changes in ground elevations and other significant features. The direction of flow on all watercourses shall be indicated. 
(12)	Cultural features within the proposed subdivision, including street names, right-of-way and pavement widths, easements, bridges, culverts, utility lines and structures, buildings, city and county lines, land lot lines and such other information desired by the subdivider. 
(13)	Proposed subdivision layout including street and alley lines with letter designation, right-of-way widths, lot lines with rough dimensions, lot numbers, block letters, building setback lines with dimensions, sites to be reserved through covenants, easements, dedication or otherwise for public uses or for non-public uses exclusive of family dwellings. 
(14)	Location and results of percolation tests for any lots which will not be served by a public or community sanitary sewage system, as required by the county health department. 
(15)	Location, site plan and other information as required by the health department for all community sewage disposal plants. 
(16)	Certificates as specified in section 42-97(a). 
(e)	An application for final improvements for a subdivision (or for a unit division thereof) shall include the following information, submitted to the administrator in two copies: 
(1)	A plat, drawn to the preliminary plat specifications (subsection (c) of this section), showing the following information: 
a.	Right-of-way lines of all proposed streets, alleys, walkways, easements and other public lands and ways. 
b.	Location and size of all proposed drainage structures and lines including, catch basins, headwalls and extensions thereof. 
c.	Acreage of drainage area and constant used in determining size of structures as approved by the city manager. 
d.	Whenever the property proposed for subdivision contains a stream or drainage way and has any area susceptible to flooding once every 100 years, a grading and drainage plan prepared by a currently state registered professional engineer, shall be submitted with the preliminary plat. The plan shall: 
1.	Contain provisions for erosion control measures which will prevent the deposit on private property, public property and streets, or natural drainage ways of site generated waterborne silt and debris during development, construction or use of property; 
2.	Include a complete hydrologic study to evaluate the total effects the development under review may have upon drainage facilities and systems. It shall include an analysis of stormwater runoff under existing site conditions and under proposed developed site conditions. It shall include a determination of the channel cross-section area required to carry the affected stream at the 100-year flood stage level. It shall show provisions to ensure conformance with the requirements of this section. It shall show the projected 100-year flood level after the development is completed. It shall include the details of providing and maintaining equivalent flow and storage capacity as required by section 42-185(c). 
e.	Location of all proposed sanitary and storm sewer lines and of any easements required therefor, together with sufficient dimensions to locate same on the ground, and; as installed, the location and description of all monuments and pins. 
(2)	Engineering data, as listed below, drawn to a scale not less than a horizontal scale of one inch to 100 feet and a vertical scale of one inch to ten feet. 
a.	Profile of proposed streets showing centerline elevation as existing and finished street elevations and elevations along right-of-way lines on either side of street, exposed rock to be indicated, drawn on standard plan and profile sheet with plan section showing street layout, width, all curve data and drainage required; 
b.	Where sanitary or storm sewers are to be installed, the grate, size of pipe, and location of manholes shall be indicated on the road profiles; 
c.	Profiles covering roadways that are extensions of existing roadways shall include elevations of 50 feet intervals for a minimum distance of 300 feet back of beginning point and forward of ending point, or such additional distance as required by the administrator; and 
d.	All elevations shall be coordinated and tied into U.S. Coast and Geodetic datum and location and elevation of the datum shall be indicated. 
(3)	Copies of all necessary deeds and easements for the streets and other public lands and ways indicated on the plat, properly executed in such forms as shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2022; Code 1985, § 20-31; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Sec. 42-96. Final plat specifications.
(a)	The final plat shall conform to the preliminary plat; it may, however, represent only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which subdivider proposes to develop and record at any one time, provided that such portion conforms to the requirements of these regulations. 
(b)	The submittal shall consist of the original tracing, or a reproducible copy thereof. 
(c)	Final plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn, at a scale of 100 feet to one inch. Sheet size shall not exceed 48 by 36 inches; however, a scale of 200 feet to one inch may be used to avoid sheets in excess of these dimensions. In no case shall the sheet size be less than 8.5 by 11 inches. 
(d)	Final plat shall contain the following information: 
(1)	Name of subdivision. 
(2)	Name and address of the owner of record. 
(3)	Name and address and telephone number of subdivider. 
(4)	Date of survey, date of plat drawing, graphic scale, north arrow with reference of bearings to magnetic or true north, indicating whether bearings were calculated from angles, turned or from compass readings. 
(5)	Location of tract (land district, land lot, county and state) and acreage. 
(6)	If part or all of the tract is a portion of a former subdivision, reference shall be made to the former plat, with indication of the former lots and blocks being resubdivided. 
(7)	Index map, when more than one sheet is required to present plat. 
(8)	Courses and distance to the nearest existing street lines or bench marks or other recognized permanent monuments (not less than three, which shall be accurately described on the plat). 
(9)	Exact boundary lines of the tract, to be indicated by a heavy line, giving distances to the nearest one-tenth foot and angles to the nearest minute. Tract boundaries shall be determined by accurate survey in the field and will be balanced and closed with an error of closure not to exceed one foot in 5,000 feet. The error of closure as calculated by latitude and departures, shall be stated. Surveys shall be coordinated and tied into U.S. Coast and Geodetic Traverse and Triangulation Survey, where same is available. 
(10)	City, county or land lot lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles when such lines traverse or are reasonably close to the subdivision. 
(11)	Exact location, right-of-way widths, and names of all streets and alleys within and immediately adjoining the plat, and the exact location and widths of all crosswalks. 
(12)	Street center lines showing angles of deflection, angles of intersection, radii, length of tangents and arcs, and degree of curvature with basic curve data. 
(13)	Lot lines with dimensions to the nearest one-tenth foot, bearings on all lines, necessary internal angles, arcs and chords and tangents or radii of rounded corners. 
(14)	Building setback lines with dimensions. 
(15)	When lots are located on a curve or when side lot lines are at angles other than 90 degrees, the lot width at the building line shall be shown. 
(16)	Subdivision blocks lettered alphabetically, within each block. Lots or sites numbered in numerical order within same. 
(17)	Location dimensions, and purpose of easements, including slope easements, if required, public service utility right-of-way lines; areas (other than streets) to be reserved, donated or dedicated to public use; sites for other than residential use, with notes stating their purpose and limitations; and of any areas to be reserved by deed covenants for common uses of all property owners. 
(18)	Accurate location, material and description of monuments and markers. Monuments to be placed after final street improvements shall be designated "future." 
(19)	Certificates, as specified in section 42-48(c). 
(e)	The final plat shall be accompanied by statements of deed restrictions and covenants which the subdivider intends to impose on the subdivision. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2023; Code 1985, § 20-32)
 
Sec. 42-97. Plat certificates.
(a)	The following certificates are required for a preliminary plat: 
(1)	Before submitting a preliminary plat, the subdivider shall have had stamped or printed thereon, and signed as follows: 
a.	Preliminary engineering or surveying certificate: 
I hereby certify that this proposed preliminary plat represents a survey completed by me, or under my supervision on ________, 20___, of the property shown and described hereon. 
___________ Registered C. E. No. 
___________ Registered L. S. No.

The undersigned recognizes that all improvements otherwise made or commenced may not be approved by the administrator. 
Subdivider ___________ Date ________ 
Agent ___________ Date ________ 
(2)	Appropriate space shall be provided on the preliminary plat for the following certificate: Certificate for preliminary plat approval: 
All of the requirements of the Austell Subdivision Regulations relative to the preparation and submission of a preliminary plat having been fulfilled, preliminary approval of this plat is hereby granted subject to the further provisions of the regulations. This certificate shall expire ________, 20___.

     Secretary of Austell 
     Planning and Zoning Commission 	

(b)	Upon approval of an application for final improvements, the administrator shall endorse thereon: 
Permit for Final Improvements 
Preliminary subdivision improvements having been made in accordance with the Austell Subdivision Regulations and city specifications, and the attached plat and drawings conforming with the regulations and specifications, permission is hereby granted for installation of final improvements.

(c)	The following certificates are required for a final plat: 
(1)	Before a final plat has been submitted to the administrator, the subdivider shall have had stamped or printed thereon, and signed, substantially as follows:

(2)	Appropriate spaces shall be provided on the final plat for the following certificates:

Date ________ 
b.	Certificate of recording. The form of the certificate of recording in on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2024; Code 1985, § 20-33; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Secs. 42-98—42-122. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE IV. DESIGN PRINCIPLES
 
Sec. 42-123. Suitability of the land.
Land subject to flooding, improper drainage, erosion or otherwise deemed by the planning and zoning commission to be topographically unsuitable for residential use shall not be platted for residential occupancy, nor shall such land be platted for any other uses which may continue such conditions or increase danger to health, safety, life or property, unless steps are taken to eliminate the abovementioned hazards. Such property may be dedicated to the city for use as parks, recreation areas and open spaces subject to the acceptance of the city. On subdividing land of this nature, every effort should be made to utilize these lands as a benefit to the public and property owner. Use as buffer areas, privately maintained recreation areas or public use should all be considered. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2031; Code 1985, § 20-40)
 
Sec. 42-124. Access.
(a)	Every subdivision shall be served by a publicly dedicated street. 
(b)	When land is subdivided into larger parcels than ordinary building lots, such parcels shall be arranged and designed so as to allow for the opening of future streets and to provide access to those areas not presently served by streets. 
(c)	No subdivision shall be so designed as to completely eliminate street access to adjoining parcels of land. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2032; Code 1985, § 20-41)
 
Sec. 42-125. Conformance to master plans.
(a)	All proposed subdivisions shall conform to the master zoning plan, thoroughfare plan and all other portions of the city master plan adopted at the time of plat submission to the planning and zoning commission. 
(b)	In subdivisions related to or affecting any state or federal highway, the written approval of the state department of transportation shall be required by the planning and zoning commission. 
(c)	Where features of the master plan other than minor streets and collector streets, such as school sites, parks, collector streets, major streets and other public spaces are located in whole or in part in a proposed subdivision or when these features have not been anticipated by the master plan, but are considered essential by the planning and zoning commission, such features shall be either dedicated or reserved by the subdivider. Whenever such reserved land, or any portion thereof is not acquired, optioned or condemned by the appropriate public agency within a one-year period from the date of recording the subdivision, the subdivider may claim the original reservation, or portion thereof, and cause it to be subdivided in a manner suitable to the subdivider, subject to the provisions of these regulations. 
(d)	Whenever a plat proposes the dedication of land to a public use that the planning and zoning commission finds not required or suitable for public use, the planning and zoning commission shall refuse to approve the plat, and shall notify the city of the reasons for such action. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2033; Code 1985, § 20-42)
 
Sec. 42-126. Non-subdivision developments.
The standards and requirements of these regulations may be modified in the case of a plan for a development which is not to be subdivided into customary lots, blocks and streets, when in the judgment of the planning and zoning commission and the administrator, this plan will provide adequate open spaces and improvements for the circulation, recreation, light, aid and service needs of the tract when fully developed and populated and which also provides such covenants and other means as will ensure conformity to and achievement of the plan. Plans for such development shall be submitted to and approved by the planning and zoning commission and administrator whether or not a plat is to be recorded, and no building permits shall be issued until such approval has been given. Failure of the planning and zoning commission to act on such a plan within 30 days shall be deemed approval and thereafter a certificate of approval shall be issued to the developer at the developer's request. However, if the planning and zoning commission determines that additional time is required to study the plan, it may order an extension of time. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2035; Code 1985, § 20-44; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Secs. 42-127—42-150. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE V. DESIGN STANDARDS
 
Sec. 42-151. Application of article.
The design standards set forth in this article shall be observed in all plats which are required to be approved by the planning and zoning commission, except that standards for improvements shall be applicable only to those plats for which improvements or improvement plans are required as a condition of plat approval. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2041; Code 1985, § 20-50)
 
Sec. 42-152. Streets.
(a)	The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographic conditions, to public convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the lands to be served by such streets. 
(b)	The arrangement of streets in a subdivision shall either: 
(1)	Provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing streets in surrounding areas at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required minimum; 
(2)	Conform to a plan, approved or adopted by the planning and zoning commission to meet a particular situation where topographic or other conditions made continuance or conformance to existing streets impractical. 
(c)	Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. 
(d)	The planning and zoning commission may require the subdivider to provide a temporary vehicular turnaround within the right-of-way at the end of any dead-end street other than a cul-de-sac, when the commission finds this necessary for safe traffic circulation. 
(e)	Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed major street, the planning and zoning commission may require marginal access streets, double frontage lots with screen planting contained in a non-access reservation along the rear property lines, deep lots with rear service drives, or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to provide separation of through and local traffic. 
(f)	Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way or expressway right-of-way, the planning and zoning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. 
(g)	Except as otherwise specified by the planning and zoning commission, all streets shall have the following minimum right-of-way: 
(1)	Major streets: 90 to 100 feet of right-of-way, as shown on the major thoroughfare plan or as determined by the administrator. Generally, 100 feet shall be required. 
(2)	Collector streets: 60 to 90 feet of right-of-way, as shown on the major thoroughfare plan or as determined by the administrator. Generally, 60 feet will be required. 
(3)	Minor residential streets and marginal access streets, single-family and low density multiple family: 50 feet. 
(4)	Cul-de-sac (turn around radius), residential: 60 feet, commercial and industrial: 75 feet. 
(5)	Alleys and service ways: 20 feet. 
(h)	Right-of-way requirements in excess of 60 feet shall be dedicated or reserved for acquisition by the appropriate public body, subject to the provisions of section 42-125. 
(i)	Street paving widths shall be not less than as follows, measured from back of curb to back of curb, unless otherwise specified by the planning and zoning commission: 
(1)	Major streets (100-foot right-of-way): 81 feet; pavement widths for other size rights-of-way as specified by the city. 
(2)	Collector streets (60-foot right-of-way): 39 feet; pavement width for other size rights-of-way as specified by the city. 
(3)	Minor and marginal access streets (50-foot right-of-way): 30 feet. 
(4)	Cul-de-sac turn arounds: 
a.	Residential (diameter): 60 feet. 
b.	Commercial and industrial (diameter): 100 feet. 
(5)	Alleys or service drive: 20 feet. 
(j)	Grades shall be as follows: 
(1)	Major streets: As specified by state highway department, otherwise four percent maximum. 
(2)	Collector streets: Eight percent maximum. 
(3)	Minor and marginal access streets: 12 percent maximum. 
(4)	No street grade shall be less than one percent. 
(k)	Alignment. 
(1)	Vertical: 
a.	Major street profile grades, unless otherwise specified by the state department of transportation, shall be connected by vertical curves of a minimum length equal in feet to 25 times the algebraic difference between the rates of grade expressed in feet per 100; for all other streets not less than 20 times. 
b.	In approaches to intersections, there shall be a suitable leveling of the street at a grade not exceeding three percent and for a distance of not less than 50 feet from the nearest line of the intersecting street. 
(2)	Horizontal: 
a.	A minimum radii of centerline curvature will be: 
1.	Major streets: As specified by state highway department; otherwise: 1,260 feet. 
2.	Collector streets: 500 feet. 
3.	Minor residential and marginal access streets: 200 feet. 
b.	Minimum horizontal visibility measured on centerline shall be: 
1.	Major streets: As specified by state highway department; otherwise: 500 feet. 
2.	Collector streets: 300 feet. 
3.	Minor residential and marginal access streets: 200 feet. 
(l)	Street intersections. 
(1)	Intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible, and no intersection shall be at an angle less than 60 degrees. 
(2)	Curb radius at street intersection shall be at least 15 feet. Where the angle of street intersection is less than 90 degrees, the planning and zoning commission may require a greater radius. 
(3)	Right-of-way lines at intersections shall assume a radius or chord compatible with curb radius. 
(4)	Intersections with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall not be permitted. 
(m)	Cul-de-sac streets shall be designed so that the maximum length shall not exceed 800 feet, nor shall the paved turn-around at the end be less than 60 feet in diameter for residential streets, or less than 100 feet for commercial and industrial streets. 
(n)	Alleys or service drives may be required at rear of all lots to be used for multiple-family, commercial or industrial developments, but shall not otherwise be provided except where the subdivider produces evidence of need satisfactory to the planning and zoning commission. 
(o)	Half streets shall be prohibited. 
(p)	Reserve strips controlling access to streets, alleys (or public grounds) shall not be permitted unless their control is definitely placed with the city under conditions approved by the planning and zoning commission. 
(q)	Entrance and exit points. Except in districts zoned for single-family and duplex housing units, curb breaks shall not be more than 30 feet in width; less than 25 feet in width; nor shall there be less than 50 feet from the closest sides of any two driveway curb lines. Curb breaks in all zones shall be located at least 25 feet from the nearest intersection of two curb lines as measured along one of the curb lines. Business establishments on contiguous lots are encouraged to consolidate entrance and exit points. Suitable provisions, including a five-foot wide planted buffer strip between the right-of-way and parking area shall be made to prevent entrance or exit from other than at designated entrance or exit points. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2042; Code 1985, § 20-51; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Sec. 42-153. Blocks.
(a)	The lengths, widths, and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to: 
(1)	Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the needs of the type of use contemplated. 
(2)	Any provision of chapter 48 on requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions. 
(3)	Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic. 
(4)	Limitations and opportunities of topography. 
(b)	In general, residential blocks shall not be greater than 1,200 feet in length, or less than 600 feet in length. In blocks over 1,000 feet long, the planning and zoning commission may, when existing or proposed public gathering places so justify, require public crosswalks across the block. 
(c)	Residential blocks shall be wide enough to provide two tiers of lots of at least minimum depth, except where fronting on major streets or prevented by topographic conditions or size of the property, in which case the planning and zoning commission may require or approve a single of tier of lots. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2043; Code 1985, § 20-52)
 
Sec. 42-154. Lots.
(a)	Insofar as practical, side lot lines shall be perpendicular or radial to street lines. Each lot shall abut upon a public street. 
(b)	The size, shape and orientation of every lot shall be subject to approval of the planning and zoning commission and administrator for the type of development and use contemplated. No lot shall be more than three times as deep as it is wide at the building setback line. 
(c)	Double frontage lots, unless required by the planning and zoning commission, shall be prohibited, except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or other incompatible uses; or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography, orientation, and property size. A planting screen reservation at least ten feet wide, and across which there shall be no right of access, shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery or other incompatible use. 
(d)	Corner lots shall have extra width to permit appropriate building setback from and orientation to both streets. 
(e)	Lot remnants (parcels of land below minimum lot area or width left over after subdividing) shall be prohibited. Such remnant areas shall be added to adjacent lots, rather than remain as unusable parcels or shall be dedicated to the city (subject to city acceptance) for public use as parks and open spaces. 
(f)	In subdividing land adjacent to or surrounding an existing or proposed lake, the lot lines of lots abutting the lake shall be drawn to the centerline of the lake. Such requirement may be waived upon approval by the planning and zoning commission of an alternate method for ensuring proper maintenance of the lake and any recreational operations to be provided thereon. 
(g)	In subdivisions with lots less than one acre in size or subdivisions with more than 20 lots contained within, the planning and zoning commission may require the subdivider to set aside an area within the subdivision for a recreational area. This will be dependent upon the location of the subdivision and on the location of nearby existing recreational areas. In all other subdivisions, the planning and zoning commission shall recommend to the developer the need for recreational areas in the plans for development. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2044; Code 1985, § 20-53; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Secs. 42-155—42-176. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE VI. REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS
 
Sec. 42-177. Application of article.
Every subdivider shall be required to install or to have installed by the appropriate public agency or utility, the physical subdivision improvements specified in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2051; Code 1985, § 20-60)
 
Sec. 42-178. Street grading.
(a)	All street rights-of-way shall be cleared and graded at the expense of the subdivider and in accordance with the standards of the city. 
(b)	Finished grades shall be at levels approved by the administrator. 
(c)	When property adjacent to a proposed street is not owned by the subdivider, he shall obtain the necessary easements for sloping banks, before submitting application for final improvements. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2052; Code 1985, § 20-61; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Sec. 42-179. Street paving.
Street pavements shall be installed at the subdivider's expense and in accordance with the standards of the city and shall be paved to at least the minimum widths specified in section 42-152. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2053; Code 1985, § 20-62)
 
Sec. 42-180. Standards for new streets.
(a)	All new streets shall be curbed and guttered with two-foot by nine-inch by six-inch "el" back curbs set on proper slope and elevation to ensure drainage, set by the developer. An expansion joint of one-half-inch premolded bitumastic expansion joint material shall be provided at all radius points and at intervals not to exceed 50 feet in the remainder of the curb and gutter. 
(b)	Intersection radii shall be as follows: 
Street Types	Radii
(feet)	Length Storage Lane
(feet)	Taper
(feet)
Arterial 	40 	150 	50 
Major collector 	40 	150 	50 
Minor collector 	25 	100 	50 
Local 	25 	100 	50 
Alleys 	To be designated by administrator 

(c)	Special curbing design shall be individually approved by administrator. Inferior workmanship or construction methods resulting in unsightly curb and gutter will be cause of rejection of the finished work. 
(d)	When a subdivision is being developed fronting on a city street, curb and gutter on the city street shall be provided as follows: 
Street Type	Location
(feet)
Arterial 	24 
Major collector 	18 
Minor collector 	12—18 
Local street 	12 

Distance is measured from center line of street to face of curb. All curbing shall be backfilled and landscaped. 
(e)	Residential streets shall be built to the following standards: 
(1)	Base shall be eight inches of crusher run placed and compacted. After compaction, three inches of asphaltic concrete plant mix type to be installed and compacted. All streets will be bored for testing. 
(2)	Paving widths shall be built as follows: 
Street Type	Minimum R/W
(feet)	Minimum Paving Widths
Arterial 	100—200 	As may be required 
Major collector 	80—100 	12 ft. lanes and curb and gutter 
Minor collector 	60 	24 ft. and curb and gutter 
Local 	50 	22 ft. and curb and gutter* 
Rural local 	60 	24 ft. no curb 

*On local subdivision streets a minimum paving width of 20 feet, plus curb and gutter may be allowed by the planning and zoning commission. 
(Code 1985, § 20-62.1; Mo. of 5-6-1985; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Sec. 42-181. Curbs and gutters.
Curbs and gutters shall be installed on all streets, except where noted herein. Installation shall be at the subdivider's expense and in accordance with the standards of the city. Where sidewalks are required, curbs may be of a straight or standard construction, on one or both sides of street as applicable. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2054; Code 1985, § 20-63)
 
Sec. 42-182. Sidewalks.
(a)	Sidewalks will be required: 
(1)	Adjoining all major streets; 
(2)	On at least one side of all collector streets; 
(3)	Adjoining any street providing access to and within 1,000 feet of a school; 
(4)	In all areas zoned commercially (to be built as part of the commercial structure); and 
(5)	Whenever the planning and zoning commission determines the public safety necessitates their construction.
