When sidewalks are installed, they shall be at the expense of the subdivider, with a minimum width of five feet and in accordance with the standards of the city. In commercial areas, sidewalks shall be a minimum of ten feet in width, unless determined otherwise by the planning and zoning commission. 
(b)	Driveway aprons over sidewalks shall be paved in accordance with the standards of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2055; Code 1985, § 20-64)
 
Sec. 42-183. Water supply.
(a)	The installation of water mains and of a connection to each lot shall be accomplished prior to the paving of the street. 
(b)	The installation of water mains, including all materials, shall be performed by the subdivider under city standards. 
(c)	The standard meter charge for each house will be at the expense of the subdivider. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2056; Code 1985, § 20-65)
 
Sec. 42-184. Sanitary sewage disposal.
(a)	When, in the written opinion of the administrator, access is available to the subdivision, the subdivider shall provide sanitary sewer services to each lot therein, in accordance with the standards of the city. 
(b)	When, in the written opinion of the administrator, a public sanitary sewer is not accessible, community sewage disposal system may be provided, when in compliance with the standards of the city and the appropriate health department. 
(c)	Whenever a sanitary sewer is required to be installed within the right-of-way of a street, the street shall not be paved without such sewer first being installed. 
(d)	Whenever the installation of a sanitary sewer will require an easement, no building permit shall be issued for any lot affected by such easement until that portion of the sanitary sewer has been installed. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2057; Code 1985, § 20-66; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Sec. 42-185. Storm drainage.
(a)	Every subdivision shall be served by appropriate storm drainage facilities, these facilities shall be designed in accordance with the standards of the city. 
(b)	All storm drainage facilities shall be designed to serve the entire drainage area in which they are located. 
(c)	In those cases where a hydrologic study is required and if the required hydrologic study reveals that filling or grading within a floodplain drainage easement would overload the capacity of the channel downstream or increase flood stages upstream, preliminary plat approval shall be denied, unless equivalent flow and storage capacity is replaced and maintained by the owner within the floodplain drainage easement. In addition, if the required hydrologic study reveals that development or building would generate an increase of stormwater runoff in excess of one cubic foot per second during a 100-year frequency storm, preliminary plat approval shall be denied unless improvements are made to provide storage on the site of the increased runoff and a method for regulating the flow in order that the rate of runoff from the site will not be increased. 
(d)	Storm drainage facilities shall be so arranged as to transport water to existing storm drains, or other facilities, as approved by the administrator. 
(e)	When drainage facilities must parallel streets or are located within the front or side setbacks, stormwater drainage pipes, catch basins, and manholes shall be required. Whenever drainage facilities are located a minimum of 30 feet to the rear of a building, drainage ditches may be used. Such ditches shall be designed so as to retain natural design characteristics, and so as not to present a hazard to life or property. All ditches must be in accordance with the standards of the city. 
(f)	Whenever it is necessary for a storm drain to be crossed by a street or driveway, the subdivider shall provide and install the pipe and any other structures necessary in accordance with the standards of the city. 
(g)	Whenever a storm drain is to be extended through lots proposed to be platted for development, the subdivider shall provide and install drains designed in accordance with the standards of the city, such drains to extend from the street drains to a point 30 feet to the rear of the building. 
(h)	Whenever a storm drain is to be extended through land that is not proposed for development, a drainage ditch may be provided. However, in such case the plat shall be so marked and an easement shown thereon indicating that no building or driveway shall be built over or within ten feet of such ditch. 
(i)	Improvements, such as widening, deepening, relocating, clearing, protecting or otherwise improving existing lakes and shore lines, stream beds and other watercourses, for the control of mosquitoes and public health nuisances, shall be carried out by the developer in accordance with standards and requirements of the appropriate health department. 
(j)	Any water impoundment structure shall be constructed so as to minimize the mosquito breeding and other nuisance hazards and shall be built in accordance with the standards of the city and with approval of the administrator and the appropriate health department. 
(k)	No land subject to flooding as determined by the administrator shall be improved for residential or other use which may be endangered by floods, unless such land shall be raised above the potential flood level to the extent specified by the administrator and health department, and in accordance with the required hydrologic study including any federal floodplains study or requirements for federal flood insurance. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2058; Code 1985, § 20-67; Ord. of 7-12-1993, § 19)
 
Sec. 42-186. Monuments and pins.
Iron pins at least one-half inch by 24 inches shall be placed at all property corners and driven so as to set four inches above the finished grade. Iron pins shall also be set at the intersection of any property line with a land lot line, and, if not already set, land lot corners shall be set in a like manner. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2059; Code 1985, § 20-68)
 
Sec. 42-187. Fire hydrants.
(a)	Fire hydrants in the city in all new developments shall be located on city rights-of-way every 500 feet. 
(b)	On all existing streets, fire hydrants shall be added as necessary from time to time so that they shall be located every 500 feet on city rights-of-way as approved by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2060; Code 1985, § 20-69; Ord. of 1-7-1985)
 
Sec. 42-188. Street trees.
Street trees and other shrubbery that may be retained or planted shall be retained or planted so as not to obstruct required visibility utility along the street. Any trees or shrubs planted within the right-of-way must be approved by the public works director. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2061; Code 1985, § 20-70)
 
Chapter 44 TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES 
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 44-1. Adoption of state uniform rules of the road.
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370, the provisions of O.C.G.A. ch. 40-6, known as the uniform rules of the road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1, to the extent applicable within municipalities, are adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited in this chapter. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provisions of such rules shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1976, § 8-1001; Code 1985, § 21-1; Ord. of 9-10-1979, § 2)
 
Sec. 44-2. Temporary traffic regulations.
In cases where traffic upon the streets of the city may become congested upon occasions of parades, at theaters and other public assemblages where large numbers of vehicles are assembled, the police may make temporary rules regulating the traffic in these congested districts, and it is unlawful for any person, after being warned of the temporary traffic regulations, to violate them. 
(Code 1976, § 8-1002; Code 1985, § 21-3)
 
Sec. 44-3. Traffic signs, signals and markings.
(a)	Upon written approval of the city, the police department is authorized: 
(1)	To designate and maintain, by appropriate traffic-control signs and devices, including speed breakers, marks or lines erected at intersections or upon the surface of roadways, crosswalks at intersections where there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as deemed necessary; 
(2)	To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as deemed necessary for the protection of pedestrians; 
(3)	To mark lanes for traffic; 
(4)	To designate and maintain by appropriate traffic-control signs and devices, speed, parking or other traffic-control zones in the city. 
(b)	All traffic-control signs, signals, devices and markings shall conform to specifications in the Manual on Uniform Traffic-Control Devices adopted by the state department of transportation. All signs and signals required hereunder for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic-control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this chapter shall be official traffic-control devices of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 8-1003; Code 1985, § 21-4)
 
Sec. 44-4. U-turns prohibited.
No operator of any vehicle shall make a U-turn upon any of the streets of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 8-1005; Code 1985, § 21-5)
 
Sec. 44-5. Vehicle load cover required.
(a)	It shall be a violation of this Code to operate any vehicle on the public streets and roads of this city unless the vehicle is constructed or loaded or covered so as to prevent any of its load from dropping, escaping or shifting in such a manner as to create a safety hazard or in such a manner so as to litter the streets and roads of the city, provided that this shall not prohibit the necessary spreading of any substance in public road maintenance or construction operation. 
(b)	No person shall operate or load for operation on any public road or street of this city any vehicle with any load unless the load and any covering thereon is securely fastened so as to prevent the covering or load from coming loose, detached or in any manner becoming a hazard to other users of the public road or street, or littering the public roads or streets. 
(Code 1976, § 8-1008; Code 1985, § 21-6)
 
Sec. 44-6. Obstructing street crossings by railroad train.
It is unlawful for any railroad conductor or other person in charge of a railroad engine, train or car to cause any public crossing to be blocked or otherwise obstruct travel at the crossing by such engine, train or car longer than ten minutes. 
(Code 1976, § 7-3051; Code 1985, § 21-7)
 
Secs. 44-7—44-30. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. PARKING
 
Sec. 44-31. Prohibition of parking.
(a)	No vehicle shall remain parked on any street within the city for a longer period than 12 hours. This shall not conflict with time limit parking in restricted zones, as approved by the city. 
(b)	Notwithstanding the above, no vehicle shall be allowed to park at any time on the following streets in the area indicated: 
Street Name	From	To
Millstone Court 	East cul-de-sac 	West cul-de-sac 
Venesa Circle 	City limits 	Lisa Lane 
Lisa Lane 	Venesa Circle 	Venesa Circle 
Matt Drive 	Venesa Circle 	Lisa Lane 
Pontiac Circle 	Maxham Road 	Maxham Road 
Cochise Circle 	Hiwatha Lane 	Hiwatha Lane 
Hiwatha Lane 	Pontiac Circle 	Pontiac Circle 
Miller Road 	Humphries Hill Road 	Dead-end 

(Code 1976, § 8-1006; Code 1985, § 21-12; Ord. of 3-6-1989)
 
Sec. 44-32. Parking of business vehicles.
(a)	Business vehicles shall be defined as school, commercial and church buses, trailers, tandem rigs and any other vehicles driven for hire, or utilized in conducting business affairs, such as transportation of equipment, freight, goods, or individuals. As used in this section, vehicles include any trailer, boat, or other device or vehicle being towed by the vehicle. 
(b)	Business vehicles under 10,000 pounds gross volume weight shall be allowed to park on property zoned residential in a carport or garage or in a side or rear yard but not closer than 20 feet to a side or rear yard line of the property, but may not park in the front yard thereof. Business vehicles weighing or exceeding 10,000 pounds gross volume weight shall be allowed to park on property zoned residential during daylight hours on weekdays, but not overnight or on Saturdays or Sundays, in a carport or garage or in a side or rear yard, but not closer than 20 feet to a side or rear yard line of the property and not at all in the front yard. Daylight hours shall mean 30 minutes after dawn to 30 minutes before sunset. 
(c)	Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, school buses may be parked in any school property parking lot at any time, and church buses may be parked in any church property parking lot at any time. 
(d)	It shall further be unlawful for any person, to park any of the vehicles described in this section on the streets within the business section of the city between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., on any week day, and it is unlawful to park same during any other time on the streets within the business section of the city in such a way as to obstruct the normal flow of traffic over such streets or to otherwise create a hazard. 
(Code 1976, §§ 8-2001, 8-2002; Code 1985, §§ 21-13, 21-14; Ord. of 9-14-1987)
 
Sec. 44-33. Temporary parking for deliveries.
There is excluded from the prohibitions contained within this chapter, the temporary parking of any vehicle on the business or residential streets of the city for the purpose of making deliveries therefrom to business houses or residences within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 8-2003; Code 1985, § 21-15)
 
Sec. 44-34. Parking on state highway right-of-way.
It is unlawful for any vehicle to be parked on the right-of-way of any state highway within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 8-2005; Code 1985, § 21-16)
 
Sec. 44-35. Parking on the city rights-of-way.
It is unlawful for any vehicle to park on any right-of-way within the city boundaries, except as follows: 
(1)	Business district. If a vehicle becomes inoperative due to an accident or mechanical problems, the owner may have 24 hours to remove the vehicle from the right-of-way. 
(2)	Residential areas. It is unlawful to park on the right-of-way of any residential area without a special parking permit issued by the city for social occasions except that parking may be permitted for a period not to exceed four hours for social functions (i.e., parties, reunions, funerals, etc.) but such permits shall limit parking to one side of the right-of-way only. 
(3)	Opposite sides of right-of-way. At no time shall multiple cars park opposite from one another on opposite rights-of-way. 
(Code 1985, § 18-7.7)
 
Secs. 44-36—44-49. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. TRAFFIC ENFORCEMENT CONTROL DEVICES
 
Sec. 44-50. Automated traffic enforcement control devices.
(a)	Adoption by reference. O.C.G.A. § 40-14-18 is hereby adopted into the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited herein. 
(b)	Violations. Drivers exceeding school zone speeds in excess of ten miles per hour over the posted speed during applicable time periods may cited utilizing automated traffic enforcement safety devices under and according to this section as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 40-14-18. Printed notice and/or citations shall notify drivers that they have been cited under this section as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 40-14-18. Late fees shall refer to subsection (d) of this section. 
(c)	Penalties. A civil monetary penalty will be assessed against drivers as set forth in this section as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 40-14-18, currently $75.00 for the first violation and $125.00 for additional violations, plus late fees as described in this article. 
(d)	Late fees. Pursuant to this section as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 40-14-18(i)(3), the following late fees shall be added to any civil monetary penalty not timely paid: 
(1)	30 days after the due date printed on the second notice$25.00
(2)	90 days after the due date printed on the second notice 25.00
Total late fees shall not exceed $50.00 per violation and shall be printed on all notices. 
(e)	Court. Contested notices of violation shall be referred to the municipal court for adjudication in accordance with this section as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 40-14-18. 
(f)	Out of state drivers. Service on out of state drivers who fail to pay upon standard notices may be affected as set forth by O.C.G.A. § 40-12-2. In the case of nonresident drivers beyond the reach of registration holds as set forth in § 40-14-18, the city may designate a private collection company or companies to assist in the recovery of civil monetary penalties and late fees. 
(g)	Repeal and severability. Existing ordinances or parts of ordinances inconsistent with the provisions of this article are hereby repealed. In the event any provision of this article is found to be unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction it shall be severed, and the remainder shall remain in force. 
(Ord. of 2-1-2021, § 21-43)
 
Chapter 46 UTILITIES 
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 46-1. Public works director to administer chapter.
This chapter shall be administered by the public works director, who is the director of both the water and sewer and street and sanitation departments. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1001; Code 1985, § 14-1; Ord. of 11-7-1988; Ord. of 7-12-1993)
 
Sec. 46-2. Patron conduct in utility administrative offices restricted.
Persons visiting the administrative office of any city utility shall refrain from shouting, cursing or otherwise exhibiting disorderly conduct. Persons who violate this section will be immediately removed by city law enforcement personnel and may be charged with disorderly conduct and such other violations of this Code as may be applicable in the circumstances. 
 
Sec. 46-3. Connection fees.
(a)	Upon the application by any customer for new water tap and service connection, the applicant shall pay the fee in an amount determined by the issuing department as specified for the size of the water tap as required by the building code. All one-inch and larger meters will be considered commercial. The contractor will supply the meter, lines, valves and other fitting for installation of meters over two inches. Backflow prevention units are installed on meters up to one inch. The customer is responsible for installation of backflow prevention units on installation of meters over one inch. 
(b)	In addition to the above fees, mobile home parks and apartment buildings shall pay an amount as determined by the issuing department per mobile home pad or an amount as determined by the issuing department per apartment unit. 
(c)	The charge for a residential sanitary sewer tap shall be an amount as determined by the issuing department. Commercial sanitary sewer tap fees are calculated in accordance with the Guidelines for Administering Regional System Development Fees, current edition. 
(d)	The foregoing rates shall not limit the city to charge more to cover special circumstances caused by the volume of service for special difficulties in connection and charges therefor shall reflect the cost incurred by the city for such special circumstances or difficulties in connection. 
(e)	The customer shall bear all expenses for the purchase and installation of meters, lines, valves, and other fittings from tap to structure. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2008; Code 1985, § 14-3; Ord. of 9-10-1979; Ord. of 11-5-1984(2); Ord. of 2-2-1987; Ord. of 7-3-2006(2))
 
Sec. 46-4. Payment of utility charges; lien for city utility service costs.
(a)	Due dates and payment. All charges for natural gas, water and sewerage services, as established by the city and the gas board rendered within and outside the boundaries of the city shall be due and payable as provided in the rules and regulations of the city and the board. Failure to receive notice of the amount due shall in no way relieve the customer from making payment as therein provided. Should any customer receiving municipal utility service fail to pay any sums finally determined due, such service may be discontinued until such sums together with all penalties are paid in full; provided, nondelinquent tenants must be provided with such services as individuals upon proper application and payment for installation of meters. 
(b)	Notice of lien. If default occurs in the payment of such sums as may be due by a customer who is either the owner of the property served or the agent of such owner, then notice shall be given to the owner of such property so served, as shown on the latest available ad valorem tax digest of the county, that the property so served is subject to a lien for such utility charges in the nature of a tax lien for special assessments. 
(c)	Executions. Should a customer who is either the owner of property served or the agent of such owner not pay the municipal utility charges thereon, and the payment thereof shall be in default for a period of 90 days after the first date due, then the city shall be entitled and authorized to have an execution issue, which execution shall issue in the name of the city in rem against the property described and shown on the ad valorem tax digest, and in personam against the owner of the property and shall be for the principal amount due, plus interest at the rate of seven percent per annum from the first date due, and the sum of $1.50 cost for the issuance of the execution. Executions under this section are subject to the following: 
(1)	Subsequent costs thereon shall be the same as those now or hereafter allowed by law to the sheriff for the performance of similar services. Such execution for municipal utility charges shall be delivered to the marshal of the city, and subsequent proceedings had thereon shall be as provided by law for the enforcement of executions for taxes. 
(2)	All executions issued pursuant hereto, shall issue against the owner and the property served, and shall be recorded on the general execution docket in the office of the clerk of superior court in the county where the land lies and the same shall constitute a lien against the property from the time the charge was first due, which lien shall rank on a parity with and be of equal dignity to other liens for special tax assessments. 
(d)	Exception. Anything herein to the contrary notwithstanding, no lien is created and no execution is authorized against property where the owner or the owner's agent is not the customer, such as rental property where a tenant is the customer. 
(Code 1976, §§ 6-4001—6-4004; Code 1985, §§ 14-4—14-7; Ord. of 11-6-1978)
 
Secs. 46-5—46-26. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. WATER
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 46-27. Water service business hours.
All communications, transactions and duties related to commencement, reinstatement or termination of water service shall be conducted between the hours of 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday of each week during the year except on holidays. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2016; Code 1985, § 14-20)
 
Sec. 46-28. Director may establish rules and regulations.
The public works director may establish other rules and regulations consistent with this Code and approved by the city for connection procedures, water meter locations and inspections. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2017; Code 1985, § 14-21)
 
Sec. 46-29. Water service application.
Water shall not be connected to any premises without application having first been made and approved by the public works director or his designee. Every water service application made must be by the owner of the property to be benefited or by any authorized agent. The application must be made on a form prescribed by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2001; Code 1985, § 14-22; Ord. of 7-3-2006(2))
 
Sec. 46-30. Service deposits.
(a)	Each new or reinstated residential customer must pay a deposit in an amount as determined by the issuing department prior to the connection of water service. Each new or reinstated commercial customer shall pay a deposit equal to a typical 45 day bill for that type of business, but not less than the amount as determined by the issuing department prior to the connection of water service. The deposit may be waived if the customer can provide a two year history from another utility. 
(b)	Water meter deposits shall be refundable on application any time after two years provided the account has not been billed a penalty within the past 24 months next preceding the application. 
(c)	Additional or different water accounts for existing customers with an account at least two years of age shall not require deposits when their existing account shows no penalties within the last 24 months next preceding their application for additional or different meters. 
(d)	If a customer's water service is cut off after having such customer's deposit previously refunded, or no deposit ever having been made, a new deposit will be required before water service can be reconnected. 
(Code 1976, §§ 6-2002, 6-2003; Code 1985, §§ 14-23, 14-24; Ord. of 5-11-1987; Ord. of 3-6-1989; Ord. of 7-3-2006(2))
 
Sec. 46-31. Separate meters.
Except for apartments and mobile home parks, which may have one master meter for multiple users, in no case shall more than one premises be supplied through the same meter but each separate premises (house, duplex unit, office building, garage apartment or other premises) shall have its own meter and receive water through the meter only unless otherwise specifically authorized by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2005; Code 1985, § 14-26; Ord. of 11-5-1984(1))
 
Sec. 46-32. Water meter reading.
All water meters shall be read monthly upon such cycles as may be convenient for the water department. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2010; Code 1985, § 14-27)
 
Sec. 46-33. Water rates.
The water rates shall be as established from time to time by the city for residential customers within the city limits. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2009; Code 1985, § 14-31)
 
Sec. 46-34. Billing for water and water cutoff.
All water bills are due and payable monthly not later than the tenth of the succeeding month. The public works director may cut off water on customers who shall have failed to pay their bills by the 15th of that month. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2011; Code 1985, § 14-32)
 
Sec. 46-35. Special late payment charge.
If a customer's name appears on a cut-off list for failure to pay such person's water bill, or if a customer has water cut off for failure to pay such person's water bill, such customer must pay such customer's entire account, including an additional charge in an amount as determined by the issuing department to turn the water on following the first cut-off and in an amount as determined by the issuing department to turn the water on following the second and all subsequent cut-offs, prior to such reinstatement of service, rather than paying only the amount delinquent. If such customer's account is turned over to a collection agency or an attorney for collection, there shall be added to such account the cost of collection. A penalty of an additional ten percent of any past due balance shall be added to any bill each month showing a past due balance. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2012; Code 1985, § 14-33; Ord. of 2-5-1979; Ord. of 3-19-1979; Ord. of 5-11-1987; Ord. of 3-6-1989)
 
Sec. 46-36. Landlord's liability.
Landlords and agents controlling property for domestic use or rooms for lodging purposes, or offices, shall be liable for water rents, and shall in every case give the public works directorwritten notice of the removal of the tenant or the nonuse of the water, and shall continue liable until such notice is given for any water actually used. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2013; Code 1985, § 14-34)
 
Sec. 46-37. Persons authorized to water tap.
No person but the public works director or a person authorized by such public works director shall tap any main or distributing pipe or connection. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2007; Code 1985, § 14-30)
 
Sec. 46-38. Interference or damage to equipment.
It is a misdemeanor to tamper with, interfere with, disable, bypass, damage, or destroy city equipment, meters, meter pits, pipes, or other facilities used in the operation of the gas, water and sewer system. Upon conviction the court may impose, in addition to a minimum fine of $100.00, restitution in an amount equal to the amount necessary to repair or replace the damaged equipment. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2015; Code 1985, § 14-28; Ord. of 3-6-1989; Ord. of 7-12-1999, § 1)
State law reference(s)—Theft of services, O.C.G.A. § 16-8-5; damaging, etc., utility property, O.C.G.A § 16-7-25. 
 
Sec. 46-39. Unauthorized persons prohibited from turning gas or water off and on.
No person except one legally authorized will be allowed to turn city gas or water on or off at the meter. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2004; Code 1985, § 14-25)
 
Sec. 46-40. Inspection; emergencies.
The public works director and the police authorities of the city shall have the right at all hours to enter upon any premises where the city water is taken for the purpose of inspecting the pipes and fixtures, setting and repairing meters, turning water on or off, examining the sanitary conditions incident to the use of the water and enforcing these rules generally. Every denial of this right will render the offending party liable to fine or imprisonment, or both. The public works director may stop the supply of water in case of emergency, and shut off for repairs or extensions, such public works director being the sole judge of the time and necessity therefor, reasonable notice being given when practicable. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2006; Code 1985, § 14-29)
 
Sec. 46-41. Illegal use of water and sewer services.
It is a misdemeanor to make any unauthorized water or sewer connection or to obtain or attempt to obtain unauthorized water or sewer services, including unauthorized use of fire hydrants. Upon conviction, the court may impose, in addition to a minimum fine of $200.00, restitution in an amount equal to the cost of water or sewer services illegally obtained. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2014; Code 1985, § 14-35; Ord. of 7-12-1999, § 2)
 
Sec. 46-42. Fire sprinklers and suppression systems.
(a)	Fire sprinkler and suppression systems shall mean a NFPA Standard 13 or NFPA Standard 13A or modified sprinkler system standard approved by the city or Cobb County or any other fire suppression system utilizing detector check valves, hydrants, and similar equipment, when any such system receives its water directly through a tap into the city water system line. 
(b)	All structures within the city which shall be required to have a sprinkler and suppression system pursuant to the city fire prevention and protection code shall pay a deposit in an amount as determined by the issuing department prior to the connection of the system to the water system of the city. The deposit is in addition to the water service deposit required in section 46-30. 
(c)	With response to the installation and use of fire sprinkler and suppression system which requires a separate tap into a water line belonging to the city, the charges in an amount as determined by the issuing department shall apply. The customer shall also bear all expenses for the purchase and installation of the fire protection meter, detector check, valve, meters, lines, and other fittings from the tap to the fire sprinkler and suppression systems. 
(d)	All accounts which have existing fire sprinkler and suppression systems in operation prior to May 1, 1991, shall not be required to pay the deposit for any existing systems. 
(e)	No fire protection sprinkler system shall be installed, repaired, altered, modified, added to, maintained, or inspected except in compliance with this Code and other regulations and ordinances in effect. 
(Code 1985, § 14-37; Ord. of 3-4-1991; Ord. of 7-3-2006(2))
 
Secs. 46-43—46-72. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. OUTDOOR WATER USE
 
Sec. 46-73. Authority of mayor to restrict; procedure.
At any time, and from time to time, the mayor is empowered to implement the following water use restrictions on water customers of the city water system, requiring compliance with the restrictions under the following levels and moving from one level to another for such periods as conditions my reasonably require. The notification by the city's water supplier or the state environmental protection division and the need to implement water use restrictions, or the loss of adequate water supply to the city, or that one or more city water tanks become empty shall be sufficient reason to implement such restrictions. The actions taken hereunder shall be reported to the next city council meeting, at which time the city council may modify the restriction if it deems it appropriate. 
(Code 1985, § 14-36(a); Ord. of 7-7-1986; Ord. of 10-6-1986; Ord. of 7-3-2006(2))
 
Sec. 46-74. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Address means the house number (a numeric or alphanumeric designation) that, together with the street name, describes a physical location of a specific property. The term "even numbered address" means a house number ending with the number 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or no house number. The term "odd numbered address" means a house number ending with the number 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. 
Declared drought response level means one of four levels of drought that can be declared based on the severity of drought conditions, with one being the least severe and four being the most severe. 
(Code 1985, § 14-36(b); Ord. of 7-7-1986; Ord. of 10-6-1986; Ord. of 7-3-2006(2))
 
Sec. 46-75. Applicability of rule.
These rules apply to any entity, and its customers, permitted by the state environmental protection division for water withdrawal or for operation of a drinking water system. 
(Code 1985, § 14-36(c); Ord. of 7-7-1986; Ord. of 10-6-1986; Ord. of 7-3-2006(2))
 
Sec. 46-76. Outdoor water use schedule—During non-drought periods.
Outdoor water use other than exempted activities shall occur only as follows: 
(1)	Odd-numbered addresses: Outdoor water use is allowed on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays. 
(2)	Even-numbered addresses: Outdoor water use is allowed on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays. 
(3)	There shall be no outdoor water use on Fridays. 
(Code 1985, § 14-36(d); Ord. of 7-7-1986; Ord. of 10-6-1986; Ord. of 7-3-2006(2))
 
Sec. 46-77. Outdoor water use schedule—During declared drought response levels.
During declared drought conditions, outdoor water use other than activities exempted in section 46-78, shall occur only during scheduled hours on the scheduled days. 
(1)	Declared drought response level one. Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 12:00 midnight. 
a.	Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays. 
b.	Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses are Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays. 
c.	There shall be no outdoor water use on Fridays. 
d.	Use of hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety, or flushing is prohibited. 
(2)	Declared drought response level two. Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. 
a.	Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays. 
b.	Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways are Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays. 
c.	There shall be no outdoor water use on Fridays. 
d.	The following are prohibited: 
1.	Using hydrants for any other purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety, or flushing. 
2.	Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks, and driveways except when necessary for public health and safety. 
(3)	Declared drought response level three. Outdoor water use may occur on the scheduled day within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. 
a.	The scheduled day for odd-numbered addresses is Sunday. 
b.	The scheduled day for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways is Saturday. 
c.	The following uses are prohibited: 
1.	Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety, or flushing. 
2.	Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, except when necessary for public health and safety. 
3.	Filling installed swimming pools except when necessary for public care or structural integrity. 
4.	Washing vehicles, such as cars, boats, trailers, motorbikes, airplanes, or golf carts. 
5.	Washing buildings or structures except for immediate fire protection. 
6.	Noncommercial fund raisers, such as carwashes. 
7.	Using water for ornamental purposes, such as fountains, reflecting pools, and waterfalls except when necessary to support aquatic life. 
(4)	Declared drought response level four. No outdoor water use is allowed, other than for activities exempted in section 46-78. 
(Code 1985, § 14-36(e); Ord. of 7-7-1986; Ord. of 10-6-1986; Ord. of 7-3-2006(2))
 
Sec. 46-78. Exemptions.
(a)	Mandatory water use restrictions shall not apply to the following outdoor water uses: 
(1)	Capture and re-use of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable local ordinances. 
(2)	Re-use of gray water in compliance with applicable local ordinances. 
(b)	The following established landscape water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use schedules of mandatory water use restrictions: 
(1)	Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by the state environmental protection division to provide reclaimed wastewater. 
(2)	Irrigation of personal food gardens. 
(c)	Newly (in place less than 30 days) installed landscapes are subject to the following: 
(1)	Irrigation of newly installed landscapes is allowed any day of the week, but only during allowed hours for the drought response level in effect, for a period of 30 days following installation. No watering is allowed during drought response level four. 
(2)	For new landscapes installed by certified or licensed professionals, commercial exemptions apply. 
(d)	The following golf course outdoor water uses are exempt from outdoor water use schedules of this division. 
(1)	Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by the state environmental protection division to provide reclaimed wastewater. 
(2)	Irrigation of fairways during times of non-drought and declared drought response level one. 
(3)	Irrigation of tees during times of non-drought and declared drought response levels one, two, and three. 
(4)	Irrigation of greens. 
(5)	The following commercial outdoor water uses are exempted from the outdoor water use schedules of this division: 
a.	Professionally certified or licensed landscapers, golf course contractors, and sports turf landscapers; during installation and 30 days following installation only. Professional landscapers must be certified for commercial exemptions to apply. 
b.	Irrigation contractors, during installation and as needed for proper maintenance and adjustments only. 
c.	Sod producers. 
d.	Ornamental growers. 
e.	Fruit and vegetable growers. 
f.	Retail garden centers. 
g.	Hydro-seeding. 
h.	Power washing. 
i.	Construction sites. 
j.	Producers of food and fiber. 
k.	Carwashes. 
l.	Other activities essential to daily business. 
m.	Watering-in of pesticides and herbicides on turf. 
(6)	Enforcement shall be by the city police department and code enforcement personnel and authorized personnel of the city water system. Enforcement may consist of warning, fines of not less than $100.00 to not more than $250.00 for each offense, or disconnection of water service by removal of the water meter and payment of fines and reinstallation of meter charges in an amount as determined by the issuing department or any combination of the foregoing. 
(7)	This section shall apply to all city water customers regardless of whether they reside inside the city limits or their property served with city water is inside the city limits. All citations issued for violations shall be returnable to the municipal court. The city hereby delegates concurrent jurisdiction over such offenses to the county government within which the property is served with city water lays if it is outside the city limits. If a citation is issued by county personnel for a violation of this section, it may also be returnable to the magistrate's court of the county where the property lies. 
(Code 1985, § 14-36(f); Ord. of 7-7-1986; Ord. of 10-6-1986; Ord. of 7-3-2006(2))
 
Secs. 46-79—46-99. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. BACKFLOW PREVENTION
 
Sec. 46-100. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Auxiliary intake means any piping connection or other device by which water may be secured from a source other than that normally used. 
By-pass means any system of piping or other arrangement by which the water may be diverted around any part or portion of a water purification plant. 
Cross-connection means any physical connection by which the public water supply is connected with any other water supply system, whether public or private, either inside or outside of any building, in such manners that a flow of water into the public water supply is possible either through the manipulation of valves or because of ineffective check or backpressure valves, is because of any other arrangement. 
Inter-connection means any system of piping or other arrangement by which the public water supply is connected directly with a sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, or other device that does or may contain sewage or other waste or liquid that would be capable of imparting contamination to the public water supply. 
Person means any persons, natural or artificial, including any individual form or association, and any municipal or a private corporation organized or existing under the laws of this or any other state or country. 
Public water supply means the waterworks' system furnishing water to the citizens of the city for general use by the state department of natural resources or the environmental protection division. 
(Code 1985, § 14-38(a); Ord. of 5-5-1997, § 1)
 
Sec. 46-101. Compliance with state rules.
The city public water supply shall comply with Ga. Comp. Rules and Regs. R. ch. 391-3-5-13 and the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act, 42 USC 300f et seq., legally adopted in accordance with this Code, which pertain to cross-connections, and establish an effective, ongoing program to control these undesirable water uses. 
(Code 1985, § 14-38(b); Ord. of 5-5-1997, § 2)
 
Sec. 46-102. Unlawful connections.
It is unlawful for any person to cause a cross-connection, auxiliary intake, by-pass, or inter-connection to be made; or allow one to exist for any purpose whatsoever. 
(Code 1985, § 14-38(c); Ord. of 5-5-1997, § 3)
 
Sec. 46-103. Nonexistent or unapproved connections.
Any person whose premises are supplied with water from the public water supply and who also has on the same premises a separate source of water supply or stores water in an uncovered or unsanitary storage reservoir from which the water stored therein is circulated through a piping system, shall file with the director of the water department a statement of the nonexistence of unapproved or unauthorized cross-connections, auxiliary intakes, by-passes, or interconnections. Such statements shall also contain an agreement that no cross-connection, auxiliary intake, by-pass, or inter-connection will be permitted upon the premises. 
(Code 1985, § 14-38(d); Ord. of 5-5-1997, § 4)
 
Sec. 46-104. Water department inspections.
It is the duty of the water department to cause inspections to be made on all properties served by the public water supply where cross-connections with the public water supply are deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be established by the water department. 
(Code 1985, § 14-38(e); Ord. of 5-5-1997, § 5)
 
Sec. 46-105. Right of entry.
The public works director or his designee shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time, any property served by a connection to the city public water supply for the purpose of inspecting the piping system thereof for cross-connections, auxiliary intakes, by-passes, or inter-connection. On request, the owner, lessee, or occupant of any property so served shall furnish to the inspection agency any pertinent information regarding the piping system on such property. The refusal of such information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed evidence of the presence of cross-connections. 
(Code 1985, § 14-38(f); Ord. of 5-5-1997, § 6)
 
Sec. 46-106. Remedy of connection violation.
Any person who is determined to have cross-connections, auxiliary intakes, by-passes, or inter-connections violating the provisions of this division, shall be allowed a reasonable time within which to remedy the violations. The amount of time shall be determined by the public works director. 
(Code 1985, § 14-38(g); Ord. of 5-5-1997, § 7)
 
Sec. 46-107. Protective device.
(a)	Where nature of use of the water supplied on premises by the water department is such that it is deemed: 
(1)	Impractical to provide an effective air-gap separation; 
(2)	That the owner or occupant of the premises cannot or is not willing to demonstrate to the official in charge of the system, or his designated representatives, that the water use and protective features of the plumbing are such as to propose no threat to the safety of portability of the water supply; 
(3)	That the nature and mode of operation within a premises are such that frequent alterations are made to the plumbing; or 
(4)	There is a likelihood that protective measures may be subverted, altered, or disconnected; 
The public works director, or his designated representative, shall require the use of an approved protective device on the service line serving the premises to ensure that any contamination that may originate in the customer's premises is contained therein. 
(b)	The protective device shall be a reduced pressure come type back flow preventer approved by the public works director as to manufacture, model, and size. 
(c)	The method of installation of back flow protective devices shall be approved by the director before installation. The installation shall be at the expense of the owner or occupant of the premises. 
(d)	The department shall have the right to inspect and test the device or annually or whenever deemed necessary by the director or his designated representative. Water service shall not be disrupted to test the device without the knowledge of the occupant of the premises. 
(e)	Where the use of water is critical to the continuance of normal operations or protection of life, property, or equipment, duplicate units shall be provided to avoid the necessity of discontinuing water service to test or repair the protective device. Where only one unit is installed and the continuance of service is critical, the director shall give written notice to the occupant of the premises of plans to discontinue water service and arrange for a mutually acceptable time to test or repair the device. Any repairs shall be made by qualified personnel approved by the director. 
(Code 1985, § 14-38(h); Ord. of 5-5-1997, § 8)
 
Sec. 46-108. Protection of potable water from contamination.
The potable water supply made available on the properties served by the public water supply shall be protected from possible contamination as specified herein. Any water outlet which may be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as follows: 
WATER UNSAFE FOR DRINKING. 
The minimum acceptable sign shall have black letters one-inch high located on a red background. 
(Code 1985, § 14-38(i); Ord. of 5-5-1997, § 9)
 
Sec. 46-109. Penalties for violation.
Any person who neglects or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction therefor, shall be fined not less than $10.00 nor more than $100.00, and each day of continued violation after conviction shall constitute a separate offense. In addition to the foregoing fines and penalties, the water director shall discontinue the public water supply service at any premises upon which there is found to be a cross-connection, auxiliary intake, by-pass, or intersection, and service shall not be restored until such cross-connection, auxiliary intake, by-pass, or inter-connection has been discontinued. 
(Code 1985, § 14-38(j); Ord. of 5-5-1997, § 10)
 
Sec. 46-110. Restriction on outdoor water of landscape.
Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: 
(1)	Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; 
(2)	Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable city ordinances and state guidelines; 
(3)	Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable county public health regulations; 
(4)	Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources to provide reclaimed wastewater; 
(5)	Watering personal food gardens; 
(6)	Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; 
(7)	Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
(8)	Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
(9)	Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on the property; 
(10)	Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
(11)	Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
(12)	Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or 
(13)	Hydroseeding. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 14-39, 1-1-2011(eff.))
 
Sec. 46-111. Enforcement.
Any violation of this section may also be enforced by a citation or accusation returnable to the appropriate court or by any other legal means authorized under this Code. Violation of this division is punishable as provided in section 1-9, in addition to administrative and other remedies available to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 14-40, 1-1-2011(eff.))
 
Secs. 46-112—46-135. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. SEWER
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 46-136. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
BOD (biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees centigrade, expressed in mg/L. 
Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
FOG means fat, oil and grease. 
Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking or disposing of food, and from the handling, storage or sale of produce. 
Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen concentration in moles per liter. 
Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking, or dispensing of food that have been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half-inch in any dimension. 
Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights and which is controlled by public authority. 
Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such groundwaters, surface waters and stormwaters as may be present. 
Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures or lagoons used for treating sewage presently owned or afterward acquired by this city or owned and operated by the county water system. 
Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
Sewerage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
Storm sewer orstorm drain means a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial wastes. 
Suspended solids meas solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids; and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1976, § 6-3001; Code 1985, § 14-40)
 
Sec. 46-137. Prohibited acts.
(a)	Except as hereinafter provided, it is unlawful for any person to construct or maintain or cause to be constructed or maintained any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(b)	It is unlawful for any person to maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the municipal sewerage works. 
(Code 1976, § 6-3002; Code 1985, § 14-41)
 
Sec. 46-138. Connection to public sewers required.
The owner of all houses, or other buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes within the corporate limits of this city and located within 250 feet of a line of public sanitary sewer now in existence or after constructed to which such house, or other building, or property may be connected so that sewage will flow therefrom and into such sewer line by gravity is hereby required at such owner's own expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the line of a public sanitary sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article within 60 days after the date of official notice to do so. 
(Code 1976, § 6-3003; Code 1985, § 14-42)
 
Sec. 46-139. Private sewage disposal.
(a)	Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 46-138, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with applicable rules of the county health department. 
(b)	At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. 
(c)	The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times at no expense to the city. 
(d)	No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the state department of natural resources. 
(Code 1976, § 6-3004; Code 1985, § 14-43)
 
Sec. 46-140. Building sewers and connections.
(a)	No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenances thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the public works director. 
(b)	There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)	For residential and commercial service; and 
(2)	For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
In either case, the owner or the owner's agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the public works director. 
(c)	All cost and expense incident to the connection of the building sewer from the owner's building to the municipal property line shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the connection of the building sewer. Any connection from the municipal property line into the public sewer shall be made by the city, for which the owner shall pay the city a standard sewer tap fee as provided in section 46-3. 
(d)	A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except that, where one building stands at the rear of another or on an interior lot, and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(e)	Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings when they are found, on examination and test by the public works director, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(f)	The building sewer shall be of cast iron pipe; ASTM specification A74; or plastic PVC sewer pipe, ASTM specifications 346 or greater. Joints shall be tight and waterproof. Any part of the building sewer that is located within ten feet of a water service shall be constructed of cast iron soil pipe with leaded joints. Cast iron pipe with leaded joints may be required by the public works director where the building sewer is exposed to damage by tree roots. If installed in filled or unstable ground, the building sewer shall be of cast iron soil pipe, except that non-metallic material may be accepted if laid on a suitable concrete bed or cradle as approved by the public works director. 
(g)	The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the public works director, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four inch pipe shall not be less than one-eighth inch per foot. 
(h)	Whenever possible the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall, which might thereby be weakened. The building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipes and fittings. 
(i)	In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(j)	All excavations required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the public works director. Pipe laying and back fill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM specification C12; except that no back fill shall be placed until the work has been inspected. 
(k)	All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. 
(l)	The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the "Y" branch, if such branch is available at a suitable location. If the public sewer is 12 inches in diameter or less, and no properly located "Y" branch is available, the city shall install a "Y" branch in the public sewer at the location specified by the public works director. Where the public sewer is greater than 12 inches in diameter, and no properly located "Y" is available, a neat hole may be cut into the public sewer to receive the building sewer, with entry in the downstream direction at an angle of about 45 degrees. A 45-degree ell may be used to make such connection, with the spigot end cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at the same or at a higher elevation than the invert of the public sewer. A smooth, neat joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the public works director. 
(m)	The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the public works director when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. 
(n)	All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-3005; Code 1985, § 14-44)
 
Sec. 46-141. Regulation of discharge into public sewers.
(a)	No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)	Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the public works director. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged upon approval of the public works director, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(c)	Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewer: 
(1)	Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit; 
(2)	Any water or waste which may contain more than 100 mg/L of fat, oil, or grease; 
(3)	Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid, or gas; 
(4)	Any garbage that has not been properly shredded; 
(5)	Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure, or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works; 
(6)	Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.0, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works; 
(7)	Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plan. The fixed upper limits for the constituents listed below, in parts per million (ppm), shall be: 
a.	Cadmium0.02
b.	Chromium1.00
c.	Copper1.00
d.	Cyanide0.20
e.	Nickel1.00
f.	Silver1.00
g.	Lead0.10
h.	Zinc3.00
i.	Phenol0.05
j.	Arsenic0.05
(8)	Any waters or wastes containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the sewage treatment plant; 
(9)	Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance. 
(d)	Grease, oil, and sand interceptors. 
(1)	Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the public works director, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, and other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the public works director and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(2)	Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily removable covers which, when bolted in place, shall be gas-tight and watertight. 
(e)	When installed, all grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at such owner's expense, in continuously efficient operation. 
(f)	Preliminary treatment. 
(1)	The admission into the public sewers of any water or wastes having: 
a.	A five-day biochemical oxygen demand greater than 300 mg/L; 
b.	Containing more than 350 mg/L of suspended solids; 
c.	Containing any quantity of substance having the characteristics described in subsection (c) of this section; or 
d.	An average daily flow greater than two percent of the average daily sewage flow of the city; 
shall be subject to the review and approval of the public works director. 
(2)	Where necessary, in the opinion of the public works director, the owner shall provide at such owner's expense such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to: 
a.	Reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to 300 mg/L and the suspended solids to 350 mg/L; 
b.	Reduce objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits provided for in subsection (c) of this section; or 
c.	Control the quantities and rates of discharge of such water or wastes. 
(3)	Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the public works director, and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until the approval is obtained in writing. 
(g)	Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at such owner's expense. 
(h)	When required by the public works director, the owner of any property served by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the public works director. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at such owner's expense, and the owner at such owner's expense shall maintain the same so the manhole shall be safe and accessible at all times. 
(i)	All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in subsections (c) and (f) of this section shall be determined in accordance with Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Sewage, at the control manhole provided for in subsection (h) of this section, or upon suitable samples taken at such control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. 
(j)	No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1976, § 6-3006; Code 1985, § 14-45)
 
Sec. 46-142. Power and authority of inspectors.
The public works director and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 6-3007; Code 1985, § 14-46)
 
Sec. 46-143. Penalties.
(a)	Any person found to be violating any provision of this article, except section 46-138, shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(b)	Any person who shall violate the provisions of section 46-138 or who shall continue any violation hereof beyond the time limit provided for in section 46-138, or who shall continue any other violation hereof beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) of this section, shall be deemed guilty of a municipal offense and upon conviction therefor shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1976, § 6-3008; Code 1985, § 14-47)
 
Sec. 46-144. Sewer rates.
The sewer rates shall be as provided by a written schedule of rates available to the public and approved by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-3009; Code 1985, § 14-48; Mo. of 10-20-1980)
 
Sec. 46-145. Public works director may establish other rules and regulations.
The public works director may establish other rules and regulations consistent with this Code and approved by the city governing the operation of his department. 
(Code 1976, § 6-3007; Code 1985, § 14-49)
 
Secs. 46-146—46-173. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. SEWER USE STANDARDS AND RESTRICTIONS
 
Sec. 46-174. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, 33 USC 1251 et seq. 
Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in mg/L. 
Chemical oxygen demand (COD) means a measure of oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidant. 
Cooling water means the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) means the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, or where appropriate, the term "Environmental Protection Agency" may also be used as a designation for the administrator or other duly authorized official of the agency. 
Floatable oil means oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable oil if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. 
Holding tank waste means any waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks, and vacuum-pump tank trucks. 
Indirect discharge means the discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants from any source regulated under section 307(b) or (c) of the Act into the POTW (including holding tank waste discharged into the system). 
Industrial user means a source of direct discharge which does not constitute a discharge of pollutants under regulations issued pursuant to section 402 of the Act. 
Industrial waste surcharge means the charge made in excess of the sewer service charge for all wastewater over and above normal wastewater. 
Industrial wastes means the wastewater from industrial processes as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes. 
Interference means the inhibition or disruption of the POTW treatment processes or operations which contributes to a violation of any requirement of Cobb County's NPDES permit. The term "interference" includes prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal by the POTW in accordance with section 405 of the Act or any criteria, guidelines or regulations developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), 42 USC 6901 et seq., the Clean Air Act, 42 USC 7401 et seq., the Toxic Substance Control Act, 15 USC 2601 et seq., or more stringent state criteria (including those contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to title IV of SWDA) applicable to the method of disposal or use employed by the POTW. 
Manager means the public works director or such other official as may be designated by the city from time to time to enforce the provisions of this article. 
National Categorical Pretreatment Standard orpretreatment standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with section 307(b) and (c) of the Act which applies to a specific category of industrial users. 
National Pollution Discharge Elimination System permit orNPDES permit means a permit issued pursuant to section 402 of the Act. 
Natural outlet means any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer overflows, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
Normal wastewater means wastewater discharged into the sanitary sewers in which the average concentration of total suspended solids and BOD is not more than 300 mg/L, total phosphorus is not more than 15 mg/L, total Kjeldahl nitrogen is not more than 18 mg/L; and total flow is not more than 25,000 gallons per day. 
pH means the logarithm (base ten) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions expressed in grams per liter of solution. 
Pollutant means any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt and industrial, municipal and agricultural waste discharged into water. 
Pollution means the manmade or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological and radiological integrity of water. 
Pretreatment ortreatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to or in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into a POTW. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, or by process changes or other means, except as prohibited by 40 CFR 403.6(d). 
Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
Publicly owned treatment works (POTW) means a treatment works as defined by section 212 of the Act which is owned in this instance by Cobb County or the city. The term "publicly owned treatment works" includes any sewers that convey wastewater to the POTW treatment plant, but does not include pipes, sewers or other conveyances not connected to a facility providing treatment. 
Suspended solids mean total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater, or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater and referred to as nonfilterable residue. 
Toxic pollutant means any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the EPA. 
User means any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into the POTW. 
Wastewater means the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, wastewater may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present. 
Watercourse means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1985, § 14-50; Ord. of 5-6-1986, § 1)
 
Sec. 46-175. Abbreviations.
The following abbreviations shall have the designated meanings: 
BOD 	Biochemical oxygen demand 
CFR 	Code of Federal Regulations 
COD 	Chemical oxygen demand 
EPA 	Federal Environmental Protection Agency 
L 	Liter 
mg 	Milligrams 
mg/L 	Milligrams per liter 
NPDES 	National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System 
POTW 	Publicly owned treatment works 
SIC 	Standard industrial classification 
SWDA 	Solid Waste Disposal Act, 42 USC 6901 et seq. 
TSS 	Total suspended solids 
USC 	United States Code 

(Code 1985, § 14-51; Ord. of 5-6-1986, § 2)
 
Sec. 46-176. Powers and authority of inspectors.
(a)	Duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing pertinent to discharge to the sewer system in accordance with the provisions hereof. 
(b)	While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to herein, the authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company. 
(c)	The duly authorized employees of the city shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds an easement for the purpose, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the wastewater facilities lying within the easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the easement involved. 
(Code 1985, § 14-52; Ord. of 5-6-1986, § 3)
 
Sec. 46-177. Compliance with regulatory requirements.
(a)	General. The provisions of this division shall not be deemed as alleviating compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. Specific user charge and industrial cost recovery requirements, promulgated pursuant to Public Law 92-500, shall be considered as a part of this division upon official adoption.
